item.title: Quicktime 6, Applescript, Rappelling, Xfree86
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Lauryn was up early this morning and seemed to be in a lot of pain. After wailing for 15 minutes we gave her some Tylenol and she settled down in half an hour. Then she wanted to play. She played all happy and fun for another hour while Brenda and I fell into and out of sleep. Then she yawned so I put her back to bed and I started tweaking this blog some more.
Quicktime 6 was released last night so I tried to modify my script to batch convert .mp3 files into .mp4 files. It hasn't worked yet, unless you want to say 'yes' to every file that you save. I'm having trouble with the file references and alias' to the saving location. Applescript is rather challenging with regard to that for me.
I'm going to help my brother-in-law Mike with his Scout camp, and I have to make sure I have all the equipment necessary for two rappelling lines. I'm still working on that. And I should be getting at my Xfree86 modifications for e-complex.

item.title: So I've Started A Blog
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Feeling the desire to keep a basic log of my thoughts, ideas, actions and emotions, I joined in the growing trend of creating a weblog.
I have, to some degree, come to a reasonable design. I don't like to tweak html for hours on end, and as I have done so, I leave my changes as they are coded.
I've been spending my days enjoying the company of Brenda and Lauryn, as well as working with Ryan and Matt on a project with e-complex. Its coming along quite nicely. Hopefully tomorrow I will be able to enact some of the changes that I have been planning on and preparing for. Xfree86 is a complex beast, hopefully I don't break it along the way.
see you tomorrow...
item.excerpt:encoded: Feeling the desire to keep a basic log of my thoughts, ideas, actions and emotions, I joined in the growing trend of creating a weblog.... Hopefully tomorrow I will be able to enact some of the changes that I have been planning on and preparing for.

item.title: Macworld Mumbles
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: So today was the Apple Macworld keynote. OS 10.2 (Jaguar) looks good, and though I like the idea of multiple calendars and a nice calendar program, I don't understand the idea of web-publishing your personal calendar. Not unless there was some sort of publish subscribe model where you could update it from any computer anywhere. Such a scheme would make good use of a wireless internet connection. The $100US subscription to .Mac services is a great way to turn iChat into a $100US instant messaging client. Grrr... Looks like I'll be setting up mail services here at skipandmadge.com for myself, and perhaps even my own webmail service. I just can't justify it. I have not found the iDisk to be THAT useful yet (but it seemed to be just getting fast enough). All the OS X references to "Connect to iDisk..." have now become bloat. However, the mpeg4 quicktime stream of the keynote was fantastic. Clear, clean, audio in sync. It finally worked the way streaming video is supposed to work. I'm interested in acquiring the new remote for my iPod, as well as making use of the enhanced calendar functionality. If only they could use the scroll wheel to move through a list of characters so you could modify contact info on the iPod. Another iPod improvement I'm interested in would be the ability to build ad-hoc (on-the-fly) playlists. Go into an "ad-hoc playlist" mode and then just scroll through the music using the select button to select upcoming songs. Then go back to "ad-hoc playlist" and switch out of that mode for regular functionality. Pick the playlist, and you have an on the spot grouping of music, suitable for the most random moments. You could even go into a "modify playlist mode" and move songs up and down in the playlist. Though it may not be the simplest of interfaces it shouldn't be that hard to build it in a reasonably clear manner. Interested in making the most of the 10GB on my iPod, I've been working on an applescript that will convert .mp3s to .mp4s. I could potentially make it convert from .aiff (directly off a CD?) but I haven't tried of yet. Get it here. The readme briefly outlines how it works (and the bug it has). I'm also having difficulty compiling Xfree86 after my last round of changes, wired errors when I #include items that may already be #included...
item.excerpt:encoded: OS 10.2 (Jaguar) looks good, and though I like the idea of multiple calendars and a nice calendar program, I don't understand the idea of web-publishing your personal calendar.... Go into an "ad-hoc playlist" mode and then just scroll through the music using the select button to select upcoming songs.

item.title: Mmm, Sunburn
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
My trip camping this weekend involved me getting a nice sunburn on my neck. I also banged up my shins nicely. I went to help give the kids a chance to do some rappelling. I ended up making it possible for one of the leaders to remain on the camp. That is, Mike, Brenda's brother, tore a muscle in his calf and could not go up and down the steep valley wall from the "road" to the camp sites. A zip line had been erected to "drop" supplies and equipment into the valley, but was too steep to send people on safely. So I rigged up a system to belay Mike on the zip line. We tied a harness that would fit him and lowered him into the valley. There he remained until the next morning. I couldn't return home that night, as I would need to set up a pulley system to extricate him from the valley. That night, using crevass rescue techniques from "Mountaineering, Freedom of the Hills" I built a Z pulley system using pullies and two ascenders that would give us a 3 to 1 mechanical advantage. So the next morning, after staying up until 4am supervising some kids hanging out by the fire, we had a relatively simple time hauling Mike out.
Friday night at camp also gave me a chance to lash another chair. Several years ago I built a chair. I remembered some of the flaws in the previous design and build a recliner chair that was quite comfortable. I should draw up the design (with directions) for future reference.
Arriving in Calgary at 4:00pm I found that Brenda had travelled with Ryan and Camila to the "Two Creek" ranch south of Longview. They had left instructions with me to come out for the rest of the evening. I was dead tired, but didn't want to miss out on a good time, so I showered and jumped in Ryan and Cam's car and drove for an hour out to the ranch. I scared myself by almost falling asleep on the way, but after a while the road turned to gravel and I was alert and enjoying the scenic view of the foothills. The ranch is a nice quite place down in a valley where creeks join. What a wonderful place. We saw horses, deer, and I badly wanted to go play in the large pool where the two creeks meet, but Lauryn was pretty sleepy and it was time to go. I was glad to go out there, despite my fatigue. Perhaps some other time I'll have the opportunity to go out there and work with some of their cattle. While I don't want to be a farmer/rancher full time, I certainly would enjoy helping someone else out from time to time.
item.excerpt:encoded: That is, Mike, Brenda's brother, tore a muscle in his calf and could not go up and down the steep valley wall from the "road" to the camp sites.... I was dead tired, but didn't want to miss out on a good time, so I showered and jumped in Ryan and Cam's car and drove for an hour out to the ranch.

item.title: FreeStanding
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Last night we visited Ryan and Camila at their Aunt and Uncle's home. They are house-sitting and we went over for the evening. After dinner, when we were playing with Satchmo, a Standard Schnauzer, Lauryn, excited by the dog, suddenly stood up on her own. She stood there for about 10 seconds before she decided to sit down again. Several times she defied the tendance to fall over and stood, unassisted, for several seconds.
item.excerpt:encoded: After dinner, when we were playing with Satchmo, a Standard Schnauzer, Lauryn, excited by the dog, suddenly stood up on her own.... Several times she defied the tendance to fall over and stood, unassisted, for several seconds.

item.title: Tardiness
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Several days of without an entry eh? You sure you're cut out for this 'blogging hobby? Overcoming my work problems with getting X to compile, I've been busy being busy. Lauryn is free standing more and more but only takes 1 step before she gets scared and sits down. And my hair, courtesy of Cari, has been trimmed. I should run faster now. A major reason for my tardyness is an eMac. Tuesday I purchased, for my parents, a 700 MHz eMac and after installing a couple of apps, I set it up to convert .wmf files to .ai. Boy that is a slow process. I'm trying to convert the Print Shop library of images to an Illustrator format. Slow going ... So tonight we'll be heading south to deliver the eMac to my parents. Hopefully they can enjoy it. Its a nice machine. When ram prices drop I'll have to get them more RAM. ... and setting up my own email server has proven to be a slow process...
item.excerpt:encoded: New eMac for my parents

item.title: eMacilicious
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: So I've sent and received several emails to/from my mom on her new eMac. She has only "lost" one message thusfar. I think she accidentally moved the mouse while holding down the button and selected the entire message and then deleted it by typing another word. Perhaps I should explain the concept of "Undo" to her, as I don't think it is a concept that she is familiar with. Her inexperience with "mousing" and the "no-button" apple mouse makes it easy for her to click and drag while simply trying to move the cursor. Finally a flaw with Apple simplicity. Clicking without trying. As well, I finally have my DNS and webserver settings figured out so skip.skipandmadge.com now points to this exact page. Perhaps I should put that link in my email signature to "spread the word" a bit more. That would necessarily mean that someone other than myself would have to find this blog interesting. Note to self: Email your brother

item.title: Enthymeme
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Well, my CD burner appears to have problems. I'm not sure why but it will never correctly burn a cd image. Looks like a good excuse to get a SuperDrive. But being poor as I am, it probably isn't going to happen any time soon. And the green beans are ready for picking, so before I go to work I think I am going to go pick a few. Yum. Fuzzy Fresh Green Beans. Our corn is looking good, albeit very short, with about 4 cobs per plant. The recent rain should hopefully let the cobs fill out. And people said you can't grow corn in Calgary! (Well, we're still waiting to disprove that, and it's probably not very relevant to most people. Good thing its relevant to me, right?)

item.title: Summerburn
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
A week in Waterton among friends and family. Such bliss...
After having my SCSI card die and prevent my machine from booting, I was able to ditch work for a week and go to Waterton. Participating in a family reunion, I enjoyed reencountering friends, who are now family, that I haven't seen for 5 to 7 years. It was fantastic.
I surprised myself by coming in 2nd in a 5 km fun run, and by being 2nd in a race to the top of Bear's Hump and down. Talk about stiff legs the next day! I could hardly walk, with inclines and declines becoming nearly impossible navigate so bad was my stiffness.
Too bad I had to pay Waterton sale prices to buy a pair of shoes to run in...
Another lesson I learned, not the hard way, was that canoes remain stable only while being used properly. That is, two friends tried to participate in a canoe race by paddling their canoe backwards - using the tail end of the canoe at the front. They ended up in the freezing lake and had to be "rescued."
item.excerpt:encoded: Ellingson Family Reunion 2002

item.title: Frozen
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
So the my broken tooth is being repaired. Today was the grind and freeze part of the job. In 11 days I get my crown. Apparently there was a large and nasty cavity under the dislodged filling.
I have these friends that want to go caving. I would act as guide and they would come along, but the scheduling just isn't working. One is moving, and having the movers come this weekend, the other has school a week from friday. I had wanted to make it a 3 day affair, but who knows if any of it will happen now. Mostly I just want to get out and tramp around a mountain. Another friend that I would like to come, already has the next few weekends booked. Ah, well, what can you do?
And if you're thinking of getting new wheels and bearings for your rollerblades, just don't do it. Just get new skates. Unless I totally looked in the wrong place, $50 for wheels and $40 for bearings. My used skates only cost me $45 in the first place. When I get rich I'll just have to get new skates.
item.excerpt:encoded: Tooth repair and caving

item.title: Limestone Horizons
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Friday was a beautiful day. The sun shone like photons from a nearby star, the wind blew like gas molecules excited by diferences in surface temperature. Dave, not I, wanted to go caving before starting the next semester of school. Thus, the swirling molecules and photons of light influenced my decisions such that we left the city at 17:00 and commenced our 7+km hike at 20:05. Along the 4x4 trail we marched and soon we arrived at the steep trail to our campsite. 2 and 2/3 hours after abandoning the Kia we arrived at the Plateau and enjoyed the welcoming scent of burning pine logs. Near some other cavers, and their dwindling campfire, we unfurled our sleeping bags and positioned ourselves perpendicular to pull of gravity.
The heat of the August night, combined with the plush environ of a subzero (-20) down sleeping bag, made comfort a fleeting affair. Exposing myself to the fragrant mountain air quickly relieved the building warmth within the bag, but one could not sleep and carry on the duty of temperature regulation all night. Eventually a position of sleeping half in the bag, and half exposed, produced a sufficient radiator effect to allow prolonged rest, yet my left hip ached in the morn due to the constant evening chill it endured.
The gooey taste of instant oatmeal, and the heady smell of turkey sausages enlived this pair of hikers sufficent to seemingly sprint up the mountainside to Cleft - the cave with the carrot-shaped entrance. Inside, attempting to follow another group of speologists, we took a left turn and followed an icy (ice flows and crystals on the walls) passage to what appeared to be the end of the road. A small hole in the floor/wall, suggested a possible continuance, and when combined with the recollection of stories of a "squeeze hole" through to a larger passage and the ugly signatures of previous touristic adventures in this room we decided to try it out. I then flopped on my back and stuck my head in the hole and discovered that indeed a larger passage did lie beyone this limestone sphincter. Wriggling through I beckoned to Dave who followed. Continuing along this passage we soon felt the warmth of August air and knew that we must be readily approaching one of Cleft's two lookouts.
These windows to the valley opposite the entrance, are some 600 feet (at least) above the scree below. Carefully peaking over the jaggged edge we basked in the warmth of the surterranian world for only a minute or two before skulking back into the inky blackness. Near the window we had noticed a small passage heading east. This we decided to take in the hopes of making the "loop" of which others had spoken. Crawling a short distance along this passage, I soon heard the sound, and voiced, of the other party. Reaching a spot where the small passage widened, we crawled up onto a shelf and waited for the other group of seven to pass. Chatting briefly we learned that they had headed to the other window first and so we were meeting midway through the loop of seeing both lookouts. Once they continued on to where we had just been, we crawled forward on to the portion of the cave that we had not yet seen. Soon this small tunel became icy, with frozen pools of water on the floor. At times this passage would probably make traversers quite wet. For us it was closer to an ice slide as we decended to the main passage in front of us. Appearing in the familiar main passage, we continued through a tall and skinny section of the cave to the second window. It is far less of an enjoyable spot than the first, as the floor slopes steeply to the cliff edge, and to get near the edge you must brace yourself against the narrow walls to feel safe.
Thus having reached both lookouts, we turned around headed for the other side of the mountain - the entrance. Arriving we stowed our underground gear and prepared to descend. Soon the other party emerged and, having brought significantly less equipment than us mules, began the descent to the main camp area. The youngest member of their party attempted to run down the scree slope and, allowing his upper body to travel faster down the mountain than his feet, fell head over heels down the slope. After one revolution he managed to slide on his back to a stop. The rest of his party rush to his aid, but he quickly stood and appear, from our distance, to be alright. Certainly he was bruised and a bit battered, but after a several minute rest he then limped off the mountainside.
Needless to say we were careful in our descent of the same section. However, before descending to the campsite, we stopped to fill our water bottles. Leaving mine wedged between some rocks to catch the drips, I scampered up the mountainside above the cave entrance in the hopes of sseing an easy route over the mountain into the opposite valley where lies the entrance to Gargantua and Yorkshire Pot. I believe I know the way, but making this trip by myself was not in the agenda. Thus after scoping out the surroundings I descended to the watering hole where Dave and I hoisted our packs and descended.
We intended to quickly retrieve the belongings remaining at our campsite and thence continue back down the mountain and out the 4x4 trail to the Kia. Our hasty attempt to leave was halted by a choice encounter with the father and son responsible for digging out the bottom end of Yorkshire Pot completing the fabled "through trip" of one of Canada's longest (19km?) caves. Naturally this cave is rather labyrinthine and the through trip does not necessitate covering all of those 19 kilometers. We learned of the exit and its location, and were able to find out some truths about this cave. We also learned of the existance and documentation of other caves in the area. What a great chance to learn more and from what a great source!
Soon we departed and slowly descended the mountain on our sore legs and feet. The kilometers passed and soon we arrived, tired an happy at the silver Kia. Home was but a 3 hour drive away.
I'm not certain when next I'll be heading to that area, but certainly a trip to the bottom of Yorkshire Pot is on the horizon.
item.excerpt:encoded: Caving with Dave Feasel

item.title: Saddle Sores
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
When you haven't done it for a while, you don't remember how much you've forgotten.
So its been about a full year since my last escapade with blogging. University hampers non-academic creativity. Now is my chance to share my opinions with anyone who thinks my opinion is worth reading.

Mostly I'm just trying out this new blogging software called iBlog. I'd link to it but well, I'm not advertising for it yet - this is the first I have used it.

And if you think my titles and subject lines are strange, make no sense, or are misleading, make up your own and do this yourself. Try to come up with something more creative than "Skip's Big Book of the Way Life REALLY Is" or the incomparable "Skip's Blog"

Not so smart now, are ya?

item.title: Abseiling Preparations
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
A list of equipment requirements for tossing 24 girls off a cliff.


I'm going to be showing some 12-13 year old girls how to rappel on Wednesday so here's my procedure and equipment list.

2 sessions of 20-24 girls
2 ropes - using one static line for both "ropes." The routes are side by side so girls will have to go down in pairs.
I run the second rope, Ryan runs the first (with Brenda to assist at the bottom)

Instruction Steps
1 Introduction
Bring the girls to the face - most often people go up it and its a lot of work. A similar sensation occurs when you go down. Its an easy way to start. Has anyone done this before?
There are 3 rules:
i) Don't step on the rope
ii) Don't drop the metal equipment - it can get cracks so fine that you can only see it with and XRay (I should xray my equipment at work sometime for fun)
iii) Double check each other - Check each other. Checking is what eliminates the danger of the situation. If everything is done up correctly, you're more likely to get hurt driving here than doing this.

And one more rule:
Everyone can try as often as we have time, but no one HAS to do it. I would hope that everyone will try at least once - unless you try, you'll never know what you're missing. Don't worry if you're scared, I was terrified the first time I tried it back when I was 12. Now I'm hooked.

2 Explain the equipment
Harness - how to put it on - double back the buckles. Everyone helps each other put them on and check each other.
Carabiner, figure 8 - explain the friction. Have the rope run through and demonstrate (& the lingo too -> on rope, on belay, off belay, off rope)

3 Explain how it will work
Two ready on top, two on rope, two at bottom as safety, four on deck (first two showing the next two how to put on the harness & check)

Equipment list
8-10 harnesses
8-10 locking 'biners
8-10 helmets
4 slings
1 static rope
1 dynamic rope

Each girl should take less than, but not more than (hopefully) 5 minutes from top to bottom to off rope.

Estimate time requirement for 20 girls to each go once and 10 of them to go two times
(this is assuming only one rope is in use)
20 girls x 5 minutes = 100 minutes (1 hour 40 minutes)
10 girls x 5 minutes = 50 minutes (combined with the 20 girls = 150 minutes = 2 hours 30 minutes)
item.excerpt:encoded: There are 3 rules: i) Don't step on the rope ii) Don't drop the metal equipment - it can get cracks so fine that you can only see it with and XRay (I should xray my equipment at work sometime for fun) iii) Double check each other - Check each other.... Have the rope run through and demonstrate (& the lingo too -> on rope, on belay, off belay, off rope) 3 Explain how it will work Two ready on top, two on rope, two at bottom as safety, four on deck (first two showing the next two how to put on the harness & check) Equipment list 8-10 harnesses 8-10 locking 'biners 8-10 helmets 4 slings 1 static rope 1 dynamic rope Each girl should take less than, but not more than (hopefully) 5 minutes from top to bottom to off rope.

item.title: Le Tour
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Summertime addiction to seeing the countryside of France

So we're 10 days into the Tour de France and yesterday was an eventful day. Check this (Stage 9 highlights). Unfortunately it requires RealPlayer. Remind me not to break my Femur in the same manner. The race ended yesterday in Gap and I have a friend, Jean-Luc Guitton from Gap. Well, this morning, after not having seen or conversed with him for over 4 years, I got an email from him this morning. He's moving close to Paris, away from his beloved south of France, and is getting married soon. Quite the interesting coincidence.

I'm anxious about going back to France, but I'm wondering if I should hold off until next year when I can go and SEE the Tour live... I'd go up on one of the mountain passes in the Pyrenees I think. It would be a blast.

Time to save my shekels.
item.excerpt:encoded: Summertime addiction to seeing the countryside of France So we're 10 days into the Tour de France and yesterday was an eventful day.... I'm anxious about going back to France, but I'm wondering if I should hold off until next year when I can go and SEE the Tour live...

item.title: Conglomerate Bug Bites
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Yesterday was the trip to the mountains to teach some 12 and 13 year old girls how to rappel. It really went quite well. Ryan and Madge were my assistants with Lilo filling out the cute requirement. Two groups of about 21 girls, and some of their leaders rapped a 22' face in Heart Creek. They all followed directions very well and all but 4 or 5 of the girls rappelled, many of them multiple times. It was a a beautiful sunny day, so it was nice to not be at work. Lilo, having seen all these other girls come down the mountainside, wanted to do it too. She asked to go up the mountain, and asked to have a harness. I tied a little harness around her pamper butt and clipped a bent gate 'biner onto it so she'd be just like everyone else. She marched around happily for a while, and then asked to "climb" too. I lifted her up onto the the wall, about 5 feet up, put a rope through her rappelling device, and held onto her as I let her slide down the wall. Just because you're 2 years old doesn't mean you can't do everything the big kids do! In-between groups, Ryan and I had time to climb two routes. The first was an easy 5.9 and the second a sort and dirty 5.11c(Voodoo Lounge ). I managed to do the 11c last year, but I haven't climbed for about 5 months and my strength and endurance has suffered. I lead partway up it first, and worked at THE move until I was exhausted. Ryan then made it on his second try. I tried again and failed, so Ryan red-pointed it and cleaned the route. Once we were done at Heart Creek, he and I hiked off into the bush in search of some boulders I had heard about. The quick and dirty map that Mike made for us was surprisingly accurate.The boulders were a collection of a conglomerate upheaval in the middle of a mostly flat pine forest. They were 90% covered in thick lichen that was unsuitable for climbing (plus we see no need in destroying nature just to develop more climbing areas). The two good barespots we found were tough enough for us to play on until neither of us could bare to touch the rock anymore, as the rough conglomerate (and tiny crimpers) were murderous on the fingertips. I was not successful on the second problem, but made some headway after many attempts. If more of the rock were bare, this collection of 5-8 boulders would be a nice little area. Photos of the area can be found here. I am in the blue shirt, Ryan (as always) in yellow, and Dave (who showed up for the last hour) is in green.
item.excerpt:encoded: I tied a little harness around her pamper butt and clipped a bent gate 'biner onto it so she'd be just like everyone else.... The two good barespots we found were tough enough for us to play on until neither of us could bare to touch the rock anymore, as the rough conglomerate (and tiny crimpers) were murderous on the fingertips.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I notice that your particular knowing of this topic is strong and thorough. What a goody to locate someone writing whom not merely possesses knowledge but additionally the opportunity to connect via easy to visualize and recall info-bytes. Blog a lot more!

item.title: First Post
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: No, Really it is the first post. After too much fiddling over the past two days I now have movabletype installed on a base 10.3 install. Mostly it is straightforward but configuring mysql is definitely my weak point. I had to use Navicat (http://www.mysqlstudio.com/mac_detail.php3) to configure the users and permissions. I plan on posting my set of directions so others can figure it out as well.

item.title: Fink
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: So I've not been content to just get MovableType installed, I also wanted to make use of this blogtimes plugin. Unfortunately it depends on the GD perl module which depends on the presence of libgd. libgd isn't installed by default on OS X so after trying to avoid it (as I'm just rather afraid of it) for some time I looked to see if Fink had it (I was pushed toward Fink after seeing this Bugzilla post .) Fink had a copy but it hasn't been built for Panther yet so I took a gamble and went to the libgd maintainer's site and grabbed the source. After running the makefile, well, it said that I didn't have libpng or libjpeg (but I didn't care about libjpeg). Fink this time did have a 10.3 (Panther) build of libpng so I installed it via Fink. (I tried to build it on my own from the source but failed and didn't want to figure it out.) Now comes to the reason why I love to avoid Fink. It installs packages in /sw instead of /usr or /usr/local and then when you want to build something (like say libgd or the GD perl module) you have to know how to tweak the configure files or environment variables or... (I just don't know what all) so that the makefiles will work in /sw/include and /sw/lib. Needless to say this process just isn't clear to me yet. But the hack that I am, I made it work. I finally got the libgd ./configure to find my libpng install and I built and installed libgd successfully into /usr/local/lib. Next (it was hard to even remember what I was trying to get at in the first place), I followed the bugzilla patch (link above) to successfully install the GD perl module via cpan ('look GD' instead of 'install GD' and a reasonable dose of emacs). I then grabbed the MovableType plugin and placed it in the plugin folder for MT, copied the sample tags and voila! But when I rebuild this index page with MT, I get an error :( Poop, more debugging, but as you can see, its late and I need to ride my bike to work tomorrow. At least this project worked unlike that time I tried to build Gnome2.2 from scratch... BAH! [Update 2003-11-18 01:50:44] I had an improper path to the 'save_dir'. Well, it was an empty path so the html had a path to http://www.skipandmadge.com//blogtimes.png instead of http://www.skipandmadge.com/images/blogtimes.png Just another testimony of the power of lost sleep.

item.title: Messy Messy
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: So I'm trying to incorporate a previous design into this design and well, its coming along but it takes time. Sorry about the mess. I'm thinking of going for a mostly graphic-less layout. Hopefully I can make this all work nicely with the major browsers. Safari and Firebird are ok thusfar, but I had a problem with IE6. Grrr, now I remember why I don't do this for a living. I'm going down to San Diego for work tomorrow to learn about some parts we'll be using in our next design. Hopefully I'll get a chance to check out an Apple Store and poke around.

item.title: Avoiding Hacks
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: So if anyone visited this page over the past weekend (and they were using IE6 or IE5 on Windows) they would have seen the blog (text) portion of the sight going under the images and links on the right hand side. If anyone really wants to know how I fixed it, I got rid of the "position:absolute" css propertly for the center column and have the text margins set to the width of the sidebars. At least I didn't have to do some silly hack to get around it. Here's hoping that I can get a design I like without resolving to browser detection and css hacks. Standards should JUST WORK! Why doesn't everyone implement CSS the same? Oh and San Diego was nice and warm (pleasant) but I didn't get to the beach or ride the wooden rollercoaster. I did get to the applestore however and figured out that will the improved strength of the CDN dollar (US dollar weakness) I could have saved $270 CDN by purchasing a PowerBook south of the border. GST on such a purchase would be $240 CDN so it would really work out to just paying the list price (sans GST).

item.title: Not enough air
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I've been trying to ride my bike to work as much as possible (3 or 4 days a week) and hope to ride through the entire winter. Unfortunately my bike has been driving me absolutely crazy. Acutally its not the bike so much as the tires and tubes. Since I began riding in August, I have had no less than 7 flat tires. These aren't punctures, they're valve stem separations or tears.
Basically what seems to happen is as I ride the tire shifts (rotates) on the rim. As it does so it pulls the tube with it. The valve stem is fixed in place so as the tube moves with the tire, the rubber stretches on one side of the valve stem until it tears or the valve stem separates.
I've tried multiple tube brands, doublesided tape to stick the tube and tire to the rim, and spray on adhesive.
I'm getting sick of the impending flat tire I will have either leaving from work or coming to work. I need this problem fixed. My next attempt will be to coat the inside of the tire (and the outside of the tube) with baby powder so as to eliminate tube/tire friction. Then if the tire does shift on the rim, it won't pull the tube along with it. Grrrrr.
On another note, skipandmadge.com now shows up if you google for "skipandmadge." Hopefully by continually adding more content it will keep getting indexed by the search engines.
And I do intend to continue modifying the layout, but work has been far too busy. (ie. I've been putting in long work hours and working thorough lunch thereby leaving no extra time for fiddling.)

item.title: Some assembly required
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: The baby powder seems to have worked. I don't know if/when I'll need to give it another dose but three days of riding now and no flats or crooked valve stems. Now all I need are my new pedals to come in and for a pair of biking shoes to show up and I'll be crusing to and from work in comfort (relatively speaking). If I continue to avoid getting flats I may actually be able to save enough $$$ to get some cycling pants or even fancy 3ply GoreTex pants. I think I've gotten Ryan's Christmas present or birthday present collected. I'm not sure which it will be - I haven't decided yet. Ryan, when are you going home for Christmas? Oh, and I need to build a fancy bright headlight for my bike using these Luxeon Emitter super-bright LEDs.

item.title: Not alone
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Looks like I'm not alone with having my valve stem shear off in cold weather. I found this IceBiking site via this google search (search the first page for "valve stem"). The thing is I was having this happen BEFORE it got cold but that must have been because my front tire is 8 years old and doesn't stick to the rim very well.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think americans and canadian have different thresholds for what defines cold :)

item.title: South of Pyongyang
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Sometimes when you just seem to have made your mind up about something isn't it "wonderful" when circumstances immediately change and prove you wrong? One of my co-workers volunteered to spend Christmas in Korea helping support our manufacturing efforts. He will be there for almost the entire month of December, returning home shortly after the start of the new year. I took confidence in this that, as he would be there, no one else would need to go. I came to that conclusion on Monday or Tuesday. Yesterday the situation changed. To minimize potential problems one person from basically each discipline will be heading to Seoul to support manufacturing (and fight fires as they happen). I figured my name was on a list somewhere but took "Joe's" commitment to going as giving me a bye for this session. I was wrong. Yesterday I was asked and commited to going to Korea for two weeks starting Monday. It will be an interesting time I'm sure. One concession I have about going to Korea, and not stay here with my family during this pre-Christmas bustle, is that one of my good University of Calgary friends lives in Seoul. Eric and I graduated together with Computer Engineering degrees and he decided to move back to Korea in September. I was afraid that I would not be able to make contact with him before the trip, but yesterday we exchanged emails and I hope that we will be able to get together while I am, for perhaps once in my life, in his neighbourhood. I have lots to do to prepare for my trip, but most of all I wish I had an extra $3000 CDN laying around so I could increase the comfort of my trip by using one of these 15 inch aluminum slabs during the long flight. Five hour battery life stinks. Anyone have a spare digital camera I could borrow?

item.title: PhotoTest
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: So, somehow there is a way for me to remotely upload photos that can then appear in my blog entries. I'm not sure how to do it right now but I would like to experiment and figure it out before I find myself in Seoul. So here's a pretty picture to demonstrate the MovableType image upload capabilities. Now I just have to remember how, using CSS, I can have the text nicely wrap the image... I know how, just not off the top of my head.

item.title: Bulgogi as fast food
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Flew into Seoul today. My iPod Sony MDR-v700DJ headphones and Tom Clancy book made the flight go quickly enough. 11.5 hours is pretty long of a flight anyway - I don't know if there's really any way to make it go FAST. The best part of the flight is that the entire middle section of the Boeing-767 seats was empty. 3 of us grabbed entire 3 seat rows to ourselves. I didn't sleep much but it sure was nice to spread out things and use lots of pillows to get comfy as I read. Unfortunately the first chapter of the book, that I read on the way to Vancouver, involved an airline hijacking. Great set of thoughts to get into your head as you are about to fly halfway around the world. There is a slight touch of snow on the ground - the temperature is just below freezing - but the bus ride from the airport to the hotel was awful because it was so HOT in the bus. Our hotel is very nice - about 1 mile (a visual guess) from the Olympic Stadium. I have a night time picture of the olympic rings that I'll put on here. We arrived at about midnight home time and then went down under the hotel to the mall to find something to eat. And that's where we found the Bulgogi. I should have taken Ryan's camera with me to take a picture of the food. It looked great and actually tasted pretty good. Kimchi and salted squid for an appetizer followed by the Bulgogi served in a piping hot cast-iron bowl. It was yummy and spicy and hot enough to burn my tongue. Pretty good for 6,000 Won. After dinner it was back to the hotel. I was falling asleep in the elevator. Naturally I woke up a couple of times during the night not knowing where I was. And I had just settled back to a deep sleep when my 6:45am wake-up call occurred. At least the hotel room has a nice bathroom (I took pictures). The shower is wonderful!

item.title: Tardy
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: The trip to Korea is just about over and well, I've been swamped most of the time. I had planned to write an update every day, but since Monday we have been busy almost every waking hour. Things are going well and as I leave tomorrow I hope that I have sufficiently instructed the workers here on how to debug and repair faulty product. I also wanted to post pictures that I took - and hoped even to take pictures regularly, but this certainly hasn't been a vacation. This laptop has also hindered my attempts, as before posting an image it is necessary to clean it up and resize it, because any photo editing software runs slowly on it and, well, its just too much of a headache to try and do it when you're so short on time. Last night I wanted to do some data analysis to work on a solving a common failure. Remembering the effectiveness of lex to parse through a text file using regular expressions and create tokens of different type and value, I decided to manipulate some python code from my compiler construction university course of last year. Within four hours I had a complete program that would read and parse a folder full of text files (one file per product tested) and output a file containing a list of specific test results for each modem. This tab-deliminated file could then be easily imported into excel for analysis. (But I don't have Excel installed on this machine because I can't spare the drive space...) The processing engine is quite fast - but as each record is loaded into memory before the results are output, I think that I am running into a memory limit as the program would lock up the machine while loading the 75th record. (Each record is about 500 lines long, 7 entries per line.) I need to add features to it now so that it can pull up any set of tests from the group of tested products. Lexing the data has allowed me to keep each test (its limits and results) together in an "object" so printing the data from arbitrary objects should be quite simple to do. (Right now the output is hardcoded for the tests of interest). Ideally we should load the data into a database that is built to accept queries - perhaps my tool will act similarly - but this should at least get us going.

item.title: For Wanda
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Wanda, you can see the two parts of the letter here (page 1) and here (page 2). I should really compress these images some more as they're rather large and will be slow to load. Please be patient.

item.title: CVS
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: I've been working on a software project (its been idle for 2.5 months now) that would be nice to use with CVS. My friend Matt wrote up some basic instructions that I tried to use and almost got to work, but some Mac OS X project bundles (folders that behave like files) didn't seem to agree with CVS and I ran out of enthusiasm trying to make it work. I reverted to daily backups to my iPod. I just ran into this article at developer.apple.com that may be able to help me sort it out and get it working. I had yet to find a proper guide to setting up a personal CVS server and checking personal projects in and out. MacOSXHints.com is usually a good place for this stuff but this post didn't show up until now. The hints relating to Xcode are particularly relevant to me.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I just ran into this and it may be a decent guide to combine CVS and Xcode http://www.exittoshell.com/articles/cvs-setup.shtml

item.title: MOSXS - Apache webserving on OS X
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: So I've been running this site on my desktop mac for several years now (since OS X Public Beta I believe). This is by far the most sophisticated it has been, and to many web developers, its still very amature. I find, however, that too many web-development sites cater to themselves and not to the "common man." They explain how to enhance your sites but assume you already employ the common features. That's why the CSS-pure weblogging movement began with unemployed web developers. I think that, while initially quite complicated, non-static web development is within the reach of the average designer (the Joe who can make fancy and compliant static sites). They shouldn't have to go to IT school to figure out how to use server-side scripting (cgi, asp, php, etc.). All they need is a good tutorial that explains the basic process and events and doesn't make assumptions about past experience. That's the beauty of OS X. making DVDs of home movies, keeping thousands of music songs organized and available on the world's most popular mp3 player, purchasing music online (and not pirating), organizing and cataloging digital photos, and even publishing movies and photos on a homepage. In fact, Apache, the worlds most popular webserving package, comes installed by default on OS X and can be securely turned on by clicking on a checkbox. Make the common task simple and intuitive - that's what Apple's good at. If you want complex to configure capabilities you may find your preferred computing platform elsewhere. If you're one of these people, the idea of enhancing your website (personal or professional) with server-side scripting, a database, or other complex to configure features is a no-brainer. You'll download, configure/make, make install, look up the appropriate man pages and have your site fixed up in as little as 12-48 hours. But for the common man, "Mac OS X Style" (MOSXS) tutorials are needed. The beautiful thing is that the tutorials linked to below exist because of Mac OS X. Mac users historically expect to be able to get what they want done with a minimum of fuss. Thus with Mac OS X's growing adoption, the expectation to do things usually only available to the configure/make/make install crowd (without all the fuss) has resulted in marvelous projects such as fink and tutorials that actually tutor (instead of a list of indecipherable steps). Sick of those tutorial-writing geeks acting elitist by writing vague and complex tutorials? Read these instead: http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/collections/webserving.html http://developer.apple.com/internet/ Fortunately, due to Mac OS X's UNIX roots, these tutorials, while written for OS X, give insight on how do do the same things on a windows, linux or BSD box (Jeremy, this means YOU). Now I just need to find or write a "Mac OS X Style" (MOSXS) tutorial for the Terminal. Anyone seen one?

item.title: Them's the Brakes - a CMP warning
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Bing Bing Bing Bing After arriving home from my recent trip to San Diego, that was the sound that our car made each time you would accelerate or turn left. The "Brake" light on the dash, that is usually activated when you depress the emergency brake, would come on and the car would continue to Bing until you slowed down or turned right. The weather warmed up a bit and the Binging occurred less often but did not cease. Next I went to Korea for two weeks and when I arrived home it was 4 days before Christmas. The weather was cold again and the Binging occurred much more frequently. Still, we were too busy to take the car in to get looked at, and as our home lacks a garage, and it was -20 C, I wasn't keen on determining the problem out of doors. At the start of this week, Madge made a call to a local GM dealership and booked us an appointment for the car to get looked at. I had consulted the 1995 Oldsmobile 88 Owner's Manual and read about the Brake Warning Lamp, and the only instructions included, that were of any relevance, were to have the car serviced. The reason for choosing CMP? Well, last August our car had a flat tire and CMP was able to offer us the best price on four new tires. Unfortunately, the inattentive mechanics at CMP, after installing the new tires, places the hubcaps on incorrectly. The tire valve stem is to fit into a slot in the hubcap, but none of the 4 hubcaps were situated in this manner. One or two of the tires had slow leaks but we had opted to have the tires looked at when it was time for our next "free" tire rotation at CMP (before 15,000 km). So two days ago, Thursday, January 8, 2004, Brenda dropped me off at work and took the car to CMP. They were to check the slow leaking tire(s), determine why my car key made the Security Lamp come on, look into why the stereo backlight flickered, and tell us why the Brake Lamp was coming on. Thursday, all they did was fix one tire. They wanted to charge us for replacing the valve stem, and initially we were billed for this two, but as the tire had been leaking since we left their lot they refunded us the $17.50. We only have one car. We were stranded, carless at Brenda's parent's house, and had Thursday night committments. We were lucky to have their help. Friday, for half the day, we heard nothing from CMP. Brenda called and left a message with the service representative Frank. Finally we heard from him and Brenda relayed me the details. Basically, the brakes on the car, according to them, were shot. It was going to cost $1,200 to fix the car. WHAT!?! That's absolutely crazy!!! Brenda was wise enough to ask for a repair breakdown, which she relayed to me at work. I priced out some parts, to do the same job, and called Frank back to confirm the problems and their price, and then told him that I could do the work myself and asked when I could pick up the car and how much their efforts thusfar were worth. I was given a ride to CMP, paid $200 for their work, had to get a refund for the valve stem replacement, drove to Partsource to get the necessary parts to do the job (plus synthetic oil and a filter for an oil change, and new wiperblades that I'd change while I was at it). The total for the parts (and oil) came to just over $300 CDN, a far cry from CMP's $1200 pricetag. Certainly CMP would be charging for their labour, but 3X the parts price for labour? You've got to be kidding! (And I purchased the best quality third party parts possible - its not like I was going to do a complete brake job on my car and use the cheapest stuff available.) So what exactly did CMP say was wrong? Well, the right rear wheel cylinder (the part that pushes the brake shoes out into the brake drum) had been leaking and the shoes and drum were covered with brake fluid. The shoes would need to be replaced. The reason, Frank said, that the Brake Warning Lamp was coming on was because the brake fluid had been leaking out and the fluid level, by the master cylinder, had fallen to a point where the sensor was being tripped and we were being Binged to death (well, annoyance).

item.title: Splines not spines
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Why blogging is fun AND useful

My friend Matt did a Fourth Year Electrical Engineering Individual Project for course credit at the U of C, and while I can't explain the entire project I do know that it involved the use of Cubic Splines to mathmatically fit a complex curve. (Don't worry, the techical gargon ends after the next paragraph.) The complex curve would get divided into segments, and each segment could be "exactly" defined by a cubic function (ie. y = x^3 + 2x^2 - x + 4). Well, there's a project I'm working on at work where fitting a spline to a set of data points could be very useful. I looked up some C code on how to do it several months ago and built a project to test it out. It seemed to work but I never, until today, had the chance to put it into practice and truly make use of it. Unfortunately, and this is why blogging is USEFUL, I didn't write about my experience, and link to the wonderful pages I discovered (I believe I even found a book excerpt that gave me the code AND explained the nuances of it), and now I can't remember where I found all the info, or where I saved it, and don't want to go sleuth for it again. I hate having to repeat myself again. (heh) I wish I could go to my own webpage, type "spline" into the search box, and have a listing of the links that were useful and a mild explanation. Bookmarks in a web browser should help in this situation, and luckily I use Safari and my bookmarks sync via .Mac across multiple machines, but in all reality, bookmarks are context sensitive. Sure you can organize them in folders (and subfolders), but really, to make the best use of them, you need to be able to link a bookmark (link a link?) to specific words/actions/situations. For example, in my bookmarks menu, I have a subfolder full of electronics links. No, not links to consumer electronics, but links to pages showing how to do "stuff" with electrical components - how to design Infrared (IR) Remotes for example. However, when 6 months go by, and I've added a bunch of links to other "goo" like stepper motor drivers, I hate having to go through a bunch of links with goofy names trying to remember why I bookmarked it and "Where on Earth I put the link to such and such?" (and on what computer)! Perhaps I'm giving away a "revolutionary idea" about how computers and people interact and how a piece of software could fill that void, but I don't think so. It a big shift from typical bookmarks and Word documents as ways of storing information. That's why I like a database driven blog, because you have an easy search interface that is globally accessible (any computer anywhere). Its not a perfect solution, but perhaps one day the mechanism for blogging will improve to the point where it is basically a "word processor" that handles images/video/links etc. but isn't proprietary and doesn't cost money to use/own/access. That and a new 15" PowerBook. That's ALL I want. Ever.

item.title: Are You Experienced?
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: http://www.ucomics.com/foxtrot/2004/01/17/

item.title: Fast User Switching and Sharing
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
One of the few features that Windows XP had that Mac OS X didn't have (other than "features" only interesting to virus/trojan/worm writers), before Panther was Fast User Switching. This feature allows more than one person to be logged into a computer at a time and allows the first user's applications to remain open while the second (or third...) user logs in and uses the machine as though she is the only one logged in. (See the above link for the marketing-style explanation.) Well, as the above links show, Panther changes that. It nice but for my own setup, Madge and I just leave my machine logged in as me and she has her own folder for all her stuff. It hasn't been a problem and evidently my preferences for dock location (left) and background picture (and whatnot) don't bother her. I have associates, however, who like Fast User Switching (FUS) but wish for a compromise between full FUS and the single login approach that Madge and I use. These people like being able to have separate logins and the ability to switch between them quickly and easily, but also wish to use the same iTunes and iPhoto libraries of music and pictures respectively. You share the same tastes in music and are in the same pictures, right? iCal could probably fall into this same category, and probably even AddressBook. Three days ago I decided that it might be worthwhile writting an Applescript application that would quickly and easily make the changes necessary to share iApp libraries (databases) between users. Today at MacOSXHints.com someone posted a method to share an iPhoto library. One of the comments even has a script for sharing an iTunes library. Unfortunately for the average "Joe," shell scripts (if you don't know what one is, don't worry about it) aren't like double clicking a program. So I've started poking into taking my idea and making it a reality. I'm using Applescript (and not a shell script) to do it because it offers great interoperability between native Graphical User Interface (GUI) apps and the lower system that shell scripts rely on. Thus I should be able to make some rather complicated system modifications in a manner that should be seamless to the end user. As I'll naturally use the MacOSXHints exactly for what they are, I'm not too concerned about trying to make money with a product to do this because:
  1. Though this isn't an "Open Source" project I'll be referencing others' work.
    (I could think it through on my own, but why reinvent the mechanics of a wheel when you're just making it look nicer?)
  2. If its truly a useful feature, Apple will just incorporate it into the Operating System anyway. (See Sherlock vs Watson).
Lets see if I actually come through and finish it now...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Tamara and I would love this I think; I would be very nice to be able to share the same set of photos and music!

item.title: ecto and error -65795
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Finding out the meaning of ecto error "-65795" and how to correct it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's funny that you linked to my character entity chart. I must warn you though that it's presently inacurate by representing depricated entities. I am presently working on a new chart that will be online after May 1. it will feature an extremely robust lookup table with more characters than you would know what to do with. My suggestion to you is if you use my chart, you should double check the entity by copying the output character and pasting it inside my parser to double-check the entity number. It's presently residing at: http://www.jovino.com/parse.html -- and is in a perpetual state of beta. The HEX codes still stand though. ;) cheers, jovino

item.title: Xcode Tutorial - a request for requests
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
So according to the "last 10 referrers" sidebar a lot of people are looking for an Xcode Tutorial. I would be more than happy to write an Xcode Tutorial about the things I've learned over the years using Xcode (and ProjectBuilder) to do introductory-level C, C++ and Objective-C coding.
My experience is primarily at the academic level - where most people's coding experience starts. I imagine that the people finding this site, while looking for an Xcode Tutorial, are at a similar level of experience. Xcode (and ProjectBuilder before it) is fantastic for University/College level C and C++ coding. The integration of GDB (in a non-command-line state) is fantanstic for finding coding errors and bugs. Its saves a ton of time. At one time I even found a python syntax-highlighting plugin for ProjectBuilder and Xcode reportedly has built-in syntax highlighting for more languages than before (though I don't have a list...). emacs can still be faster for several operations (like searching, for example) where in Xcode you have to have to raise your hand off the keyboard and use the mouse. But for building and debugging, Xcode is great.
So if someone could please list (as a comment to this post) what kind of information they would like to see in an Xcode Tutorial, I'll definitely do what I can to provide a clean, clear and crisp tutorial.
item.excerpt:encoded: People evidently want an Xcode Tutorial, but what do you want it to cover?

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
C -command line arguments in C, how to use 'em, why xCode doesn't respect its build directory when specifying a file on a command line -how to use targets to make different apps from shared source
Java -how to tell xCode *NOT* to use JAR files, but use the class files it can create -how to use the Java debugger
Perhaps the basics of using the debugger, configuring a "project" from scratch, how to incorporate Makefiles if that functionality exists...

Oh.. your words are very tempting. cant wait for your tutorial. I opened Xcode & started typing out Hello world & am trying to compile it now. have no idea how to do it. I created the program by clicking on "new empty file". do I have to start by creating a project?
even before your full fledged tutorial.. can you tell me real quick how to type - compile - run & debug in just short words?? that would be immensely helpful.
Appreciate it.
I did finish this tutorial - it can be found at Xcode Tutorial ( http://www.skipandmadge.com/archives/000039.html )

item.title: Fast User Switching and Sharing - a followup
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
So I've spent a considerable amount of time looking into sharing an iPhoto library between multiple users and I've run into some challenges. I'd discuss the challenges and some potential solutions, but I've run into these two potential solutions: iPhoto Library Manager
Doug's AppleScripts for iTunes
The iPhoto Library Manager claims to work with iPhoto 4 while the Applescripts do not (yet). Perhaps my efforts are better spent elsewhere. I'll test these out and let you know.

item.title: Are your parents home?
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Madge and I purchased our home (well, started paying back the bank for paying our home for us...) one month before we were married, exactly. During the first two weeks of our posession I spent most of my time in the empty, stinky-like-the-previous-owners house studying my brains out for my end of term exams. During this time I had my first experience with what has now become quite a regular occurrance. 10:30 one morning the doorbell rang. I was busy studying and was surprised at the sound. I couldn't believe that someone was at my door, perhaps it was one of my sisters. Nope. It was two gentlemen selling vacuums. I was concerned at the position I was in, as I, like most people, don't particularly enjoy dealing with door-to-door salesmen. Luckily I had an out. The first gentleman introduced himself and asked the unforgettable question, "Are your parents home?" Shocked and rather stunned at his question, I couldn't bring myself to embarrass him by saying, "I'm not sure, would you like me to call and find out?" Instead I took the easy way out by playing along with his mis-judgement of my age and merely responded, much as a teenager would, "No." It was easy and quite amusing. And for 22, I did look quite young. Evidently I still do.

Act young, Feel young, Pretend young
Five years later I still answer the door and hear the now quite hilarious words, "Are your parents home?" Just last week was my last experience, and Madge broke into laughter as I closed the door. I hadn't shaved for probably three days and had visible whiskers (no magnifying glass needed). ...So much for thinking that I do look older than 16 or 19. And I've yet to correct, and embarrass, anyone soliciting at my door. Even the one time I answered the door while holding my then one year-old daughter in my arms I held a straight face and merely answered, "No." Well, we're expecting a second child in the middle of May, and I've been quite quiet about the whole situation. Perhaps I don't feel comfortable "announcing" it in conversations, or I'm shy and just want to keep it part of my private life. But I don't think those are the big reasons why I haven't told more than about five people (outside of family). I think it comes down to my "baby-face" situations at the door of my own home. Having grown accustomed to the ackward situation of being considered 16 or 19 years old when I'm really 26 and rapidly approaching 30, I think I shy away from the potential scrutiny, and judgement, by my peers who, not knowing my age, would give me a hard time about having a child (or second child) when I'm "so young." I'm incredibly happy and excited about having another baby. I'm confident that we have made the right decision in creating a sibling for Lauryn and I know that we'll be a happy family. Madge is a wonderful mother and I love being a daddy. I even have to avoid holding little babies, as I wouldn't want to let it go. But I don't want to actually go through the process of embarrassing someone who thinks that I'm "only nineteen," or "only twenty-one," and have made a rash decision (or mistake) in having a baby. I'm not interested in being placed in a position where I feel I need to defend myself. This is the right thing for us to do and I don't want to deal with other peoples' mis-interpretation of the situation. And maybe one day I'll break down and start telling people who ring my doorbell, "No, I don't think they're home. This is my house, but I could call and find out if they're home if you think its important."

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
"I'm sorry but my parents aren't home" has become part of my regular defense against door nazis. I had always struggled with how I could avoid the snares of the door-to-door sales person until one day, like skip, one of them asked "are your parents home". Since that day the simple phrase "my parents aren't home" has repelled even most savvy of door knockers.
I should mention that I am thirty years old and that line of defense still works with my 7 month old daughter in my arms.

item.title: Vocal Crossfading
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
As a child I learned a song about springtime. It went like this:
I looked out the window and what did I see? Popcorn popping on the apricot tree. Spring has brought me such a nice surprise, Blossoms popping right before my eyes...
Shortly after meeting Madge she alerted me to a rather strange talent I seem to have developed - the ability to crossfade between songs while singing them. Or, in more clear terms, I could sing the first few lines of one song and, without noticing, finish the verse by singing lyrics from a completely different song. The most memorable example was the mixing of "Popcorn Popping" and "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot," using the lyrics below and to the tune of "Swing Low."
I looked out the window and what did I see? Comin' for to carry me home. Popcorn popping on the apricot tree, Comin' for to carry me home..
Excited because its Christmas Eve
Its been fun to accidentally discover songs whose tunes easily blend and are swappable, but today my daughter Lauryn showed that she has inherited my talent.
Lauryn's Song
(To the tune of Row Row Row Your Boat)
Feb. 9, 2004

Row row row your boat
Gently down the stream.
Mary Mary quite contrary
How your garden grow?
item.excerpt:encoded: Lauryn mixes songs

item.title: Cold in Korea
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Nighttime Seoul from the 27th Floor of the Grand Intercontinental


Standard Grand Intercontinental Room


Korean War Memorial

It has been more than a month since I arrived back from Korea and its time that I put some of my pictures up. Last night I stitched my "panorama" pictures together and so here they are. They popup to be large images if you want a closer look. And yes, you can see the seams between the pictures. The first shot is of my first hotel room (I had a second that was slightly larger - it had a couch). The second shot is a composite of 12 pictures that I took out of my hotel window showing my night-time view. And the last shot is of Ian, Jared and Owen in front of the Korean War Memorial.

item.title: Warm Chinook from the West
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
Our friends Matt and Tamara recently acquired a new iBook. I'd link directly to Matt's post "Introducing Chinook," but his permanent links aren't working. Anyway, Matt had some questions/points/observations about OS X that I've been meaning to address.

Emacs

Its actually not necessary to use Apple's X11, or Fink, to run Emacs. Andrew Choi has been the OSX/Carbon Emacs maintainer, but has recently resigned. His site includes instructions if you wish to build it yourself. Binaries for Panther and Jaguar can be found at mindlube.com, however. This way you can stick Emacs in the dock as its a fully native version. Andrew's Carbon changes have been included in the latest Emacs source tree as well, so future versions should continue to be native (if built with the proper options).

MPI

I'm unable to go the the MPI link that Matt provides. I used the MPICH implementation found at hpc.sourceforge.net. (LAM MPI is now available as well, as is XMPI.) HPC is a great resource for binaries and source specific to Panther and Jaguar for High Performance Computing tools including, but not limited to, Fortran, MPI, OpenMP, Octave, Cactus, and Globus.

Bookmark Syncing

Honestly one of the most compelling features of Apple's .Mac service is Safari Bookmark and Address Book syncing (not synching - pronounced "cinching"). On any machine in the world, I can have access to and modify all my bookmarks and contacts. On OS X machines that I have an account on, the process is seamless. On a Windows or Linux box all I have to do is open "http://bookmarks.mac.com" and voila! However, if your not interested in subscribing to this service (at least try it for free for 60 days...), you could roll your own system, as Matt proposes to do, using WebDAV. MacOSXHints has all kinds of webDAV hints, but here's directions on setting in up on OS X. The same process my work on other platforms. The challenge to rolling your own system is building the app/script to place/pull the latest bookmarks file(s) on/off the server AND making a web-viewable/editable representation of the bookmarks (if that's a feature you're interested in). Could be a fun project though.

CUPS - common UNIX printing system

I'm not sure why this isn't documented (or maybe it is) but if you hold down Option while selecting Printer > Add Printer... you have access to a fairly large set of printer connection options. Matt could probably keep his current CUPS configuration and add the same printer again using the GUI (and the handy Option key) and see if he can arrange a better configuration in this manner. Oh, and while searching MacOSXHints for 'default' and 'browser' I discovered this Print to a remote CUPS server hint that might help Matt out. (As might this one.)

Safari as Default Browser

As evidenced by my main page Firefox web badge, I support Firefox, though I only use it on my Windows machine at work. I personally would prefer if they branded Firefox as 1.0 instead of 0.8, but really the version number is irrelevant. People who don't build software themselves always seem wary of sub-1.0 software, but anyway... I agree with Matt that the place for selecting a default browser in OS X is stupidly located in Safari's preferences. However, I think I have a reasonable idea of why this is so. With the conversion of iTools to .Mac, some of the free iTools services preferences, formerly located in the System Preferences > Internet were migrated to System Preferences > .Mac. However, this left the Default Browser preference all alone. It didn't belong in the .Mac or Network Panes, and didn't really deserve its own pane. The only place left, I suppose, is in Safari's preferences. Unfortunately, this isn't completely sound reasoning. Mail, OS X's default email client, also has the "Default Email Reader" preference within its own preferences, just like Safari. This is a rather Microsoft-like tactic it seems. Perhaps a third party should write an Internet Preferences Pane that gives a proper location for selecting the default browser and email client. Unfortunately, if you're the type of person who would enjoy this pane, you'd have to install it yourself and would probably know where to change the settings anyway. BAH, it would only be useful if Apple included it themselves...

item.title: Hidden Power
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: After reading this Learning Unix for Mac OS X Panther book review on slashdot.org this afternoon, I noticed some links in the reader comments that addressed at least one of the ideas/concerns I brought up in my earlier MOSXS - Apache webserving on OS X post. This book, from the sound of the review, would be a fantastic resource for a few of my friends. For myself, I'm not certain. To learn the inner workings of Linux, I was under the tutelage of Matt, Laurie and Ryan and consider myself rather above the level of this book. If I didn't have such geeky friends, however, it would probably satiate my curiosity about the command line manipulation of Mac OS X. In my earlier MOSXS post I quested for Mac OS X Terminal Tutorial. This site seems adequate: Using the Mac OS X Terminal (HTML) or Using the Mac OS X Terminal (PDF) . Books are great but free online resources are even better - as long as you remember where it was and under what title you bookmarked it. Hopefully this post will allow me to remember where to point my other non-Linux friends when they need to start using the terminal. Certainly the Learning Unix book above would be a better resource, but its not free. There was also a link to GeekTool - a Sourceforge project that allow a system log, unix commands, and images to be displayed on the desktop. You can graph network traffic, keep track of uptime and cpu usage, and pretty much anything else that you commonly "look up" in a terminal. I haven't used it much, but it looks pretty spiffy and if I have the time to configure it I'm sure I'll dig it. And as for the power of the terminal, well Wicked Cool Shell Scripts is reputed to have a collection of useful or just plane wacky shell scripts (text-based HangMan anyone?) that will run on Mac OS X (or Unix or Linux). I still have to fully check it out before I can apply my SkipsStampOfApproval™ and fully recommend it. And for a non-terminal hint, hold down Command (Cmd, the Apple key) and then click on the titlebar of a non-focus window (a window that isn't the foremost) and drag it around, still leaving it in its non-focus state. (Is there an equivalent capability in Windows or Linux?) And for one more, hold down Option and click on a non-focus window. The application that was in focus is hidden and the application of the clicked window becomes the active application. Oh, and if you hold Cmd+Option and click on a non-focus window, all the other applications are hidden and only the selected one remains. Nifty? It can be quite a timesaver if you remember the combinations and they become habit.

item.title: For every day, there is not time
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I've had lots to say lately, but haven't had time to write it. Ecto, the software that I use instead a web interface to post to this weblog, has come along to the point where I purchased a license today. The feature that moved me from demo user to registered was ecto's integration with iPhoto, making it relatively seamless to post pictures.

Lilo at Uncle Rick's Wedding
I hope that the developer adds the ability to modify the templates, and I'm also anxious to try out a version for Windows. They say they're working on it, but I'm sure it will take time. I also ran into this posting at MacOSXHints.com about syncing Safari (and other browser) bookmarks with a provided PERL script. This seems to be just the feature that Matt was interested in, but I don't know if it is designed to sync bookmarks for browsers on remote machines or only on the local machine. And the biggest occupier of brain power recently, as been the contemplation of following my employer's offer to move and work in San Diego for a year. The troublesome part is that we're going to be having a new baby in the middle of May, and my employer wants me to be working in San Diego full time in the middle of May. An exciting offer but there's lots of details to work out. You may also notice that I recently added some code to the main page template to include the 20-minute delayed stock prices of the two Nasdaq stocks I'm most interested in. The code to retrieve the appropriate stock graph image from yahoo is nothing more than
<img border="0" src="http://ichart.yahoo.com/t?s=nvtl"><br />
<img border="0" src="http://ichart.yahoo.com/t?s=aapl">
But in the process of trying to find a graph this size that also showed the volume throughout the day, I discovered some other graphs but never was I able to find a complete listing off all the graphs and all the options for each type of graph. But I did learn that
http://ichart.yahoo.com/t?s=nvtl
gives the the nice small graph where s=[the stock symbol of interest; nvtl, aapl]
http://ichart.yahoo.com/b?s=nvtl
daily large
http://ichart.yahoo.com/h?s=nvtl
teeny tiny
http://ichart.yahoo.com/w?s=nvtl
shows the last five days in a large format
http://ichart.yahoo.com/v?s=nvtl
shows the last five days in a small format
http://ichart.yahoo.com/z?s=nvtl
give a larger graph and allows for options like
&t=[length of time; 1d, 5d, 1m, 1y, 5y]
&q=[bar, line, or cdl graph; l, b, ???]
&l=[logarithmic graph; on, off]
&z=[size; s, m, l]
&c=[compare with other symbol; aapl, nvtl]
&a=[volume;v]
Some of these options are available to some of the other graphs as well but I haven't figured out which options apply to which graphs. For example:
http://ichart.yahoo.com/z?s=AAPL&t=5d&l=on&z=m&q=l&c=nvtl

item.title: Picking Baby Names
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Somewhere around May 20, 2004, Madge and I will be having a new baby. We don't know if it will be a boy or a girl and I certainly hope its not more than 5 days early since I arrive home from San Diego May 13, 2004. Tonight we had a few minutes where we could actually sit down and think about baby names. We pulled out our file from last time, and started looking over the list of names that we didn't use. NO I'm NOT going to tell you what we've picked (as I can't because we haven't – and I wouldn't anyway). However I did find a mighty fine list of "10 Baby Naming Hints." And here they are:

10 Baby Naming Hints

  1. The name must be comfortable right away for you. Will you sound funny yelling it across the playground? Eg."Dionysius!!"
  2. The number of syllables in the first name should be different from the number of syllables in the last name. The combination of names shouldn't say anything. Eg. Scott Land
  3. The first and last or all three names' initials shouldn't spell anything bad. Eg. Harold Oliver Goldman = HOG
  4. If the spelling or pronunciation is too unusual, the child will have to continually correct it.
  5. Use a name from a family member, famous person, and/or combination of family or ethnic names.
  6. Combine names to create a new baby name.
  7. Be conscious of nicknames and variations.
  8. Practice the baby's name to see how it feels. You'll use it a lot.
  9. Use the middle name to honour a family member, give two middle names or leave it blank for the child to choose when they're 18.
  10. Avoid first and last names with the same letter. First name should not end with a letter or syllable that the last name begins with.
I don't really think we'll leave our child's middle name blank expressly so that he/she can change it to "Gromit" when s/he's 18, but other than that, the list seems reasonable. Here's another interesting statement about how to "Avoid giving your baby girl a trendy name."
item.excerpt:encoded: picking baby names

item.title: Block Referrer Spam in OS X
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
I've been using googlog to provide a sidebar listing of the last 10 recent searches that have lead people to my site. It has worked quite well until I started getting a lot of referrer spam. As googlog only keeps a local listing of the last 50 referrers, the spammers quite quickly overrun the legit searches and googlog is useless. But here's how to fight back (well, defend yourself). I can click on the link to the local listing of referrers and see the listing of the last 50 referrers.
