Following these Blocking Referrer Spam directions, I learned that you can simply place a the following code inside a .htaccess file inside the main directory from where my pages are served.
SetEnvIfNoCase Referer ".*(casino|gambling|poker|porn|sex).*" BadReferrer
order deny,allow
deny from env=BadReferrer
Unfortunately I had two problems as I tried to do this. First, I had to tell Apache to look for and use the .htaccess file. MacDevCenter to the rescue! I needed to change the AllowOverride line that started as:
# This controls which options the .htaccess files # in directories can override. Can also be "All", # or any combination of "Options", "FileInfo", # "AuthConfig", and "Limit". AllowOverride None
to be
AllowOverride All
Next I needed to restart Apache using sudo apachectl graceful restart. The second problem I had was that I placed a new line character (carriage return) between SetEnvIfNoCase Referer and ".*(casino|gambling|poker|porn|sex).*" BadReferrer This made my .htaccess file invalid and caused Apache to only show my error page. If I find I'm still getting referrer spam, then all I need to do is add the names of the spamming sites to the listing of (casino|gambling|newspammerdomain|newwordinthespamdomains).
item.excerpt:encoded: Blocking Referrer Spam in OS X

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It's lucky for me I found this! The referred spam has been driving Tamara and I nuts!

item.title: Backup and Restore MovableType MySql Databases on Mac OS X
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
All Home-pages Should be Weblogs

This site, as noted in the main page's sidebar, is powered by MovableType. MovableType (not MoveableType) is basically a piece of software that runs on the web server that stores page content in a database and generates static html pages from that content. This means that I don't have to write any of my pages in HTML by hand. I don't have to worry about broken links and keeping the main (index) page updated with only the most recent posts. MovableType does all the work. In fact, I can modify the templates for the site (the templates govern the basic layout of each of the pages) and regenerate every page with the click of a button. It also allows me to upload files (usually pictures) to my website and makes it easy for me to include them in any posts I may make. MoveableType's main interface is also nothing more than a web page. This means that I can log into my web server, via a web page, from any computer in the world, and post and make changes to my site. I firmly believe that people only do that which is easy/fun or absolutely necessary. If it takes too much effort, chances are you'll get tired of it and never do it again. I believe that this is what happens to most people's web pages. They think its cool to have a website, they make an initial web page or two by hand (and spend hours and hours doing it) and then never add another page because it simply isn't easy enough. We have other important things to do in our lives, and if it takes a couple of hours every time you want to write about or show something on a website, the initial discovery-fun of HTML gets old and you just won't go through the hassle anymore. ISPs (Internet Service Providers) should STOP merely giving 5 MB of web space for every connection and should ALL include server-side web-log software (like MovableType) so that anyone can easily post to their own web-space without having to learn HTML. This would also make it more challenging for people to write web pages that aren't valid HTML. [Aside: The fact that most web pages are not actually compliant to the HTML specifications makes the job of writing web browsers (like Safari, FireFox, Netscape, and Internet Explorer) incredibly challenging, not to mention the impossible task of trying to write a web page that IS compliant, that looks the same in every major browser. Browser developers spend most of their time trying to make invalid code look correctly and then don't have the time to implement new segments of the HTML/CSS (and other) standards.] Unfortunately, I can't influence ISPs and I can't teach everyone how to write valid HTML, but I can share helpful information with those of people who are trying to do this on their own. Today I decided that it would be worthwhile to learn how to backup and restore the database that contains all my posts. If this database were to disappear, I would lose this entire site (except for the static pages that you're reading right now). I have chosen to store my content in a MySql database. MovableType will work with a flat-file BerkelyDB and PostgreSql databases (and maybe others), but I wanted to learn more about MySql and now I'm committed. If the MySql database that I was using to store the content for this website was called movabletype_database, and the MySql "user" that accessed the database was mysql_user, then the command to save the movabletype_database database to the file movabletype_database_backup_todays_date.sql (using the a command-line terminal) would be:
mysqldump -u mysql_user -p --opt movabletype_database > movabletype_database_backup_todays_date.sql
I would then be prompted to enter the password for mysql_user and that's it. If I then want to restore this backup, the command that I need to enter is:
mysql -u msql_user -p movabletype_database < movabletype_database_backup_todays_date.sql
Now I should be able to script the daily backup of the database so I could never lose more than perhaps one day's posts. (Oh, and half of the reason why I wrote these instructions down is so that I can remember how to do it the next time I need to do a backup. This blog may simply become a context sensitive bookmark mechanism one day.)
item.excerpt:encoded: What is a weblog and why should I care (and how do I back it up)?

item.title: Streetlights Make You Blind
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: I've spent the last 7 days here in San Diego, California, and apart from the rather constant pleasant weather there's one thing that I quite like about this place. No Streetlights "What?!?" you may say, "Doesn't that make it less safe?" or, "Doesn't that make it hard to see at night?" To the contrary. Let me explain. I grew up in a small town in the middle of the flat prairie. To the West were the mountains. To the East was the flat horizon. No one looked East, as anything of importance always came from the West. The wind prevailed from the West, and with it came the clouds and the weather. No native trees exist on the prairie, neither do hills, so it was always possible to look West and accurately forecast the weather. At night the stars would shimmer and beckon like a sea of pearls floating on deep waters. The impact of the few town streetlights was negligible on the night sky's visibility. It was easy to practice astronomy as the sky's jewelry was always on display. My favorites were the Perseids in August and Orion, Taurus, and the Pleiades. And then I moved to the city. The glow of Calgary can been seen in the night sky from more than 150 km away (when there's cirrus cloud cover). Within the city there's so much light pollution that usually the Moon alone is visible. For the first year or so I was too occupied with my new life of the city to notice how much I longed to simply see the stars. Over time I missed their brilliance more and more. Even climbing to the top of Nose Hill Park did not sufficiently shield me from the blinding, omnipresent glow. And then I arrived in the bustling, sprawling city of San Diego. And even in what are busy parts of town (non-downtown I'll admit), after the sun sets the stars unveil themselves. It is fantastic. Driving around the city at night, it is impossible to guess how densely populated the area is, because of the curious lack of illumination. You'd never accurately guess the number of houses/condos/roads exist, because they simply aren't visible. Only intersections seem to have streetlights, and the difference (in having so few) is amazing. Driving through residential areas of town at night is like driving through the countryside. And the stars are everywhere! Its certainly better on the beach, but deep in the city the recent conjunction of the Moon and Venus stood out in the night time sky. (Well, it wasn't a true conjunction and Venus is the brightest "star" in the night sky, but you get my point). And what of safety? Well, Northern San Diego feels pretty safe. Its very quiet and the weather is too pleasant for people to have a reason to cause trouble (I sound pretty naive, right?). However, when its dark and you're walking down the street and no streetlights exist overhead, your eyes adjust and its possible to actually see quite far. With streetlights, the direct area is lit, but the shadows are dark and very concealing. And then there's the environment. Think of all the energy wasted into the night sky. For what purpose? In winter, its too cold and unpleasant for people to be out after dark. And how much do streetlights help motorists? Cars have headlights. In fact, I'm quite bothered each time I drive out of South Airdrie onto the #2 highway (if you know the area) because the transition from many street lights to none occurs as you get onto the on ramp. Thus as you try to merge with the busy highway traffic, your eyes have not adjusted to the light disparity and I always feel quite blind and in a hazardous position. More streetlights would improve that situation, but so would fewer streetlights earlier on. I suppose that the raised reflectors in California, that help drivers see the lanes and edges of the road, wouldn't survive one swipe of the winter snowplows and would never be visible from under the snow. But, perhaps your headlights would actually help you see better if there were no other major sources of light. It would be like driving down a country road at night instead of this perpetual street-level twilight. Aah, but its nice to see the stars. And its nice to not waste energy needlessly and send it into the sky for other worlds to see. If you happen to have a good view of the stars, these sky maps (star charts) have become quite handy and fun while I've been down here. So has this interactive star chart (map) from mystarslive.com
item.excerpt:encoded: Get rid of streetlights and you'll generally see better

item.title: You have been "Selected"
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Beware of SSSS

I very recently returned from a trip to San Diego, California. Instead of returning directly to Calgary (via Denver) I needed to spend a day working in Pleasanton, California before returning home. I had about 3 hours notice before I was to leave and was lucky to have the assistance of a good travel agent at Vision 2000 who quickly modified my itinerary and had me booked to fly out that evening to Oakland. However, I have a feeling that last minute flight bookings immediately put you on some sort of "Security Hit-list," as for both my flight to Oakland, and the flight the next evening to Seattle & Calgary, an interesting "SSSS" was printed on the bottom edge of both halves of my boarding pass. For both flights, as soon as the Security agent saw my boarding pass (and its SSSSs), the agent looked up and say, "Can you follow me please?" I would be escorted to the front of the security gate line where I would have to do the regular empty-the-pockets, pull-out-the-laptop, and walk through the gate routine. Afterward I would have to go back to a special area and take a seat. An agent would go through my bags, shoes and pocket contents, while another would have me lift my feet (while seated) and "swipe" them with a metal detector. A more thorough swipe and pat-down would then occur while I stood on a mat with brown foot outlines. The second time this occurred, I think I surprised the agent by raising my foot and arms before being asked. He asked if I had done this before and I told him that I'd had the same experience yesterday. Luckily, for both flights, I arrived sufficiently early and hence wasn't stressed by the security delay. At least this set of flights didn't involve passing through a security checkpoint overcome with the smell of stinky feet.
item.excerpt:encoded: Airport Security doesn't like me

item.title: Short Police Officer
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I love short cops.
To a trim uniform, a determined face, and proper training, size is of no comparison.
But I still think its funny when classmates can't stay in sequence when they march!
item.excerpt:encoded: A Short Cop Graduates

item.title: Power in Gas and Gas in Power
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
The plan was simple. One year in San Diego would require only a small number of housewares and one 5'x8' Uhaul trailer would fit everything. Our "Grey Grandma" car is sufficently "grandma" to tow a trailer and the drive from Calgary, Alberta, Canada to San Diego, California, USA would only take two or three days. The economical savings would be substantial and a road trip with my brother Isopraxis would be fun. He's done most of the trip many a time and knows a lot of the back roads that would keep us away from the congestion of I-15.
So we head off South and arrive at the Coutts/Sweetgrass border crossing. Madge had done a lot of legwork to ensure that I would have no trouble importing our car into the States. As I have American citizenship, I have no problem traveling across the border, but my US manufactured Canadian car is a different story. The car has a VIN that begins with the number "1". This means that it was manufactured in the United States but is marked and sold as a Canadian car.
I've thought of several titles for this entry revolving around the troubles we had at the border, but the significance of "Power in Gas and Gas in Power" will be explained near the end of the post.
We were planning on importing the car as a Non-Resident for the period of one year. This situation would mean that we wouldn't need to have the normally-required letter from the manufacturer stating that the car complies to DOT safety standards. Well, regardless of where I plan on living for the rest of my life and where I own a house, because I'm an American citizen, there is no compulsion for me to leave and take my car back to Canada. So despite the assurance that Brenda had received earlier that this was a proper method for me, as an American, to temporarily import a vehicle, the customs, oops, I mean "homeland security" officers would not, despite talking to two supervisors and multiple collect calls to Madge, let me continue the trip with my potentially non-compliant car. The second supervisor quite brusquely shot down any argument that I made and ended our conversation by saying that, "We treat everyone this way. That's just the way it is."
It personally sounds like power-hungry incompetents flexing their intimidation muscles as much as possible. We had the verbal assurance from one of the heads of the homeland security and customs office (in DC) that what we were trying to do was completely legitimate and that if the officers at the borders had any problems or questions they could call him directly. Hence one of the potential titles was, "Don't Cross the Border on Friday at 4:30 PM," or something to that effect. Despite showing the officer the name and phone number of the official who was to assist me, he, "Didn't have any idea who this person is and why what he would have to say would be any different from his supervisor." And no one would even try to call the official because it was Friday afternoon and no one in DC would be in the office at 6:30.
Much to my chagrin, and to my luck, I was able to finally legitimately import the car at 8:30 that same night. The first time I talked to one of the officers, I was given the name and phone number of someone who I am familiar with from my hometown, Raymond. Madge attempted to contact him and was given his cell phone number and the positive news that he wasn't in Raymond, but there in Coutts where our road trip was halted. Despite having his voice cut out throughout our conversation, I was able to catch him on his cell and learned that he was busy on the Sweetgrass side of the border but that he was willing to post bond on my car (bond that the car was compliant) so I could import it.
And we waited.
And waited more.
After an hour of waiting, I called him again and we managed to meet. He took down the info he needed, took some pictures of the car, its airbags, speedometer, and stickers, and told me to again cross the border and go to a brokerage office and await a fax from him.
We were waived through the border, as everyone in the office had seen me come in and plead my case two times and luckily the female officer at the window came across rather sympathetic. She actually offered to tell me how to get to the office I needed to find! The others I had dealt with earlier even neglected to even tell me that in the lobby of the office was a pay-phone that I could have made all my calls from, and hence would have avoided two trips BACK to Canada.
Finally feeling like we'd caught a break and that we'd actually be able to continue our journey before Monday. (We were bearing the additional pressure that Isopraxis has a non-refundable plane ticket for Monday morning from San Diego to Calgary.) But despite our hopes to get moving before sunset, we waited.
And waited.
About an hour of waiting in the brokerage office for nothing more than two faxed pieces of paper, and feeling like exhausted zombies, we heard the pleasant hum of the fax machine and walked into customs two minutes later. Luckily I'd already filled out all other forms necessary so in another five minutes we were walking to the car with yet another customs officer who just wanted to check the VIN (and who pointed out that the car was manufactured in America). We were on the road, having only wasted five hours of our precious driving time. Ugh.
I had last filled the car with gas in Nanton, Alberta and thought it would be reasonable to stop in Shelby Montana to top up the tank. Having just gotten on the road, and still having 1/2 a tank, according to the gauge, I recalculated that we'd have enough gas to get to Great Falls. And so we rolled along.
Just as I drove past Choteau (I believe), I noticed that the needle was dropping faster than I expected, and that we only had about 1/4 of a tank left and about 25 or 30 miles to go. I almost decided to turn around, but again figured that we'd arrive without running dry.
But the level indicator seemed to change position as I watched. Soon it was dipping dangerously close to the empty line. And we still had 20 miles to go. The map, a 10+ year old road atlas, showed a town, Power, up ahead. Our only hope was that an a late-night gas station would be open. Otherwise we'd be stranded yet again. It was now just before 11:00.
I took the exit to Power and hoped that I'd be able to drive the one mile into town without sputtering to a stop. I missed the turn on Central Avenue and was suddenly out of town and looking for an approach to turn the car and trailer around. Maneuvering back into town we found two bars, across the street from each other, that were doing a decent Friday night business, with 5 to 7 pickups in front of each. If I couldn't find a gas station, I would be obligated to try and hit-up someone in one of the bars to let me siphon some gas or get a get a jerry can full from back at the home place.
I took the next right and miraculously saw two gas pumps, illuminated by overhead lights, down the hill and across the tracks by the grain elevator. We had a chance! As I drove closer, separated by the tracks, it was apparent that there was no attendant on duty, and so I was resigned to go find someone to give us assistance.
As I pulled back up to the bars, two lean and lanky ranchers were walking from one establishment to the other. I rolled down the window and called out to them, asking if they knew of someplace that I could get some gas. One, asking how much I needed, said that he had a credit card that would work with pumps just down the hill and would get me as much gas as I had cash.
Seven dollars isn't enough cash to travel with in the dreary wastes of Northern Montana. Thus a second potential title, dealing with my lack of travel wisdom. (Yet somehow as I type this, as Isopraxis is driving through Northern Nevada, I'm carrying only a blend of American and Canadian change. But my brother has pulled a few bucks out and is doing a good job looking over me as my elder brother. :) I'm glad he rode along.)
The cash I had would be sufficient to get to Great Falls, so the local boys were going to tell their pals that they were going to give us a hand and would meet us at the pump. I drove down and noticed that they weren't special key-lock pumps (though they could dispense dyed agricultural gas) but that any major credit card would be accepted. So for my second lucky break of the day we were going to get sufficient quantities of fuel without getting stranded and having to walk for miles. Well, second MAJOR lucky break - if I can even call it luck. Perhaps I should say "Despite my naivety and seeming impossibility." I'd like to think that tenacity is somewhat involved, but that would be giving me too much credit in the situation. Perhaps is just blind determination and high levels of stress and commitment.
Thus the title.
Our journey was halted in Coutts/Sweetgrass and the peril of being without fuel (literally powerless), 20 miles from the nearest bed, had been averted.
We rolled into Great Falls just after 11 o'clock and were both about ready to collapse of exhaustion. I'd been up since 5 AM and had driven the entire way (of my own choice). We found a place to eat and a cheap hotel (smoking room but it was the only one left and a double at that - yay!). Sleep soon found my tired eyes, and morning arrived far to soon - but not soon enough.
Our 6 AM wake up call never happened, and I didn't stir enough to check my watch until just before 8.
And there are many more miles to go.
item.excerpt:encoded: Day one of the trip to San Diego

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow that's some story skip hope the rest of the journey get's better.

item.title: My Private Eco-Challenge
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Things have been quite busy for me at work lately. As I'm living alone (for the moment), I don't mind staying late at work and trying to get ahead. Unfortunately, by the time I get home, all I have time to do is chat with Madge for a bit and then fall asleep. I have made no time for writing new entries, or completing old ones, though I have a lot to say. In moving to San Diego, and having a new baby in the next few weeks, I decided to find an apartment as close as possible to work. That way I could come home at lunch and give Madge a hand, and be home right after leaving work. I hate the idea of commuting, doubly so here in traffic-central, California. Luckily, I found a great place, just around the corner from work, and it wasn't nearly as expensive as everyone at work tried to tell me it would be. Unfortunately, we're changing offices. But not until October. This morning, after deciding I didn't need to waste a perfectly good Saturday at work, I decide to go for a ride to check out the new office. A few of us from work drove by it yesterday afternoon, and I figured it would be a relatively direct ride from the apartment. From the new office, I could see the "bottom" of a valley whose "top" I was quite sure was right next to the apartment. Some landmarks strongly suggested this, so I wanted to go for a ride to confirm my thesis. On a map it looked like quite a direct route, except for one problem. A six lane (each way) freeway right between the valley bottom and the office. "Freeway, schmeeway..." I think as I put my bike together and clip on my helmet. If I want to find a route, it will be found! When I had first come to look at this apartment, I arrived a bit early and decided to wander around the neighbourhood a bit. At the end of the parking area for this complex of apartments, I noticed a dirt trail leading down a valley. I'm a big fan of natural beauty, as opposed to the expanse of man's developments, so before checking out the apartment, I wandered down the valley a bit. I saw a few lizards and wondered where the trail lead. Well, my trusty old bike and I were determined to connect this valley to the new office of work. So I headed, quickly, down this sandy trail. It appears to have been established by the power company for planting power poles. Down down I go, occasionally hitting patches of soft, unstable sand. It wasn't too steep, but steep enough to make it a fun ride down. Going up will be no worse than going up one of the easier faces of Nose Hill in Calgary. Soon I was at the bottom and, hurray, I could see the building of the new office. I followed a paved road North and in not too long I was able to turn right, cross the railroad tracks and go under the freeway. One right turn and I was on the road running in front of the building I wanted to find. I poked around the building a bit, just checking it out, and decided to try and find a different route from the office back to the end of the dirt trail. I continued South until I had another chance to go under the freeway. I figured this route (South under the freeway instead of North), would be a bit shorter, but only if I could get back across the railroad tracks (and creek) to the trail up the valley. This is where the adventure began. I knew where I wanted to go, and tried over and over to get there. I found a bridge over the creek, but on the other side there was only a parking lot. Beside it were the train tracks, but no visible path over it or along it (on either side) that I could follow. I poked around some more, following the creek until it crossed under the tracks. I decided that this was my chance to cross the tracks. I did so, but still had the creek in my way. I'm rather fearful of trains, as they always arrive faster than you expect, so I didn't want to cross over the creek on the tracks. Unfortunately, the only thing keeping me from climbing back up the valley and home, was the creek. I didn't want to follow along it any farther, so I doubled back, and crossed over on the train bridge. Just after I crossed, I was dawdling a bit, looking at a prickly-pear cactus. Suddenly I heard a "TOOT" and knew it was meant for me. I rolled off the tracks and surprisingly found a path back through the brush toward the valley trail. An AMTRACK train cruised past as I disappeared into the brush. Soon, after pushing through some tall wild-mustard, I was heading up the valley. I'd had fun bushwhacking from the freeway to this point, so instead of rolling up the path I came down on, I decided to turn off and try another route. And what a route I found. First, I had to walk up one of the steepest dirt slopes that I wouldn't consider a cliff. A few sips of water and I was rolling along the plateau, approximately level with the apartment. But I was a long distance from home, yet. I could see some office buildings, each one at a point, surrounded by little valleys leading down into the the trail valley or back toward the freeway. I curiously checked almost every one out, looking for additional paths that could be used at a later date, or that could carry me home. One building, the IDE Center for Communication Research, had a surprising number of cameras around it, and a bare "path" outside its fenced area. It jutted out above the valleys and I hoped a path would lead down from it, back toward home. It didn't, and I spend 15 minutes slowly rolling all the way around the compound, coming out with a gentleman standing outside the building, probably wondering who kept appearing on all the cameras and what I was doing. No path could be found, and the native brush looked far to intimidating and steep to bike through. I checked out more offices, and could see the far end of the apartment complex, just across a little valley. An office building (and its fences and bushes) didn't allow me to cut across the top (and I didn't want to ride the boring roads), so I decided I'd have some "fun" and go around the building, through the brush on the side of the valley. The route home thus far had been OK. It wasn't the most efficient way to the office but it let me check out the area a bit. My private Eco-Challenge started the moment I decided to descend to a flat rim on the edge of the valley. I could see some dirt along this rim, and figured that, between the sage and other brush, I'd be able to ride through it once I got down. But going down was the easy part. The dry brush was sharp, rough and smelly and my shins stung as I tried to pedal and push my way through. Soon I was off my bike, then carrying it on my shoulder as the tall rough plants enveloped me. I imagined I could see a trail at times, yet it wasn't meant for man or bike. I hadn't the force to push the bike through ahead of me, nor the strength to pull it behind. If I carried it, I was caught at every move by some bramble or branch. My Eco-Challenge was through the native valley growth, and though I knew where I was and where I needed to go, I didn't know when I'd make it. I was well equipped with water, but I feared finding a snake den or other creature. My bike was holding me back, but I couldn't leave it behind. Finally, I hefted it above my head, out of the reach of Mother Nature, and pushed my burning shins through the curtain of scabrous bushes. I don't know how far I walked like this. The distance, from above, may have been short, but each agonizing step was a feat in itself. The land did not want me to cross. But I got myself into this, and the only way out was the one that I must make. Showing only a little blood, but lots of dirt, pollen, and dust on my legs and arms, I emerged onto land that I envisioned riding across. Enough bare patches existed that I could ride (or coast) along, but still each spot of scrub would lash out and strike my tender legs. A digital camera would have nicely captured some great images as I discovered a cactus growing on the edge of a rocky outcropping overlooking the valley. Glad I was that I hadn't found one with my front tire. Two golf balls I also found - sun-bleached to the point that the outer surface rubbed away with each touch. Soon I was on yet another island, surrounded by valley walls and thick brush I did not want to cross. Apartments were just on the other side of a very small valley - but how to get there? I spied a large cactus and a bare patch of ground, running down the hillside, beside it. Hopefully it would lead me to the clear base of the valley (which was obviously the haven of the local kids - the perfect place for a fort and well trampled). It did, and I'm glad. I'd had all the fun I needed by this point. And all I wanted was some shade and a shower. But you may say, if this was an self-inflicted Eco-Challenge, where were the bugs and other nasties? Well, I found no leeches, or killer-bees, and only empty snail shells, but as I rolled up the street to my home, I spied a critter, that I truly fear, crawling on my leg. A tick. I hate ticks (Ixodidae). I'm afraid of them and luckily have never had one burrow into my skin and grow. I never want to have that happen. I flicked it off and found another on the other leg. I hadn't had my head in the brush that much, so I hoped I didn't have any in my thick locks of hair. When I got home, I found two more on my legs, both looking for a nice warm place to burrow. Quickly I pulled off my clothes and checked for more, but that was all. I'm quite certain that the ticks that found me while I pushed through the brush were Dermacentor Occidentalis (Pacific Coast Ticks) and not the more dangerous Dermacentor Andersoni (Rocky Mountain Wood Tick). Sunburned, sweaty, tired and scraped, I'd survived. But I promise you that I'll never try and ride that route to the new office.
item.excerpt:encoded: Bushwhacking back from the office

item.title: Xcode Tutorial - Introduction to Xcode
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I presume, based on the lack of feedback I've received, that the people looking for an Xcode Tutorial are people relatively new to the world of computer programming. You've probably dabbled a bit, but you're not ready to get down and dirty and experimentally learn how the tool works. You want a leg up on the learning curve. Hopefully this tutorial can give you that start.

What is Xcode

Essentially Xcode is a tool that acts as a project organizer, text editor, compiler, debugger and documentation viewer. Comparable Windows software would be Microsoft Visual Studio. Xcode (formerly known as Project Builder) allows most development to be completed within a single window, putting important tools a single click away. It is built upon "open source" tools such as gcc (for compilation) and gdb (for debugging). The Xcode suite also includes other applications including Interface Builder that support Cocoa (Objective-C/Java), Carbon (Procedural C), and Applescript Studio (Applescript) projects. Apple's Xcode suite page can be found here. People interested in an Xcode Tutorial most likely aren't looking for information on how to use these extra tools and languages, so I'm not going to talk about them. Plus, many other tutorials exist both at Apple and MacDevCenter (check the sidebar for topics).

Xcode Project Types

Every project begins at the New Project Assistant (File, New...). As of Xcode 1.1 the list of available projects is:

New Project Assistant
Many other project types are selectable under the bold groups but will not be covered. A text window under the list of selectable project types give a brief definition of the currently highlighted project type. As can be seen at the right, I have selected a "Standard Tool" project that "... builds a command-line tool written in C." Other options that may be of interest include the "C++ Tool" (command-line tool that links against the stdc++ library) and the various Java Applet, Application, and Tool types. The CoreFoundation, CoreServices and Foundation Tools also build command-line tools but these link against the Cocoa libraries and are written in Objective-C.

New Standard Tool
Picking the "Standard Tool" option and clicking "Next" brings us to a pane where we can give our project a name and pick where we want to save the project. The default save location is "~/" (the base of your home folder). This is where your "Documents," "Music," and "Movies" folders reside. I usually save my projects in "~/Documents/Dev/". Give the project the name, "BasicTool," save it in your preferred location, and click "Finish." (Allow Xcode to create any directories as needed.) You are now presented with the main Xcode development window. The right pane shows the uncompiled Build Target BasicTool (the program you are going to build and compile) in red, a file used for documenting the Target BasicTool.1, and the source code file main.c. The left pane is organized to rapidly present all potentially relevant information about the project. The "folders" of information are merely logical groupings of files.

New Project Window
For example, under the BasicTool project "folder" (the topmost group), once you click the disclosure triangle to its left, you see three folders. These folders, Source, Documentation, and Products, "contain" the same three files as in the left plane, but the file's presence in a specific "folder" is only for presentation. Moving the files in these folders does not change their location on the filesystem. You can make high-level changes to these items, however. For example, by control-clicking main.c (in either pane), you are presented with a number of options, including Reveal in Finder, Get Info, and Rename. You may notice that the files shown in the right pane are the same files contained within the selected grouping (folder) in the left pane. That is, if you select Implementation Files, the only file shown in the right pane will be main.c as it is our only source file. For the moment, we will simply leave these folders as they were originally as we won't be using them just yet.

Source Code Editor

One of the main uses of Xcode is as a source code editor. Any basic text-editing application (not Word Processor) will give you the same basic capabilities. Xcode has some features that make it nicer to use than many editors, however. There are several ways to call up an editing window in Xcode. At this point we will only look at two ways. The first is by double clicking main.c in the right (or left) pane of the window. This action causes a new editor window to popup.

Basic Editor Window
We will examine the window as three segments. Later we will add an additional segment or two, but for now the window segments will be referred to as the Tool Bar - the buttons at the top of the window, the Shortcut Bar - the small buttons immediately above the source code and the Text Field - the actual area containing source code. The Tool Bar buttons are separated into two groups. The left group are used for Building, Executing and Debugging the Target executable, while the right group governs the editor interface. The Shortcut Bar is a row of buttons used for quickly jumping to relevant sections of code in the file currently being edited, or in other files in the same project (other .c and .h files, for example). The Text Field (as configured) only shows the code from one source file. Many source files can be open, however, but rather than having one window for each file, the interface allows you to move Forward and Back between open files by using the two arrowheads on the left side of the Shortcut Bar. The View menu (at the top of the screen) shows the keyboard shortcuts for moving to the Previous File, the Next File, and to Switch to Header/Source File. The Shortcut Bar buttons are a fast and effective method of flipping from source file to source file, while avoiding the tedium of managing an incredible number of windows. As our project only has one source file, the buttons are grayed out and inaccessible. Next is a button that also lets you jump from open source file (not necessarily Open Source ) to open source file (or other files previously accessed), but avoids any Previous/Next dependencies. It also displays the line of code where the cursor is located (:1). To the right of this button is one that allows you to jump from symbol to symbol within the current source file. These symbols include function names, and #defines. The other buttons in the row are for jumping to code bookmarks, breakpoints, corresponding header/source files, and to included files. Just to the right of the last button, and just below the row of Shortcut buttons is a button used to split the text field in half. Clicking this button gives us effectively two text field, each with its own Shortcut Bar, that allows you to work on two sections of code (in different files) at the same time within the same window. The text fields can each show the same source file, and, if the same segment of code is visible in both panes, the second pane will show the changes that you make in the first pane in real time. As you edit the source file, the icon next to the file name and line number in the Shortcut Bar ("main.c:8", for example) will darken. This is a visual cue that the file has not been saved since it has last been modified. Saving the file will cause the icon to appear normally, and other files shown when that Shortcut Bar button is clicked also represent their status (modified/saved) by their icon. If you have made any changes to the code, to see the icon change its shading, first save the file (cmd+S), and then undo (cmd+Z) your changes. In most applications, the list of items that can be undone is erased once the file is saved. Xcode, however, allows us to even undo to points preceding a save. You will be prompted to confirm whether you want to undo past the last point the file was saved. Click "Undo" and continue undoing until all the changes have been removed. Now, close the editor window or click on the Project button in the Tool Bar. We should now be back at the main project window. In the toolbar for this window, a button that looks like the project window exists. Its default location is between the stop sign and the magnifying glass buttons. This Show Editor button causes a text editor pane to appear within the Project window, dividing the right pane in half.


Project Window with Split Editor Panes
As you can see, this editor is the same as the one that popped up when when we double clicked main.c (other than the Tool Bar buttons). This editor pane includes the Shortcut Bar and can again be split in half. Previous version of ProjectBuilder would allow you to split the editor pane into more than two text fields. Perhaps this capability will return in future versions of Xcode as it can be quite handy. Typically, however, two text fields, combined with the other Shortcut buttons for jumping between and within files, will be sufficient for most situations. The two text fields can be minimized back to one by grabbing the rightmost button in the Shortcut bar of the bottom text field (it is actually a handle as indicated by the double horizontal lines), and dragging the shortcut bar as far up as possible. We're now ready to edit the code, and build and debug the executable.

Build and Debug

When developing, the two steps in the process that often "waste" the most time are the Build and Debug steps. If a segment of code is properly planned out, it takes a relatively small amount of time to actually type it in. But, if you're writing a linked-list from scratch (or doing other pointer operations), a rather trivial problem, such as using an invalid array index, can take hours and hours to locate. The integration of the command line gdb debugger into Xcode makes the hunt and elimination of runtime errors relatively painless (depending on the location of the error and your personal debugging skills, naturally). So lets take this Hello World code and add in a common runtime error and a syntax error. Add the following lines of code exactly as they appear between //insert code here... and printf("Hello, World!\n"); (and don't fix the syntax error).
int temp[3] = {1,2,3};
int result = 0;

result = temp[1] - temp[3] * temp[2]);
printf("%i\n", result);
To build the code, click on the left hammer button in the Tool Bar.

Syntax Error
Just below the Tool Bar we can see that the Build Failed (1 error). The Errors and Warnings group in the left pane is no longer grayed out, and we can see a red circle with a white X next to the line of code with the syntax error. If we click the "Errors and Warnings" disclosure triangle (in the left pane), and click on main.c, we will see the error message generated by the compiler (gcc) in the right pane above the text field. The message tells us that the code parser failed before the ')' token.

Error Message
From the point of view of the parser, based on the previous tokens in that line of code, something else should have appeared before the right parenthesis (such as a left parenthesis). We will interpret this message as indicating not that something should have preceded the parenthesis, but that it, itself, is out of place. Delete the erroneous round bracket, but instead of clicking on the build hammer, click on the build and run hammer - the hammer with the green circle and arrowhead. This button will not only compile the executable, but run it once it has successfully completed compiling and linking.

Runtime Error
A "Run" window now pops up and we can see that the application successfully executed and exited. However, our short line of array math didn't calculate the sum we expected. The image above shows the number -7 before the output of "Hello, World!" whereas we would expect the value -5 (1-3*2). The error in this contrived example would be rather trivial to pinpoint without even using the traditional method of inserting printf statements throughout suspect code segments. We would simply look for the line of code where the value of result is calculated and examine its references. This same error, however, could easily be buried within an incrementing loop inside a function call buried deep within the source tree. By memory, it would be difficult to recall the location of the math routine and observe the error. Even printf statements would take far too long, as this style of error may not evidence itself every time the snippet is used as the result may at times appear reasonable or not stand out. Instead, we'll track this bug down with the modern equivalent of printfs, breakpoints. First click the Debug button (the bugspray icon is amusingly appropriate). A Debug window now appears. It has its own set of Tool Bar buttons and three window segments. The bottom segment is another source code editor with all the Shortcut features. Above it are a listing of threads on the left (which we will completely ignore) and a list of variables in the right pane. First lets place a breakpoint at the line // insert code here.... We insert breakpoints by clicking in the left grey sidebar next to the line desired. Placed breakpoints can be moved by dragging them up and down and removed (deleted) by dragging them left or right of the sidebar. Now click the Debug button in the Tool Bar. You can click Build and Debug, but as we haven't modified the code yet, it makes no difference. We can now see our breakpoint, and a red arrow (also in the sidebar) pointing at the first line of code after the comment. If our breakpoint didn't point at the comment, but at the line beneath, the arrow would still be pointing at the same line of code. The red highlighted line of code has not yet been executed. In the Variables pane, click the disclosure triangle next to temp to see the contents of the array before it is initialized.

Debug Window with Breakpoint highlighted
Next, we step through the code, watching the values of temp and result. Before we pick which Step button to use, lets open the Console drawer so that we can see the program's output. The double arrows at the end of the toolbar (if your window is narrow), contains the Console Drawer button. Clicking this button causes the a drawer to appear at the bottom of the window. The drawer is filled with the output from the debugger as it loads the binary and arrives at the breakpoint. If your program contained scanf code, you would use this drawer to enter input. We can choose one of two Step buttons to push (ignoring the other two). Step Over will cause the debugger to execute the highlighted code and then stop before the next line, while Step Instruction will actually step through the assembler instructions one by one. With Step Instruction you can tell that you have completed all the instructions that are part of the line of code when the arrow moves and highlights the next line of code. We will Step Instructions until the next line is highlighted, so that we can watch each array element get initialized. We don't see the instructions themselves (at least not yet), but after 7 clicks, temp[0] will get initialized to 1 and appear red in the Variable pane (the value will be red, not the variable). Two more clicks and are ready to Step Over the initialization of result. We can also Step Over the calculation of result and see the incorrect value (in this case -7) in red. As seen accurately in the Variable pane, the array values were correctly initialized but could in no way be combined, as constrained by this algorithm, to produce the value -7. We only have one line of code that could be faulty, and, after having it stare us in the face for a few minutes, it will inevitably dawn on us that we're using invalid indices to access the array. If we were to Terminate the debugger (by clicking the Stop sign) and begin the process again by clicking Debug, we could actually watch the processor's registers as we stepped through the code, assembley instruction by instruction. If you wish to do so, click the Debug menu, Disassembly Display and then click the disclosure triangle next to Registers in the Variable Pane. The bottom half of the window will split in half again with both the line of code and the assembler instruction in question highlighted.

Debugging with Assembly Language Instructions
First we see $r0, $r9, and $r2 get filled with the array values, and then we see those values get stored in the appropriate memory locations. Next, $r2 gets loaded with the valid but incorrect array value, $r0 is loaded with the value 3 from an invalid memory location, and result is then calculated by multiplying $r2 and $r0, and placing the product in $r2. Once this is completed the value 2 is loaded into $r0 and, subtracting $r2 from $r0, the sum is stored in $r0 and output to the console. Such a fine level of inspection cannot be matched with printf, nor can it be so easily accessed and observed by using gdb on the command line. (I have no experience with ddd, though I hope it works in a similar fashion to Xcode.) Once the array indices have each been decremented, making them valid, Terminate the debugger (Stop Sign button) and close the window, returning to the Run window. Now Build and Run to see the program execute as expected. Congratulations, you've now exercised the major portions of Xcode that are useful for basic command line projects. Save it, close it, or use it as the base for a new (or new to Xcode) project.

Conclusion

Most academic and beginner level programming can be accomplished simply with a text editor and a command line compiler. For the most part, a full blown IDE (such as Xcode) is not necessary. However, access to a robust and well thought out IDE can speed and ease the task of development at any level. The main obstacle for beginners, that keeps them from using an IDE, is the additional learning curve involved as you fight the IDE to get it to do what you want. If the Development Environment gets in your way, what's the point in using it, right? Hopefully this brief tutorial has given enough insight into the layout, options and features of Xcode to make it accessible to any programmer looking to enhance his conventional development methodology. Please feel free to comment and demand further clarity or to suggest corrections and other topics to cover.
item.excerpt:encoded: An introduction to the interface and capabilities of Apple's Xcode Integrated Development Environment (IDE)

item.title: Enhancing a 34 Hour Drive
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
The trip that Isopraxis and I took from Calgary, Alberta, Canada to San Diego, California, USA, took a total travel time (including gassing up and eating) about 34 hours. Luckily I had access to an old Powerbook (G3 400) and I have my entire music collection on a portable 80 GB Firewire hard drive. I also borrowed an AC Inverter so we could run the whole setup while the car was on. Playing it through a cassette adapter was satisfactory, and the endless supply of music allowed us to pick tracks that fit the situation. iTunes was used to generate playlists, but we ran into a problem. If, in the middle of a 6 hour playlist, we stopped the car and had to resume the playlist, any tracks that we had previously played would again be available in the randomized list. We needed to be able to generate a Smart Playlist whose contents would be based on a standard playlist, but with the ability to only include songs that hadn't been previously played on the trip. Unfortunately, Smart Playlists were not given such a capacity, at that time. Less than two weeks after arriving, iTunes 4.5 (for Mac and Windows) was released, and among many more interesting features, the ability to base a Smart Playlist on other Playlists (Smart or otherwise) is included. It wouldn't have saved our lives, but it was an obvious feature that needed to be included. The music we played was of quite varied styles. Somehow, despite our 7 year age difference, and growing up mostly apart, Isopraxis and I have shockingly similar tastes in music. We've talked about it several times and can't decide if it was genetic or environmental. Our strong tendency toward electronic music (electro) we think may stem from the endless hours each of us spent driving a tractor around and around the family farm's fields. The rhythmic hum of the diesel engine and the odd vibrations combined in ways that weren't really musical, but that I came to recognize and know. Endlessly driving in circles, watching the swarming seagulls and trying to drive perfectly straight, left lots of time for imagining and thinking. Noise turned to rhythm and rhythm was companionship. I quite hated doing it, but it was good for me none-the-less. If anyone ever wonders why I don't mind working alone, I should cite my early training. So I figured it could be of interest to list the tracks that helped us make this 2600 km (1600 miles) bearable. iTunes nicely generated a Smart Playlist of all the songs listened to from April 16 to April 19, 2004. A feature also exists where you can export the information for every track in a playlist as XML (or plain text). Next I wanted to convert this data into a human readable HTML table, and I hoped I wouldn't have to program a solution to this task on my own. Versiontracker , when I searched for "xml itunes," nicely pointed me toward phptunest, a php script that will convert iTunes XML data to HTML (and do nifty sorting and whatnot). I grabbed phptunest, edited the configuration according to the instructions, and moved my .xml file into the same directory as the script, but I didn't want to run the php script through a browser (as is the common way to execute php). So I decided to try out the terminal. The command:
[hostname:~] username% php tunes.php
Seemed to take its time doing something, and then returned me to the blank prompt. A quick check in the finder and voila an .html file was awaiting. A few more tweaks to the settings file, and I had three more tables built, each with a different track sorting. If you're interested in looking through the track listing, you can look at it in the original order played, or sorted by artist, album or track name. One day, 20 hours and 15 minutes of music and spoken word - and NO REPEATS .
item.excerpt:encoded: Converting iTunes Playlist to HTML table

item.title: A Flames Fan?
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
My first introduction to hockey was in the early/mid 80's when my brother-in-law Doug watched the Edmonton Oilers play in the Stanley Cup playoffs. In the late 80's, I occasionally followed the playoffs when my team, the Oilers, were playing. I always enjoyed watching Grant Fuhr work his magic. Edmonton, however, was not the popular team in school. The team to cheer for was decidedly the Calgary Flames. I most certainly was not a Calgary fan. I liked the city, but when it came to hockey and football, the Edmonton teams were always my pick. About the last year that Fuhr played for Edmonton was the last time I really followed the playoffs. Regular season hockey has little appeal to me. There's not much at stake and you can tell when you watch the games (or else its just my attitude). But something different happened this year, and I'm following the playoffs with real intent. You see, I've been living in Calgary for about the last 8 years. I'm still an Edmonton Eskimos fan, but I enjoy seeing Calgary do well. I also still prefer the Oilers, but when Calgary made the playoffs, and Edmonton didn't, something clicked and I've really been keen on watching Calgary win (and cheering them on). Its been many years (8?) since Calgary even made the playoffs, and tonight they even beat the Detroit RedWings to make it into the final four (or third round). But there's been a problem. I've been living in San Diego for the past three weeks, and I don't have cable, and worse than that, I don't even have a TV. I have listened to a couple of games over the internet, but, while better than nothing, its just not as good as watching it. So what do I do? Hmmm, well, one day, as I was video-conferencing with Madge and Lilo with iChat, I realized that they could probably sit the iBook in front of the TV, aim the iSight at it, and with any luck I'd be able to see and hear every minute of the action. I was afraid that the picture would be all flashy - that the camera would pick up the scanning of the TV, but somehow it works out beautifully.

Personal Hockey Night in Canada
It doesn't matter that CalgaryFlames.com only provides an audio stream, all I need are my own family members to set up a private video stream. The image isn't quite as good as watching a real TV (as I can't see the puck very often), but I can see every hit and follow the action live. And if I make it full-screen, I can sit right back and enjoy myself. The game tonight was so good, and I'm so happy (though deep down I don't know why) that CALGARY WON. The Overtime goal, with just seconds left, gave them the series win with a score of 1-0. Both teams fought hard, and played really well. A tight, tense match whose outcome I quite like. It almost makes me wish I owned a jersey.
item.excerpt:encoded: Calgary beats Detroit in Hockey and I'm surprised I'm so glad

item.title: Baby Poll
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: I had the idea earlier tonight that it might be fun to put a poll on the site to get people's votes on when they think our baby will arrive. See the sidebar on the right. Pick one that seems right and click Vote. As individuals in each family may want to vote, I've enabled the ability to vote multiple times. (Please don't skew the results though, it would be fun to see how close the true average is.) I've also thought of putting up a second poll for gender voting. But I'm too tired tonight to figure it out. (For those interested, the php script for the poll is fantastic, but doesn't have the greatest instructions in the world. Its called Advanced Poll and I got it at http://proxy2.de/scripts.php. If you need help installing it, leave a comment. I should see if I can have email address not publicly displayed anywhere but so that I can contact you personally - if the address is valid of course. I don't want to help spam harvesters or contribute to a spam problem...) Update - I've incorporated MTObfuscate into the comments so that your email address (or URL) will not be harvested by spammers and search engines. It requires that javascript is enabled for your browser. If you haven't turned javascript off, its probably on and you're fine. If you want another margin of security, write dut com instead of .com. It was Ryan's idea.
item.excerpt:encoded: Vote on the baby's birth date.

item.title: Learning to Spell
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
I've been using computers since I was five or six years old. I remember knowing more about how the computer in my Grade One class worked than the teacher – because we had one just like it at home! It was an Apple ][+, and it was great.
Now, just because I mentioned computers, don't go thinking that this is going to be all technical. I'll avoid falling into my educated role of a computer engineer and just explain a tendency I've just discovered about myself. But first some background information, and that's why I mentioned my first computer.
Early on I learned the placement of the various keys on the keyboard. If I recall correctly (IIRC), the keys were rather stiff and noisy, and I certainly didn't touch type. But I soon found typing to be more efficient than writing. I wasn't the first (but may have been) in my classes to submit printed reports when everyone else just wrote. Perhaps this speed/efficiency disparity is what has caused me to have rather irregular handwriting – I just didn't see the value in perfecting it as I already knew of a better way. It was probably in Grade 4 that I first took a "Computers" class. Mostly that meant typing practice I think. "'Tiger in the tall grass,' by I.C. Stripes" I soon had mastered the home row, and I haven't left it since. Now the appearance, in those early days of word processing, of spell checkers made typing a forgiving process (unless of course you wrote "there" instead of "their" and then never proof-read). In fact, it was a huge feature. But in this modern era of Internet-enabled computing, spell checking is often an ignored and overlooked feature. People even make a living out of spelling mistakes. Now, since my early use of Apple Computers products, they remain my preferred tool to use (though I speak Windows and DOS and Linux and French fluently as well). The most recent iterations of the Mac OS operating system (OS X) have included a nifty feature that first appeared (IIRC) in Microsoft Word. That feature is real-time spell checking. That is, when you misspell a word, it becomes immediately apparent because the word gets a red "underline" mark to signify that it's not a recognized word.

Not a fake error
Now, what's unique about this feature is that the capability for real-time spell checking is built into OS X itself. Any programmer can quite simply tell his program to use the built in checker, and every place that people type, their mistakes could be highlighted. EVERY program could include spell checking with minimal effort. So what do you do when you see a word underlined like this? The easy way is to simply ctrl+click (or right-click) on the incorrect word.

Correcting the mistake
A menu will appear with the suggested words at the top. Pick the correct one, or Learn/Ignore the word. However, once I get into a typing groove, like when I'm chatting (instant messaging) with Madge, I don't like to move to and from the mouse just to fix my spelling mistakes. Even with a tough word like anthropomorphizing, I've developed the habit of backspacing and trying again, and again, until I spell the word correctly on my own. I'm learning how to spell more words all the time. In grade school I had teachers who actually discouraged the use of spell checkers because of the tendency to rely heavily on them instead of just learning the correct spelling. However, this system of having misspelt words indicated as you type them has the subtle feature of encouraging me (at least) to want to do it right on my own (and know the proper spelling). It also keeps me from sending off messages riddle with errors that come with typing fast (like writing "teh", "liek," and "thier"). Microsoft Office products have gotten "smart" and auto-correct errors like these. While easy on the user, this neither encourages people to improve their typing skills, nor teaches correct spelling, but it has the added detriment of causing people, when using non-Microsoft Office products, to type as though the machine will just fix their mistakes (even though it isn't going to). We hence have search engines that will give positive results for misspelled words, and a generation of people who expect the computer to make up for their own laziness and inattention. Its bad enough that poor pronunciation is being accepted as "correct" in the dictionary, hopefully incorrect spelling remains incorrect. The easy way isn't necessarily the best way.
item.excerpt:encoded: The right way to learn to spell and type

item.title: New Baby Girl
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Just a quick note before I fall off to sleep. Madge and I are the proud parents of a brand new baby girl. We're mostly decided on a name but have to nail it down tomorrow.

First Baby Photo
She is cute, pink and didn't get too squished. Born May 17, 2004, at 15:06. 6 lbs 9 oz and 19.5 inches long. She's very quiet thus-far (just cute little squeaks), has bright little eyes that love to peer around to see what is making noise and the softest skin on her feet. I've forgotten exactly how soft and smooth they can be.

Family of Four
Everyone is healthy and happy – I'll give a full report tomorrow, and a full set of pictures, after some sleep. Hopefully this is sufficient preliminary info and pictures.
item.excerpt:encoded: Beautiful Baby Girl born May 17, 2004

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Oh, I am so excited for you guys! Congratulations! I've been checking your blog almost every day to see if the baby had arrived. She is so tiny and perfect!
Yahoo! She looks like a cutie. A little pal for Lilo.
Woo Hooo Congrat's guys you all look so good together. Skip I hope this isn't the beginning of another 6 girl family hehehe!

item.title: Introducing, Sophia Elle Anderson
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I arrived home from San Diego on Friday, May 14, 2004. Saturday was our 5th wedding anniversary (YAY), and Sunday we just relaxed. But sometime either Saturday or Sunday Madge noticed that her Braxton Hicks Contractions were happening a bit more often and were a bit stronger. We figured that things were getting closer but labour still hadn't started. Monday morning at 6:30 AM Madge awoke to the uncomfortable feeling of her membranes rupturing. We hurriedly grabbed the hospital bags, the camera and drove off to the hospital. The sudden and immediacy of the delivery was a bit disconcerting to Madge, but once we arrived at the hospital she managed to calm herself and we put the panic behind us. We didn't get stuck in Triage for forever, in fact, after a quick check (4 cm) at around 8:00 AM, I was instructed to get Madge admitted and when I returned to the 5th floor, Madge no longer occupied the triage bed where I left her. I was quite afraid that things had progressed faster than expected and that perhaps I'd missed something important. The triage nurse caught my eye at the desk and told me to head off to room 524. Madge was there with an Obstetrical Nurse and a big smile. I soon learned that a neat set of circumstances would allow a good friend of ours, Carol, who is both an Obstetrical Nurse and a trained Midwife would be our nurse for the day. We were excited because we originally wanted to use Carol's midwifery services but were not in a position to pay the cost. So, because someone on the shift had called in sick, and the hospital had called in Carol as a replacement, we were in a wonderfully surprising situation. Carol had Madge put some street clothes back on and instructed us to go for a walk to get/keep things going. After the walk, we climbed up and down a few flights of stairs as contractions continued to progress and intensify. Sometime around 13:00, we both got a bit sleepy. I ended up having a nap in a chair while Madge laid on her side and tried, unsuccessfully, to nap as well. Suddenly I was awoken as Madge's contractions suddenly shifted gears. It was just after 14:00 when she turned the corner and we knew the delivery would soon be here. As the contractions intensified, so did our efforts to focus Madge and keep her from getting too panicked and noisy. She did really well focusing on Carol's instructions as the contractions became very intense. She managed the pain and discomfort well but certainly wished for it to be all over. Carol checked Madge again and knew that things were close (8 cm). She was scheduled to leave at 15:00 (when she checked) but because of the impending delivery decided to stay and see it through. Moments later it was evident that the Doctor ought to be brought in (Carol could have done it all, but...).

Sophia Pictures
At 15:06 our second beautiful daughter was delivered. She was cute and pink and covered in vernix. She doesn't look like Madge, like our first daughter. I'm quite sure that her features draw more from my side of the family, but unlike the first time, she has cute dark hair. The soft feet, cute toes and nose, and bright eyes melt my heart. She has a soft little squeaky cry but quiets at the sound of my voice. We spent some time trying to nail down the most appropriate name, and we've succeeded. Sophia Elle Anderson was born at 15:06, May 17, 2004. Curiously, this date was not available on my poll, so no one was able to vote for it. She was 6 lbs 9 oz, and 19.5 inches long. I'm not sure what Apgar score she got but it was probably pretty good. Pictures are available at http://homepage.mac.com/dwa/index.html. (I will mirror them here once the initial traffic has subsided - Apple has a bigger/faster connection than I do so I'll let them do the work).
item.excerpt:encoded: The birth story of Sophia Elle Anderson

item.title: More Baby Photos and Thoughts
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I should really document the fun and uncomfortable parts of newborn parenthood. Unfortunately, to properly remember the situations and exhaustion, I would want to include details that not everyone would be interested in (or want to read about). So if I start a private blog, that none of you can read and won't even know about (except for this post), don't be offended. A private journal of this type will be nice because I can better keep pace with my thoughts when typing compared handwriting. But there's also something nice about leafing through an old journal and seeing real handwriting – it tends to bring back the moment a bit better.

Sophia sleeping with Mom
However, I've posted another set of pictures of Sophia. Things on the newborn front are improving, but life certainly isn't as stable as it used to be. Where Lauryn simply wouldn't sleep at all (I paced, bouncing her, for hours and hours in an exhausted state), Sophia will sleep for periods longer than all the baby references we read say the time between feedings should be. Conversely, after initial feeding troubles with Lauryn, she quickly got much better. Sophia, however, just doesn't have enough sucking "oomph" to get the job done all the time. But don't think that she's weak or anything... For the short periods of time that she's awake, she's quite "howly" and kicky and is always holding her head up (for a few seconds). We had forgotten how frustrating little ones can be. Not because they mean to be frustrating, but just because the exhaustion compounds with the struggles and you get weary and aren't as positive about the situation. And then the little one will put on a cute face and or look cute while sleeping and wash all the troubles away. I'll have to write more about the trials of teaching/surviving a newborn as I remember/encounter them.
item.excerpt:encoded: Second set of Sophia pictures

item.title: Easy Memorization
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Bedtime with Lauryn is a ritual, with no deviations. Well, there are variations, but only Lauryn can make changes to the routine – changes that Madge and I try to avoid. She's fallen, somewhat, into the practice of trying to stretch out teeth-brushing, story-reading, and song-singing as long as possible. Most nights it all goes well, but there's always some sort of challenge. Two stories, two songs, and a lullabye, then the music box and lights out. That's the pattern.

Playing "Hole Hole" and "Bush Bush"
Lately, instead of me reading and singing everything, she's taken to splitting the reading tasks between the two of us. Sometimes I need to "help," but surprisingly she does quite well. Naturally, at being just a couple of weeks short of 3 years, she most certainly cannot read, but in reading mostly the same 20 books over the past 2 years every night, several have been committed to memory. Tonight it was Piglet's New Friend, a board book with a moveable Piglet. The words on each page were perfectly recited, word for word, as pages were turn just at the right time (and Piglet was moved appropriately). However, she surprised me tonight when it was time to sing. We used to just sing regular songs. While I was in San Diego, the ritual changed (according to her demands) so that we now sing made-up songs that are about the two songs we just read. Tonight, as we each read one story, we each also had to sing a song. After singing mine, and struggling to remember what we had just read about (including enough details to sufficiently satisfy her song criteria so I don't have to sing it again, better), Lauryn followed up by flopping around on her bed, reciting the entire story, word for word (except the last page).

Piglet's New Friend

"Who do we have here?" Pooh asked, unpacking his picnic basket. "It's a caterpillar," Piglet exclaimed. "Maybe he'd like to try some honey," Pooh suggested. "Careful, Pooh!" Piglet warned. "Honey is too sticky for caterpillars." Piglet spotted his new friend on Eeyore's lunch. "Maybe he'd like to try some of my thistles," Eeyore offered. "I think thistles may be too prickly for caterpillars," Piglet explained. "Piglet, my kite's stuck!" moaned Roo. "If I can squeeze through these bushes, maybe I can free it," said Piglet. "Look!" said Roo. "The caterpillar wants to help, too!" The hungry little caterpillar began munching the green leaves. "You've found some lunch!" Piglet said. "Now I can have mine."
Kid's books often don't have the most compelling of stories, in my opinion, but evidently this one is worth remembering. (grin) Also, while its been a few months since she convinced us of her ability to remember stories (and songs), I always assumed that the recollection of the exact words was keyed to the images on a specific page (or the tune of a song). I've probably read this story to her about half the number of times that she's heard it, and while I could tell you the gist of it, I would never remember at which point the book says "Piglet warned." Yet with no cues, her young and sponge-of-a mind has captured and can recall this funny book. If you're a parent, or will be a parent, or every spend time around a young child (which should include about everyone), never forget how much impact your speech and actions can have on that child. Little "pitchers" have big ears, so don't expect them to speak or act differently than you, their example, and don't underestimate their capacity to learn and comprehend.
item.excerpt:encoded: Bedtime Ritual and Memorization of Stories

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yes you are right. Children remember EVERY thing so be CAREFUL!

I remember a day in june last year when I woke up on a saturday morning and in my foggy half-drowsed state went out to the back lawn with Lauryn to play on the grass. I don't know what it is about the Boards of Canada, but my memories of that day recall the wonderful melty sounds as if there was something singularIy precious in that moment and I could feel myself blissfully counting through it. . . sixty-ten, sixty-eleven . . . She had her little blue knit toque on her head - perfectly matching her eyes. Somehow for a few minutes there was nothing else but the green grass, warm morning air, the sound of robins and my beautiful little niece all cast in the shimmering glow of a soft focus living dream. If I could memorize anything it would be that purely perfect morning.

item.title: Whites, Darks, and Pinks
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
The joys of two daughters

As much as I would have loved to have been writing over the past few days, well, we've been swamped. I've had lots to write about but no time to even lay my fingers to a keyboard. However, today I finally had time to do some much needed laundry. (As you can see, if replenishing the pile of infant clothes moves from the "must do" list to the "free time" list, you know your priorities have shifted and that you've been rather occupied.) I grabbed the most evident laundry, especially the ones needing scrubbing, and headed outside to our new laundry room. (New to us of course - the washing machine is old and the dryer isn't much newer.) As I started the washer, and separated the laundry, I soon realized that we are now subject to three color categories. Whites, Darks, and Pinks. Two girls, and especially one infant daughter (4 weeks old tomorrow), generate lots of cute laundry. Cute, pink laundry. (Well, its cute other than the times that it has diaper-leak spots that need endless scrubbing.) The three piles were about even in size - maybe a bit heavy on the darks, but my jeans occupy much more space than 10 burp clothes and a dozen tiny socks. Pink laundry smells nice too (mostly). Babies, up until about the age of 2, I'd say, put off a non-diaper (non-burp) odour that conveys everything cute and sweet about babies. I swear that sometime I'm going to take a worn (but clean) sleeper and double zip-lock it so that when I'm going through the struggles of teenage girls, I can open the bag and take a whiff of newborn goodness. And now I'm off to bed. Goodnight.
item.excerpt:encoded: Three types of laundry, brought to you by newborns.

item.title: Why Babies Should Be Born Bald
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
When our first daughter, Lauryn, was born, her thin blonde hair laid so evenly on her head that for months people thought she was bald. Slowly the hair grew and at one point there was a patch, at the back of her head, of soft dirty-blonde hair that, if you blew on it just right, looked like a cute mustache. Sophia, however, was born with a fair amount of soft dark hair. The back half of her head has longer hair than the front, but no one could claim that she's bald.

Playing Together
There's a downside to this situation, however. Up until about two days ago, her longer hair laid flat and neat - smooth on top of her head. When we decided that she'd probably enjoy spending some of her active-awake time laying on a blanket, we witnessed the results of Sophia's little hands discovering her own hair. With her head turned to the right, arms stretched up above her shoulders, her left hand was perfectly positioned to touch and stroke her soft locks. She seemed quite pleased with her discovery, but in the process of enjoying the sensation, she "backcombed" her hair into a soft fluff.

Backcombing
I've been told my hair, as a child, behaved in a similar fashion (only standing on end), but in addition to perhaps a genetic predisposition, Sophia assists the process. With touching comes grabbing, and Madge was required to intervene. Sophia grabbed a chunk of her own fluff and pulled, making herself cry. When the crying begins, she doesn't stop pulling and its necessary to literally pry her hand open. At this point the crying ceases. Funny, funny kid. Makes herself cry and doesn't know why. So if you wish to avoid this same situation with your children, just make sure they're born bald.
item.excerpt:encoded: Sophia discovers hair

item.title: New camera equals lots of photos
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Click me for more pictures
We should hopefully be able to post lots of pictures in the near future, as today we purchased a new camera. It should do the trick if I can figure out the best modes/buttons/settings to use for every shot.
item.excerpt:encoded: We should hopefully be able to post lots of pictures in the near future, as today we purchased a new camera. It should do the trick if I can figure out the best modes/buttons/settings to use for every shot.

item.title: SoCal Flora
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
The new camera finally gives us a chance to capture and share some of the beautiful plants and flowers that surround us here in Southern California (SoCal).

Click for more flora
