We learned, last weekend, that we have a hibiscus in our backyard (growing much faster than our neglected hibiscus in Calgary) and a pomegranate tree. The pomegranate flowers attracted a pretty hummingbird about a month ago, and now the flowers are falling off and baby pomegranates are swelling up. I don't know how big they'll get, but I'll definitely keep it watered. Anyway, here's a taste of what's in our backyard and right nearby. Click to see the SoCal Flora. (Photos by Madge)
item.excerpt:encoded: The new camera finally gives us a chance to capture and share some of the beautiful plants and flowers that surround us here in Southern California (SoCal).

item.title: Smiley Baby
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Sophia spent a fair amount of Sunday afternoon just hanging out being cute. What To Expect The First Year says that babies start to smile between 4 and 6 weeks after birth. Well, Sophia is right on schedule.

Click for Sunday Baby Photos
We shot a bunch of pictures trying to capture one of the good smiles and ended up with what we think are cute pictures.

"Everybody says that my baby's smiles are 'just gas' but he looks so happy when he does it. Couldn't they be real?"

No new mother wants to believe that her baby's first smiles are the work of a passing bubble of gas, rather than of a wave of love meant especially for her. But alas, it appears from scientific evidence so far to be true: most babies don't smile in the true social sense before four to six weeks of age.
You will be able to distinguish the first real smile from those tentative practice ones by the way the baby uses his whole face – not just his mouth. Though babies don't smile until they're ready, they're ready faster when they're talked to, played with, and cuddled a lot.

from What To Expect The First Year by Arlene Eisenbert, Heidi E. Murkoff, and Sandee E. Hathaway, B.S.N.
I also took some shots of Madge and Sophia. Other than in the hospital, Madge has been absent from almost all of the pictures (but who's keeping score, right?). Here's a batch of Sunday pictures. We hope you enjoy them.

item.title: Satellite Pictures of Canada
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
One of the best worst things about having a new baby is being awake in the middle of each night. Sophia is great compared to Lauryn, as she'll sleep from 23:00 to until about 04:30 where Lauryn would have been awake at least once during that time period (until she was almost one if I recall correctly). I wake up and try to assist Madge as much as possible. This usually involves fetching Sophia, burping (sometimes) and then soothing her back to sleep and laying her down. During the actual feeding part of the awake time, I usually talk with Madge a bit or more commonly I'll drift in and out of sleep, trying to both rest as much as possible, and be at the ready to help. In the past I've had episodes of talking in my sleep. Madge used to wish she had paper beside the bed to capture the funny things I'd say. The title of this post is one of the first things I said to Madge when I was still half-asleep. Another time, at her parents' house, Madge woke me from a nap telling me dinner was ready. My response: "No, no, its point zero–one". However, tonight, as I was drifting in and out of sleep, and Madge was trying to talk to me, my mouth decided to say things that my brain hadn't validated. She was able to record the incident, which went something like this:
Madge: You know, its taken her more than a month to get this figured out. Skip: Its taken her more than a month-and-a-half. Madge: She's not even a month-and-a-half old yet. Skip: Good point. Skip: Is that why there are more than a hundred and sixty keys?          A celebration on my cake?
I cannot explain myself, and I'm certain it will happen again. Its a good thing that Sophia is so cute (to me), otherwise I'd totally hate this. Sleep is becoming a dear old friend that I once knew but haven't been well acquainted with for a while. I miss it. Oh, and then Madge makes the joke, after saying, "That was a cute baby coo," of, "And not C-O-U-P," that gives me visions of a gang of floppy babies, barely able to hold up their heads, trying to overthrow the government. Things are funnier when you're exhausted.
item.excerpt:encoded: During the actual feeding part of the awake time, I usually talk with Madge a bit or more commonly I'll drift in and out of sleep, trying to both rest as much as possible, and be at the ready to help.... Madge was completely capable of recording the incident, which went something like this: Madge: Its taken her more than a month to get this figured out Skip: Its taken her more than a month and a half.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Dad wondered if strange fumes from the neighbors have been wafting over through the window and skewing his reasoning abilities!!!
That's hillarious. I'm glad you've got it recorded.

item.title: Beach and Bath Photos
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
We had a busy day yesterday and a frustrating night the night before. We've never owned our own television. We had loaners and old TVs, but were never in a position to purchase our own. Friday night we decided it was time, and ended up at Best Buy, ready to walk out with either a Sharp 27" regular TV or a fancy Samsung HDTV. We decided against the HDTV model because we figured HDTVs were going to improve (and come down in cost) in the near future (as confirmed by wikipedia later that night). So we moved to the till with our chosen TV. Neither would they take my starter cheque for my new account (the only one with money at this point), nor a credit card imprint on that cheque. And despite possession of a US Passport, the ultimate identification, we couldn't even get a Best Buy credit card because I don't have a state-issued drivers license. We walked out dejected and empty handed, but unsure if the TV would have even fit in the car. Grrr. Saturday we wanted to go to the beach, but I but wanted to get a little wetsuit with built in lifejacket for Lauryn from Costco and more memory for the new camera. After the previous night's experience I knew I had to get cash, so we packed up, made a trip to the bank, and headed over to Costco. After grabbing the items we had come for, we walked through the TV section and saw almost the same model TV that we'd tried to buy the night before. This time we had the cash and were still adventuresome enough to try and fit a new TV in the front seat of our car (sans boîte, bien sûr). So we did it. I'm amazed that it fit (just barely) and I even took a picture to remember our craziness. It didn't take long to drive home and drop off the TV, followed by a trip for lunch at Rubio's Fresh Mexican Grill for some fish tacos and chicken burrito. Then, after being here for about three weeks, we finally made a daytime trip to the beach (La Jolla Shores).

Lauryn goes to the beach
Lauryn was excited, but Sophia's hunger (and no reasonable place to feed her as the feedings aren't without challenges yet...) kept us from staying very long. Lauryn and I headed down to the water's edge, leaving Madge and sleeping Sophia safely on the dry sand. I planned on dipping our toes in the water to see if it was worth putting Lauryn in her new wetsuit, but my plans aren't always the best. Shortly after getting our feet wet, and while looking down into the water, a larger wave (still very small) threw Lauryn off balance, plunging into the sandy surf. I popped her up and onto her feet as quick as a flash, but the damage was done.

Sophia's bath
She was shocked, and had no idea what had happened. Seconds later Lauryn realized that she was wet and, despite my efforts to convince her that it was fine and that the water was nice, the coolness of the situation made her want to go see Mom. We pulled off her wet clothes, dressed her in a more appropriate fashion, and headed back to enjoy the water. We only spent a few more minutes before it was time to go, but the weather was beautiful, the sand was warm, and the ocean wasn't cold. We'll definitely have to go back. I have two new sets of pictures available of our trip to Costco and the Beach, and a later set from Sophia's bath that night.
item.excerpt:encoded: We had a busy day yesterday and a frustrating night the night before.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hey, you guys, I'm just loving keeping up with your family on your website! Hope you don't mind! I can't believe how Sofia is growing, and Lauryn makes me miss Talia and Liam. I'm sure Judy is missing your little ones.
I may occasionally post some of your pictures on the ward website if you don't mind. I'm sure people would enjoy them.
Don't have too much fun on those beautiful beaches! We sure miss you!
Love, Lynne

Lynne, The whole reason I post our adventures online (and have a website) is so that people who might not get included in a more typical mass-email can have an equal opportunity. Post anything on our ward's website that you'd wish or point them here. We went to our new ward for the first time today (as a family). It sure is different - hardly a grey (or even greying) hair in sight ? and its not because they use hair-dye either. Its all people our age with similarly sized families. We're sure to have a lot of fun. But it's a transient ward and we're sure to transition back north as well. Glad you left a comment, Dave
Miss you guys here. I like the pictures... i wish i were at the beach right now with you guys. Have lots of fun. love ya, Erika

Erika, After going there on Saturday I totally hope that as many people come and visit as possible while we live here. The water wasn't cold, there was lots of open breach area (even though there were a lot of people) and it was almost surreal in how NEAT it was. Oh, and I saw one of these down by the beach too - a Ferrari Enzo (and another slightly more common red Ferrari earlier in the day). Come down anytime. Skip

I read your article and felt I'd better tell you know that I think your viewpoints are excellently written and thought-provoking. Your article is fantastic.

item.title: If you haven't got your health...
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: The four of us moved down here to San Diego three weeks (to the day) after Sophia was born. Things weren't going fantastic with the little one by the time we left, but the timing worked well for my employer and this adventure had to start sometime. I hope to document the day of travel before I forget it all, but I'd like to work back to that day a bit with this post. Before Lauryn was born, we studied the pros/cons of nursing vs formula quite heavily. It was a struggle to feed Lauryn at first, including a late night trip by Madge, with Mennipus' help, to the hospital because of a severe case of mastitis. After a few weeks, things settled down and nursing turned out to be rather convenient (not to mention the health and emotional positives for Lauryn). We weren't going to change our routine with Sophia. But things didn't go very well this time around. We were able to better manage the first few days, but Sophia wouldn't latch and her electric equivalent (the proxy nurser) needed to always be at hand. Thus the prospect of traveling only three weeks after her birth, with these complications persisting, was definitely a daunting adventure. However, we don't often turn down a challenge, and we survived the day of travel. Just four days later, we were weary and facing a bleak situation. Friday night, just when things in the feeding department seemed to be turning a corner, Madge started feeling achy and feverish. We both immediately recognized these as mastitis symptoms. But this time we were in a foreign country, with the expectation of having health care coverage, but nothing to prove (even to ourselves) that we wouldn't be facing huge medical bills because of the infection. So I pumped Madge as full of ibuprofen as I could and did my best to let her rest – hoping that somehow things could improve on their own. They didn't. That night I laid, half-awake, trying to imagine how to get out of this awful situation. "We could fly back, and just forget living here," my fatigued brain said amongst other equally unrealistic solutions. Saturday morning Lauryn and I awoke early, and Sophia and Madge slept. Hoping that Madge would awaken feeling better, I was rebuked by her reminder late that morning that, "These things don't just get better." "I need to see a Doctor." I went into panic mode, being forced to deal with a situation that I dreaded and that caused me much anguish. Immediately I realized that I had no one to turn to. The internet didn't give me any health hotline numbers to call for advice, and I didn't have time to waste. A co-worker, Dennis, who had also moved down for the project at work, was my only hope. I didn't know his home phone number, but luckily I'd asked him about his weekend plans, and knew that he was going to be in the office that morning. So I sent him an email. I could have tried calling his extension, as its one off from my own, but I figured that if he were in the office, he'd check his email before checking his voicemail (and its permanent queue of 15 messages). Within minutes he called. I'm thankful for his wisdom and his assistance. Basically he told me to forget the potential expense and get the situation taken care of – that it was foolishness to risk Madge's health. He also volunteered to look around the office for our project manager's home phone (or cell) number and that he'd even call and find out what he could as far as my coverage was concerned (and what I should say and do). He left voice-mails with at least two people before getting a live body, and promptly called back saying that we should simply head to the nearest hospital, explain our symptoms (but not raise any alarms) and to be armed with our Visa card (just in case). I knew there was a hospital around the corner (and another just on the other side of the freeway), so we packed up the kids and made our first outing: a trip to the hospital. We were surprised that the walk-in emergency was empty. Madge wrote her symptoms on a card, and dropped it in a box. A triage nurse retrieved it from the other side of the wall in a few minutes, and soon she was evaluated. Sophia slept and Lauryn ate a two-slice peanut butter and jam sandwich (the whole thing - crust and all.) After being evaluated, and prior to seeing a doctor, payment had to be arranged. I could remember enough from the healthcare forms I'd filled out two days prior that I was able to convince the administrator-guy that we should have coverage even though we'd not yet received cards. Madge saw a doctor and our home-diagnosis was confirmed. A simple antibiotic prescription would be sufficient and we were done. In the meantime, Lauryn's diaper had leaked and she'd started into her second PB&J sandwich (which she later finished!). Based on the "Primary Care Physician" that I'd chosen (two days earlier), the Administrator-guy warned that our insurance plan might try and get out of paying for our visit because we'd gone to a hospital to which our Dr. was not affiliated! Ugh. We'd survived that far only to learn that the hospital that we should have gone to was right next door. Not only are there two hospitals within a 5-minute drive of each other, there are actually three within that distance. (I later discovered that the Dr. is affiliated with the hospital we picked, and we haven't heard anything from the insurance people yet.) Basically things worked out well despite all my trepidation and agony. The business nature of medical service down here does mean that the emergency wait is nice and short, and that the people are very friendly and accommodating (as they want your business). But honestly, three hospitals within shouting distance seems a bit excessive. Oh, wait, we now live in the land of excess. I forgot for a second...

item.title: Stockman's Memorial Foundation
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
My friend Ryan claims to personally know every person that shows up in a google search for "Biffard". After browsing the section of Ryan's site belonging to his brother, Glen Neil Biffard, I decided to google "Glen Neil Biffard". At the bottom of the search page I noticed the name "Biffard" placed in close proximity to small towns near my hometown.
Naturally I clicked on the link and was taken to a page at the Stockmen's Memorial Foundation website listing "Community Families". I don't particularly know why they have such a listing, as other than looking for a ranching family in Southern Alberta and being able to see what community area they live[d] in, you can't do much with that information. Looking for familiar names may, however, take you into a nostalgic journey of yesteryear. So my curiousity was piqued and I decided to look and see what members of my family were listed on these mysterious pages. Jumping to the A page I was not able to find the name of my own father, but did see listings for my grandparents (who I never knew), Anderson, Angus & Ada - Warner, and for one of my unkles and for one of his sons. Someone in my extended family was obviously a member of this association, so I looked at their "About" page and read this declaration

The Stockmen's Memorial Foundation

The Stockmen?s Memorial Foundation was officially organized in 1980 by fifty founding members comprising of ranchers, farmers and individuals who wanted to commemorate the Canadian livestock industry. The organization was incorporated as a non-profit association and was established as a foundation by an act of the Alberta legislature. It is also approved as a charitable organization by Revenue Canada.
as well as the following Foundation Objectives
The objectives of the Stockmen's Memorial Foundation are:
  • to identify and remember the builders of the livestock industry and others who have made outstanding contributions to its progress
  • to provide historical and business information relating to the livestock industry
  • to familiarize the public with the lore of the cattle industry
  • to encourage a general appreciation of the sociological and economic significance of the livestock industry
What makes this find interesting is not as much that I have family members listed in their index, but that the farming and ranching are part of my heritage - its in my blood. As much as I am now removed from that arduous industry, I hope to never forget my experiences and my heritage in it. So, when I discovered that the website is actually an extension of the The Bert Sheppard Stockmen's Foundation Library And Archives I became quite excited about travelling to Cochrane to look at some of their artifacts and archives. I think its wonderful that such an association and library exists. Alberta was built on ranching and oil, & the traditional ranching way of life is the base for the Calgary Stampede (regardless of the financial support of the local oil companies). Its a little far for me to drive these days, so all you locals can go without me (& we'll go together later). Their directions are
The Bert Sheppard Stockmen's Foundation Library And Archives is located in the Cochrane RancheHouse, 1/2 km north of Cochrane, Alberta on Highway 22. The Library is open from 9:00 am to 12:00 noon and from 1:00 pm to 4:00 pm Monday through Friday.

item.title: 14 Days a Week
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: In French, there are two ways to refer to the amount of time we, in English, refer to as a week. First is the straightforward "une semaine" or "one week." However, in conversation it is more common for people to refer to a week as "huit jours" or "eight days." Now if you count the days, from say Wednesday until and including the next Wednesday, you will count eight days. I don't know if this is the logical origin, but if someone, on a Friday, says they'll see you in "huit jours," show up at the specified time on Friday, not Saturday. Similarly, "quinze jours" is equivalent to two weeks (or a fortnight), and not the two-weeks-plus-one-day that you may expect. Lauryn, however, has her own non-French, non-"English" way of counting days. She eats breakfast 14 times a week, and never has dinner/supper. Each one of our days is, in Lauryn's world, comprised of breakfast, lunch, nap, breakfast and another (long) nap. Consequently it has been very challenging to teach her the concept of "days of the week." However, while she knows that once it gets dark at night its time to go to bed, she doesn't fight the afternoon nap despite the fact that its not dark. No complaints here.

item.title: Little Baker
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
As I type this, Lauryn is receiving additional instruction from Madge on the proper procedure for cracking, opening, and pouring eggs. Lauryn's been cracking and emptying eggs for several months now with varied success and usually she does a good job.
Today they're making some sort of a fruit pie with a custard filling I think. Madge read off the recipe, "We need three eggs." Lauryn responded, "I could crack two, and you could crack one."
I swear, other than regular counting I haven't done any addition, subtraciton, or multiplication lessons with her. Perhaps I should.

item.title: Empowered by Open Source and Clear Documentation
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
At work, I'm working (go figure...) on some circuitry that connects to a common laptop interface – the CardBus PC Card slot. A large portion of the connection is outside of my control, but I'm responsible to make sure that this connection is as flawless as possible. Our competitors have connection issues that we don't want to repeat. As such, I've spent considerable time delving into the inner details of the interface, and how operating systems (Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux) interact with and configure these components. I have poured over the Microsoft site trying to understand if/how I can manipulate some settings and verify my ideas. Unfortunately, despite having heard in the past about how "Microsoft's documentation is much better than Apple's", I have never found a concise guide to how the operating system (and developers) can interact with CardBus hardware, or how to write a device driver on the Microsoft sites. I have found tidbits that containing complex information making reference to concepts left unexplained and surprisingly devoid of links. The picture in my mind is far from clear and the amount of clarifying work seems insurmountable. So I started to look into the Linux code and documentation for the same devices and concepts. Unfortunately, my dual-boot Windows/Linux work laptop doesn't like to talk to the work email server under Linux, so I can't really spend all day booted into Linux, though its documentation seems a bit more friendly. My personal laptop, however, gives me the best of both worlds and more. I can access useful and detailed documentation that clearly explains the process for doing what I want to do, and I can send and receive email all day long without suffering any of the limitations that my Linux install gives me. The Apple documentation is strongly oriented towards bringing people into the Apple development community whereas all the Microsoft documentation that I've read makes huge assumptions about my existing understanding. If I should happen to google into an Apple document that's a little too coarse, it always contains a link to other higher-level documentation better suited to my situation. I feel that this is (yet another) example of the ideological difference between Apple and Microsoft. Both companies are interested, at the lowest level, in making money, but the way they cater to their users, and in this case developers, is completely different. Looking at this solely from the software development point of view, Microsoft assumes you've been part of "their team" for years – that you've taken their training courses and have an intimate knowledge of the old and new styles of working with Windows. Obscure references to undefined acronyms and concepts is commonplace. Links to pages that seem to have no relation to the subject at hand are all that exist, and there's no sight of a "how-to" or self-explanatory morsel of sample code in sight. The windows source code is closed, and its as though they don't want to give anyone but their paying developers any insight for free (ie. they want you to pay to get your questions answered and your hand held through the process). Apple, however, has the core of Mac OS X (and many other software pieces) available for anyone to browse and learn from. This Open Source policy is great for someone like me in a situation like me. I'm independent and willing to inform myself if the materials are available. If I want to see how Mac OS X initializes and configures CardBus devices, I can simply read the Darwin code. If I'm curious about some function I see used in some sample code, I can read exactly how its defined and implemented. And, as I said earlier, the Apple documentation is oriented completely towards bringing new developers on board (from either the ground up or from other platforms). It was trivial to find a sample driver for what I'm interested in, and its completely free for me to download the Mac development tools. All I invest is my time, and its not a frustrating learning process. This quote, from the Getting Started With Darwin page, sums up Apple's stance succinctly.
The Darwin layers of Mac OS X are open source. This serves two main purposes: to provide a resource for other open source development efforts (such as Linux and BSD variants) to make their software available on Mac hardware and to provide source code to aid developers writing device drivers and other low-level technologies for Mac OS X.
Find me a "Getting Started with Windows XP Development" page on microsoft.com or other information that provides this same opportunity, and I'll print and eat these very words.
item.excerpt:encoded: At work I'm working (go figure...)

item.title: PBXRemoteClient.framework
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: I ran into a Trial Version of Apple's WebObjects on their Apple Developer Connection site. Its good for 30 days and if I work at it I could seriously evaluate the possibility of using WO for an idea I have. Unfortunately, after installing the demo, none of the WO developer applications would launch. The WebObjects Getting Started page said that the trial was for Mac OS X 10.2.2, but the installer key I received says its good until October 1, 2004. Panther (OS X 10.3) is the latest version of the operating system, so I figured it should be forwards compatible, but it isn't. A quick peek at the system.log using the Console program in /Applications/Utilities showed that /Developer/Applications/EOModeler.app/Contents/MacOS/EOModeler can't open library: /System/Library/PrivateFrameworks/PBXRemoteClient.framework/Versions/A/PBXRemoteClient (No such file or directory, errno = 2) A quick search for PBXRemoteClient.framework lead to this page describing How to enable support for the old PB.project of WO 5.2.2 under Panther with Xcode It turns out that the framework being sought has been updated and renamed. Using a symbolic link (like an alias or shortcut) to create an old framework that is pointing to the new framework is sufficient (thusfar) for enabling WO 5.2 under Mac OS X 10.3.4 Panther.
item.excerpt:encoded: I ran into a Trial Version of Apple's WebObjects on their Apple Developer Connection site.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ok, so it turns out that to get WO to work under Panther all I really needed to to was to update it to 5.2.2 from 5.2.
Voila!

item.title: Old Content
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: This morning I spent a few minutes moving my old weblog posts into this one by hand. It didn't take too long and now they are all accessible via the monthly archives on the main page. Anything older than November 2003 is old content that is new as of today. Because of the poor quality of blogging software available at the time, making regular posts was too arduous and I only kept up the practice for a short stint. Two months in my first stint, and one month on my second attempt. Its a notable coincidence that my first entry every was July 15, 2002 and the first entry for my second stint was July 14, 2003. There must be something about Madge's birthday (July 14) that causes me to want to express myself in writing. This stint has been much longer (November 2003 to present) and I'll totally attribute this to the ease of posting and maintaining a site using my current combination of MovableType and ecto. I do think however, that I'm going to give WordPress a test run in the near future and if it works nicely I'll move the whole site over from MT (as I'm not going to upgrade to 3.0). Of note, the previous blogging package I used include Radio Userland (which I only used for one day and I totally didn't understand why I would want to post to a common site. It was a bad experience), Blosxom (which converted simple .txt files into html using a browse-time .cgi. It was ok but not very scalable or fun after the first, well, two months), and iBlog (which dumbed down the experience too much, had a wacky interface, hid the posts under crazy urls and just felt too micky-mouse-ish. Its features didn't work and it was incredibly rough). MovableType has been good for me thusfar, but its always nice to improve as well.

item.title: LiveStrong
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
I love the Tour de France. I think its an amazing example of endurance, teamwork, technology, competition and strategy. Mainstream sport (Basketball, Baseball, Football) have a collection of plays and minimal plans, but usually the only time during a game that these can be seen as valuable is during the closing minutes of a close and important game. Cycling can have its critical moment at any time during the race. If you stretch this race over 24 days, and each day has between 2 and 6 hours of riding, that's a lot of exciting moments for 200 riders on narrow, traffic-circled, people-lined roads. Flat tires, crashes, mountain climbs, sprints, time-trials, rain, drunken spectators on critical stages, and scorching heat. Yes, there's no tackling, punching, chair-throwing, mound-charging, helmet-throwing action, but the strategy, multiple jerseys to be won, and constant potential for upset is just what I crave. This year was Lance's chance to win six Tours in six years, and to become the first man to do that. I think he's a great rider and a great strategist and he's helped form and mold his team into an almost perfect engine for propelling him to the win. Other riders are great as well. Last year it was Vinokourov and Beloki that provided excitement. Ullrich was good to watch as well, winning second only 61 seconds behind Armstrong. This year it was Tyler Hamilton (and his early exit), Andréas Kloden, Ivan Basso, and young Thomas Voeckler. The Basques from Euskaltel - Euskadi didn't provide any excitement on the mountain stages, but a small yellow wristband was all the rage on and off the race-course. 14 out of 20 stage winners wore them and, as of the day after the Tour finished, eight million other people around the world. The day after Lance won the Alp d'Huez time-trial, I remembered to order a couple from the Lance Armstrong Foundation.
They only sell them in packs of 10, 100 or 1000, so I ignored the "backordered" status and ordered 10. Yesterday they arrived. The website still says they are backordered, but evidently they're shipping them as soon as they receive more. And as this yellow emblem can be seen regularly on TV (John Kerry), and around town here in San Diego, they must still be a very hot item. I think this is a pretty neat trend that I'm glad to be a part of, however. The proceeds from each $1 wristband go to the Lance Armstrong Foundation to support young people diagnosed with cancer through education, advocacy, public health and research. The goal of the WearYellow campaign was $5 million dollars. If 8 million people were wearing them three weeks ago, that number has probably doubled by now. Its amazing to think that a simple band of Made-in-China silicone could become so popular – that giving to charity could become so fashionable and highly recognizable. Who's wearing yellow near you?

item.title: San Diego Zoo
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Many people have told us how amazing the San Diego Zoo is and how its one of those things you just have to visit when you come down here. Thursday we went with Dama and Tapa to check out this famous zoo. Madge and Lauryn and I got year-long memberships that gave us two free passes. We used these passes on Dama and Tapa, and entered the zoo with no idea where to go. We also received a two 2-for-1 discounts on the bus-tour of the zoo. It is such a large zoo that to see the entire zoo in one visit would be nearly impossible. (At least, if you wanted to really see things and not just run past them all.) We forked over a few more bucks and took at 35 minute bus ride through the park. It generally gave use a sense of what animals were found where, and what parts we'd want to visit on foot. The tour was good. The section of the zoo dealing with hoofed animals was quite packed with nice displays of endangered and extinct-in-the-wild animals.

Click the elephant for more Zoo pictures
The tour finished by the elephants, rhinos, and pygmy hippo, close to a café and right at lunch time. The marine layer had lasted for an unusually long time that day, keeping us shaded and cool until just when we finished eating. Sophia was hungry, so we checked out snakes and tortoises while she ate. A huge albino python (white and yellow), a copper-head rattle snake, and a cobra were some of my favorites. The snake exhibit, right next to the Children's Zoo was horribly crowded and I was always unsure as to whether Lauryn really could see the snakes or if she just wanted to look through the next window. For all the trouble it was to get her a good view, it was hard when she'd just lean over (in my arms) and try to see the next one. Back together we wandered past the apes, skipped the crowded gorillas, and walked down an amazing hillside full of exhibits and authentic foliage. One thing that definitely makes the San Diego Zoo special (and probably quite unique) is that the natural landscape and climate (when you add lots of water) allows you to recreate tropical forests, grow bamboo, and have beautiful outdoor exhibits that should be comfortable for the animals and that are a pleasure for people to see. The exhibits are often built so that cages and metal fences either aren't visible or needed. Seeing the beautiful tiger on his sloped, lush, grassed habitat was a real treat. After the hippo, the heat and fatigue set in and we made our way back to the entrance. Lauryn must have enjoyed herself, as she promptly fell asleep, her head lolling in her carseat. We'll have to go back to see the Pandas and Polar Bears. Photos from our adventure can be seen here.
item.excerpt:encoded: The snake exhibit, right next to the Children's Zoo was horribly crowded and I was always unsure as to whether Lauryn really could see the snakes or if she just wanted to look through the next window.... One thing that definitely makes the San Diego Zoo special (and probably quite unique) is that the natural landscape and climate (when you add lots of water) allows you to recreate tropical forests, grow bamboo, and have beautiful outdoor exhibits that should be comfortable for the animals and that are a pleasure for people to see.

item.title: Optimization
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: I'm very much a proponent of optimization. This isn't to say that I do everything in the most optimal fashion, but mundane tasks that I find inefficient or backwards really drive me bonkers. In such a situation, my mind has a tendency to focus on this inefficiency until I can propose a proper solution (or until I find one). I'm sure it drives Madge crazy at times because I can suddenly get refocused on something that isn't relevant to the important tasks at hand, but that I have an almost uncontrollable desire to fix. If I'm unable to remedy the situation, I'll usually avoid the inefficiency until I have time and can dedicate some time and make it right. Up until a few days ago I didn't have what I thought was a proper method of posting galleries of pictures. Weblog software (MoveableType and ecto) have allowed me to easily write my thoughts and events, and include single images in posts, but to shoot a digital roll of pictures and post them quickly and easily, in a page format that I can specify and tweak/customize effectively has been out of my reach. iPhoto is a very good tool for capturing, organizing, viewing and performing basic editing on photos. However, outputting a roll of images onto web pages limits you to its hard-coded styles, organization and structure. To customize the look of the output I would have to edit every page by had. Computers are tools, but only if you can harness that power. There is no reason that I should have to make the same changes to each page every time I want to post pictures (and still be limited). Someone else evidently felt the same, and came up with an iPhoto Export plugin, BetterHTMLExport, which allows you to specify a template for the thumbnails and for each image page. I grabbed a decent template and then set to customizing it. My biggest addition was to take the javascript that Ryan uses to create a slide show effect, and add it to the template. The SeaWorld pictures and Zoo pictures both used this template. You can lazily browse all the pictures in each set by clicking on the first thumbnail picture and then clicking on "Start Slide Show". Sit back and the images will switch every six seconds, but you can speed up, slow down, or pause/resume the slideshow as well. I'll still probably make some changes to the template, but for now its an acceptable solution. If you want the template that I'm using, just leave a comment (with valid email address) and I'll contact you.
item.excerpt:encoded: This isn't to say that I do everything in the most optimal fashion, but mundane tasks that I find inefficient or backwards really drive me bonkers. In such a situation, my mind has a tendency to focus on this inefficiency until I can propose a proper solution (or until I find one).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Tamara bought BetterHTMLExport for iPhoto and uses it for her galleries. She too was frustrated with the default iPhoto export. She seems to like it.
Thanks for the great post on your blog, it actually gives me an insight on this subject
Good post! I have a random question for you. How do you get your weblog indexed by bing? I've a related internet weblog.

item.title: Hot Desert and Comfy Beach
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Lauryn and I went for a walk on Friday. Right next to our apartment is the beginnings of a long valley. She and I enjoy strolling down the dusty path, throwing rocks and asking each other questions about what we see. Sometimes we climb up the steep side of the valley to the community playground. This time, we just kept walking. Mostly we didn't see anything but airplanes, helicopters, a butterfly, growing bamboo, and last of all, a cute little lizard. We had been watching for lizards, but the sweltering heat of the valley must be too much for even lizards, as we found this little fellow in the shade of the bushes growing in the runoff of the sprinkler system above the valley. I quickly halted Lauryn and pointed toward this small shape that mostly looked like a funny rock or stick.

Little Lizard
She did spot him and I faced a barrage of questions as I quickly tried to zoom in a take a picture of him. I'm very glad that our digital camera (Canon S1IS) has a 10X optical zoom, as in combination with some additional digital zoom, I was able to get a reasonably clean picture. He scurried off into the brush as we turned and headed back up the valley, turning off and climbing the steep valley wall to the playground. Lauryn played on the swings as I took a few photos of the nearby flowers. After lots of swinging, I convinced her that it would be OK to go look for a cactus that I saw on my epic bike ride. I marched off through the brush in a different direction with her on my shoulders. Soon we were back in the blazing sun, surrounded by tinder-dry bushes. A few steps more and I found a cute cactus, seemingly growing straight out of the rock. After a few pictures for my memory, it was time to head back home for lunch. Lauryn had enjoyed reaching down and grabbing the drinking tube for the water-bladder in my backpack, but I was getting hungry. After lunch and naps, we decided that this would be a good day to go to the beach at Del Mar. The six of us piled into the Grey Grandma again and we drove out through the Torrey Pine State Park, through the quaint center of Del Mar and managed to find a spot to park a block from the beach. We marched off to the sand, the marine layer in the sky and sea breeze in our faces. I suspected that it was too late in the day and that the water would be too cold for Lauryn and I to enjoy.

Lauryn and Daddy
Quickly we prepared ourselves and headed for the surf. I wanted Lauryn to feel comfortable in the water, but she was a little anxious so I held her and kept her from getting soaked. Surprisingly, the water was quite nice, but the action of the waves was a bit scary for my little girl. I'd dip her feet and waist in the water after every wave and she enjoyed it for a while, but, too soon for my wishes, she wanted to head back to the sand and be with Mommy. She was quite content thereafter to sit, playing in the sand and watching the surf, people and birds. Fortunately this was then my opportunity to enjoy the ocean. Lauyrn and I have played with our Boogie Board in the pool many a time, but it had not yet been used in the Pacific. I hurriedly grabbed it and ran off into the surf, excited at the prospect of being able to experience the free-flowing movement that body-boarding, surfing, snow-boarding, and water-skiing allow. Quickly I realized that I had completely forgotten, since the last time I played in the Ocean when Madge and I went to France, how the sea was incredibly salty and how the waves truly never cease. Very soon I managed to catch a couple of small waves and was quite enthralled with the experience. My only complaint was that I had not put in my contact lenses, didn't want to risk losing my glasses, and could then only enjoy the activity from my myopic point of view. My family on the beach was nothing more than coloured, expressionless pillars. Still it was fun. But, until either someone else visits and can ease some of the struggle that taking a newborn to the beach entails, or we build up our courage and try to do it on our own, I'll have to ignore our proximity to such merriment and remain satisfied just enjoying the wonderful weather and my beautiful, giggly girls and wife. Pictures of our day can be seen by clicking on one of the above thumbnails, or by clicking here.
item.excerpt:encoded: Lauryn and I went for a walk on Friday.

item.title: Duh Olympics
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: I'm pretty bummed out about the NBC Olympics coverage. Day after day we turn on the coverage and I'm completely convinced that there are only three events in the Olympics – Swimming, Gymnastics and the National Anthem. The coverage is too disproportionate for my tastes, and I definitely like to see more than 3 minutes of cycling, rowing, judo or boxing for every 10 minutes they spend showing the flag raising and national anthem four times a night. I don't care if I only see US athletes, I just want to see more than an obligatory morsel of sport to justify playing that song, in its entirety, again. Tonight, instead of even turning on the TV, I'm going to bed. Even home grown Americans feel as I do.
item.excerpt:encoded: I'm pretty bummed out about the NBC Olympics coverage.

item.title: Glen's Canadian Olympic Team Thoughts
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Ryan's brother Glen made a fairly large post the other day that I quite enjoyed. Glen's site is fantastic but he doesn't (yet) have any archives so once he changes his page anything he's written is lost. So I'm just going to quote his entire post here for archival purposes.
Aug 22/04: [snip] Olympic Thought: Well now on to the Olympics. I hate to say it but I have been very disappointed in our Canadian team. One week of competition and only four medals. For the size of the team we have sent that's not very good. I was thinking this was going to be our break-out year with well over 20 medals. It looks like I am wrong. Amateur sport in Canada needs a real shake down. In their interviews, all the athletes are saying. “I gave it all I had but it didn't work for me [this day].” The ones who where going to be our big guns have all chocked. It's like they can't deal with the pressure. Now don't get me wrong - to make it to the Olympics is unbelievable. You must be an extraordinary athlete just to qualify. I just think that with the size of team we sent we should be doing 'way better in the medal count. I talked to my friends Sukhpaul, Rossco and BJ about this and we have come to the same conclusions. Sukh believes that we need to build more training centers for our athletes. Every major city should have some sort of major sports complex with all the bells and whistles. I am with him on this. Not only would these state of the art training centers give our up-and-coming athletes a chance to train in the best sports complexes in the world, it would also get many of your top athletes together to train and compete with the very best. There are a few spin off to all of this. First, it would give the youth in the country the chance to watch their idols train. This could keep them more interested in their sports instead of more interested in their video games. Second, if we have the best training facilities in the world then we will attract athletes from other countries to come and train right here in Canada . Many times when the CBS is introducing the athletes on the starting line, they say this guy is from Poland but trains in the US or this guy is from Croatia and trains in the US . Well, if we had state of the art facilities we might get more athletes from abroad coming to Canada to train. If athletes from all over the globe come to Canada to train then it will push our athletes to be even better. A great example of a major sports complex is in Calgary . Since the '88 Olympics, Calgary has been turning out some very good athletes who wouldn't have been as good if it wasn't for the facilities they have there. The second problem is we need better coaching. I think BJ came up with this as well. The coaching at the top level in Canada is great. The problem is with our youth development system. Now over the years, I have seen this problem, on a small scale with the Central Okanagan Youth Soccer Association. For those of you who don't know how soccer works in the in the Central Okanagan , here it is in a nut shell. At the top we have the select program, from which teams compete for top honors in the province every year. Then the system works its way down to gold and then silver. What the Central Okanagan Youth Soccer Association has done is they have hired a head coach (Andrew Letham) for the whole system. He goes around to all the teams' different practices and runs them for a night. So what you have is one head coach for all of the central Okanagan (that's like 10,000 kids) going around and running one or maybe two team's practices every night. So Andrew runs about 5-10 practices a week. Then, after he runs a practice he won't see the kids for at least a month, and maybe not even for the rest of the season. This to me is not very efficient. With 10,000 kids in the system and Andrew moving through one or maybe two practices a night, he is seeing about 35 kids a day who he might not see again for the rest of the season. Well what are these kids going to learn from this guy once a year? If you want the kids to learn team play and positioning then they would need him to show up every night. It takes a team many years of training to get these concepts down. The second thing is that after this guy comes in with his British accent and fancy drills, the kids then lose some respect for their real coach. So after Andrew leaves, the kids think they have seen the good times and won't be as responsive to the real coach. This is not good. Well I have had an idea for a few years. When I coached in the Central Okanagan Select program, I suggested it to the people who ran the show, but nothing ever came of it. I know from experience, both as a player and coach, that having Andrew coming into practices once a year, it is almost more destructive than positive. What he needs to do is classroom sessions with the coaches. In the classroom, he can show the coaches everything from strategy and positioning, to conditioning and healthy eating. He could use power point video and white boards to teach these parents-turned-coaches how to coach. All you would need to do is group the different coaches together for these class room sessions. Say Mondays is Select coaches from U-15 up then Tuesday is gold coaches from U-15 up etc etc. This way you could group the different levels of teams together and have different level classroom sessions for each. Then the coaches can bring up different game scenarios and as a group they would be able to come up with solutions to the problems that might arise. With this, Andrew would be able to get involved with every team's practice without even going to the field. So, instead of working with 35 kids a night he can work with much bigger groups. Now what does this all have to do with the Olympics? Well let me tell you. It shows how the youth of Canada aren't getting the best possible coaching they could get. For the most part, the youth coaches out there, are parents who don't really know enough about the sports their kids are playing. If you could educate these parents we would be able to bring better athletes through the different systems across Canada . First off if you have better coaches then they will give a higher knowledge level to our younger athletes. If our young athletes know more about their sport, they will be 'way better off in the long run. The most successful youth teams have a very dedicated and energetic coach who has a thorough knowledge of the sport he or she is teaching to the kids. With this knowledge and energy the kids maintain and high level of interest. With more kids staying in sports comes more competition. With more competition, kids will push themselves more. If they get pushed more they will not only excel to a higher level but will also be able to deal with the pressure of getting pushed or the pressure of a major event. This can only help them in the long run. This is why we need better coaching for the youth of Canada . The last major problem we came up with is the need for more awareness of all Olympic sports. Now I ask you - How often do you watch swimming, track, rowing, or amateur boxing ? Well, if you are anything like me your answer would be every four years at the Olympics and maybe a bit during the Pan Am or Commonwealth Games. My second question is this. When are these sports even on TV? The answer is Sports Sunday on the CBC. That's every Sunday afternoon. Now who wants to be watching TV on a Sunday afternoon? Well not me that's for sure. Ok last question. When do you even watch the CBC? Well, for me it is every Saturday night in the winter for Hockey Night in Canada . Then maybe once a year for a Sunday night movie. So instead of playing those stupid sitcoms about a retired cop in the Arctic , they should show some sports on prime time TV. That's right - show some amateur sports during the evening mid week. I know I would watch. It's not like anybody watches those dumb shows about a farmer from Saskatchewan who moves to Toronto anyway. It would probably be a lot cheaper to send a few announcers and a camera to an event somewhere than pay for a crew to make a sitcom that nobody watches. With the CBC there is a section of their web page that is ask CBC. You can go there and ask them about their programming and make comments on it. So I urge you to go there and tell them to air more sports in better time slots. Here is the link you can go to www.cbc.ca/askcbc/ Now the second thing is, we have 2 major sports networks in Canada. One is TSN the other is Sportsnet. These stations are "Sports Networks." To their credit, they do show lots of pro sports like hockey and baseball. But where are the amateur sports? I have never ever seen track, rowing, gymnastics, amateur boxing, or swimming on these networks. You get more WWF and dog shows on TSN. Or "You Gotta See This", and Fishing with Shelley & Courtney on Sportsnet. Are these shows even sports? How is a dog show a sport? Or how is some drunk hick who rolled his 4x4 and miraculously survived, a sport? Not only are these things not sports, these networks are showing them. Even the web pages for these Sports networks have nothing on amateur sports. They have all the professional leagues but nothing on amateur sports. For example it took me 30 min of searching the web to try to find out how Malindi ran in Zurich and London . So awareness in Canada is nonexistent and you have the major TV networks to blame for that one. If you would show these sports when people are actually at home watching TV then maybe we would know a lot more about them. People need to realize how much an athlete with Canadian colours can bring together a country. Whenever I watch a Canadian athlete wearing the Canadian colours, I get all excited and start to cheer them on. The pride and nationalism felt by Canadians when Canada wins a sporting event, is huge. Like today when Kyle Shewfelt won gold for the men's floor exercise in artistic gymnastics I was like “Yeah Canada !” Then, when they played “O Canada,” I got goose bumps and was very proud to be Canadian. I had never even heard of this guy when I woke up this morning. But now I am like he is the man and Canada is the country . Look at the past and how the morale of Canada elevated a few notches after we beat the Americans for gold in Olympic hockey. In Kelowna it was mid Feb and people where all painted up running around the streets like chickens with their heads cut off. You couldn't even drive through the downtown streets and that's in Kelowna ! That was two years ago and people still talk about it. People still talk about '72. When ever I hear the words, "There's a shot - Henderson takes a wild stab at it. There another shot - Henderson scores!" I get goose bumps and I wasn't even alive. But I am like yeah Canada is the Best. So, all I hope is that after the Olympics, Sport Canada takes a long hard look at the problems we are facing and fixes them at the roots instead of putting a bandage on a gushing wound. If anyone has anything else to say on this please email me and I will put up your views up on the web page next week. Feel free to criticize my thoughts or add to them. Just send me an email glen_biffard@yahoo.ca Also I urge you again to go to www.cbc.ca/askcbc/ and tell them your thoughts on the CBCs programming.
item.excerpt:encoded: Not only would these state of the art training centers give our up-and-coming athletes a chance to train in the best sports complexes in the world, it would also get many of your top athletes together to train and compete with the very best.... So what you have is one head coach for all of the central Okanagan (that's like 10,000 kids) going around and running one or maybe two team's practices every night.

item.title: Overvalued
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
A townhouse across the street from us is for sale. I'll list the specs, and you guess the price.
  • Bedrooms: 3
  • Baths: 2.5
  • Est. Sq. Ft.: 1264
  • Stories: 2
  • Garage: 2 car, attached
  • Pool: Community
  • Jacuzzi: Community
  • Rec. Room: Community
  • Tennis Courts: Community
  • Heat: Radiant (Ceiling)
  • Cooling: Room A/C in Living Rm. & Mstr. BR
  • Patio: Enclosed
  • Deck: Off Mstr. BR (over Garage)
  • Recent Upgrades (past 2 years)
    • Dishwasher, Disposal, Microwave, Range/Oven
    • Carpet
    • Kitchen Cabinets
    • Tile Floors
    • Granite Countertops
This 30 year old townhome, complete with recent termite fumigation, can be yours (or ours I suppose) for the amazing low price of only $519,000 USD What an incredible steal of a deal! Oh, but I forgot that on top of the mortgage payments every month for the next 30 years, there's an additional $250/month Home Owners Association fee to cover the Common Area Maintenance, Exterior Building Maintenance, Insurance, Sewer, Trash Pickup, and Water. Over the course of 30 years, at the static price of $250/month, that's $90,000 USD So, using these figures, the present value of the dollar, and ignoring leap years, that's $55.62 USD/day. I've stayed in a motel in Nevada and a Hotel in France for less than that a night. However, the interest of a mortgage usually costs at least as much as the principle, so that doubles the daily cost to ~$110 USD/day for the next 30 years. For 1200 square feet, a 15' x 12', concrete patio, and a rather small 2 car garage? Nah, not for me. If I really loved debt that much, I'd buy a similarly priced monstrous house in a high end part of Calgary and get a much better value for my dollar.
item.excerpt:encoded: A townhouse across the street from us is for sale. I'll list the specs, and you guess the price.

item.title: Tired of Being Exhausted
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Its been a busy two or three weeks, and I'm a bit worn out. Many things have I had to say, and longed to express, but nary a moment existed for me to inscribe them. Work, though enjoyable and satisfying, has been ceaselessly hectic. Its crunch time, with people required to work over the previous two weekends to meet the deadlines. This next weekend we will be voyaging to the Switzerland of the Americas™ and from there I shall be semi-circumnavigating the world to spend two weeks in China. I don't expect to enjoy the pleasures of visiting foreign lands, as I'm prescribed to support manufacturing efforts, meaning I may not see the sun and scarcely my pillow. I gain peace through expression, and have many thoughts and ideas bottled up. The rigours of two children, despite the much improved situation of Madge and Sophia (thankfully), and a demanding work schedule, have left me ill-at-ease. Hopefully I can dedicate the time necessary to resolve the disparity between thought and expression. Children are a sacrifice, in ways I simply never imagined. Two children cause sacrifices that can be avoided with but one. Small things like showers, eating, shaving, cleaning, laundry and sleeping go by the wayside, let alone time for expression, creativity, planning, and recovering from the asperity of the day. Yet still they are wonderful and darling, smart and cuddly, needing and grateful. Many things could I spend my time on, but they deserve my time and I'm usually glad to devote it. It seems a rule in life that nothing good comes without hard work, sacrifice, and devotion. I shall follow this then, with faith that the results merit the effort and more.
item.excerpt:encoded: Its been a busy two or three weeks.
