Virtually all feelings along with ideology aside, I do think it has the possibility to be your better works, would possibly you retain creating this sort of superior within your long term producing.

item.title: My Hummer
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
The other day as I made my walk home from work, a fluttering green rock caught my eye from a spot where my foot was about to go. I quickly halted and with disbelief recognized this shimmer of green to be an injured hummingbird. One wing failed to flutter like its mate, and my stomach sank as I realized this beautiful creature was in a very vulnerable and probably fatal position. I curiously looked up for the cause of the injury and found the beautifully mirrored windows of the fancy pharmaceutical company staring ominously back at me. I did not want to touch this little hummer, lest my smell and presence cause more grief, yet I couldn't leave it helplessly fluttering. I searched my bag for a suitable scooping device, and ended up using an enveloped CD to carefully lift this tiny body from its concrete doom. At first I thought perhaps I could place it near some flowers, where it could eat a bit and wait for me to inform myself at home and return. This wouldn't have worked at all, I decided, and I carefully headed home, porting this thumb-sized body on a polycarbonate platter. As I made the rest of the 5 minute journey home, I was amazed at the calmness of my long-beaked friend. It did not stir or try to flee. I'd like to think that it could sense my compassion, but I'm certain it was quite exhausted and weary unto death. Ignoring Madge's quizzical looks as I entered our apartment, I headed for the patio and a suitable container for my famished cargo. Placing it in a clear aquarium-like box, I googled for the sugar-water recipe with which I could hopefully nourish this poor Anna's Hummingbird. Project Wildlife has a page devoted to helping people who have found hummingbirds. Amazingly this top search hit is also located in San Diego, not far from Old Town and Sea World. I quickly mixed the 1 part sugar to 4 parts water "nectar" and claimed Sophia's 1-milliliter liquid syringe as a feeding apparatus. Filling it 0.7 mL full, I quietly took Lauryn with me outside in the hopes of helping my little bird. It did not even startle as I brought my hand close and placed the tip of the syringe around its slender beak.

Feeding my Hummer
At first it did nothing, but as I removed the syringe, the tiny mouth opened and a tongue made furtive licks. Soon after enveloping half the beak a second time, I noticed a tiny flutter inside the syringe as the hummer's tongue quickly slurped the energy-rich drink. Hummingbirds must feed very often to keep their fast metabolisms running (every 30 minutes I believe - except at night). I hoped that the window-strike had not happened long before my arrival on the scene, but I was excited that my attempts to assist and feed were finding success. About 0.5 mL of sugar-water were consumed in that session. Every half hour thereafter until around 10:00 I continued to offer more nourishment. Madge called the Project Wildlife hotline and learned a few more hints, and what we should do if the fragile life should make it through the night. We didn't want it to get cold, so we brought it inside, and around midnight I tried to feed it again but was mostly refused. At 6:00 I was awoken by Sophia, so I used those moments of awakedness to offer a morning drink. It was still a rather sleepy bird I guess, as at first it didn't respond to the syringe, but moments later it fluttered to life, startling me and then commenced to drink close to another half a mL. The Project Wildlife shelter didn't open until 9:00, so I stayed home from work, helped to get Lauryn ready to go with me, and then drove down and dropped off my Hummer after our rather short "test drive." Lauryn thought the tiny bird was "so cute," and hoped that it would "feel better and get bigger." She was also a bit sad that we wouldn't be returning later to pick up "our" healthy bird. She wanted to keep taking care of it, but we've had our hands full enough with Sophia without having to feed a cute bird like this every half hour. I gave a $5 donation to the wildlife rescue organization, sufficient to buy food for close to a dozen hummingbirds I think, and we made our way home. We've seen these beautiful creatures flitting by from time to time, and it was a rare treat to see one up close. Rarer still was the chance to help and hopefully save such a tiny, shimmering green body and gossamer wings. I doubt we'll get a "status update" from the busy volunteers, but I'm glad that such a society exists to help something as seemingly insignificant as a hummingbird. Its fairly easy to get wrapped up in the duties and cares of our material world, and I'm grateful to have been raised with enough caring sensitivity to do all I could to assist the best kind of Hummer.
item.excerpt:encoded: One wing failed to flutter as its mate, and quickly my stomach sank as I recognized this beautiful creature as being in a very vulnerable and probably fatal position.... Soon after enveloping half the beak a second time, I noticed a tiny flutter inside the syringe as the hummer's tongue quickly slurped the energy-rich drink.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Good on ya Skip. Hope it makes it.
anecdotes like this seem to stem the malaise...cheers

item.title: Off to Asia
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
So this morning I have the fortune of flying for who knows how many hours (14? 18?) to Hong Kong for work. I'll try to post some of my adventures here but I don't know
  1. what time I'll have available - usually on trips like these I work 16 hour days
  2. what internet access is available and where
  3. what websites China filters and if I'll even have access to my own site
Luckily, however, we were able to go out into the cold yesterday and take our traditional fall family pictures with Ryan. It was just above freezing, fairly humid, and windy, and the kids got cold pretty quickly.

My Plane to Vancouver
Ryan snapped off 90 pictures in just a few minutes and I'm pretty sure we got at least a couple of good ones. I'm not ready to post any at this minute though, as I'm currently awaiting my flight to Vancouver. Luckily the YYC airport has free Telus WiFi at the moment. I wish/hope it would stay free forever, but naturally they'll want to hook travelers like me with a "the first hit is free" scenario and then charge a lutt-boad (spoonerism) once they have enough addicts. Well, my plane just pulled up, so I'd better grab some spare food from Tim Horton's and walk around while I have the chance. I'm definitely going to miss Madge and my two cute girls. Lauryn is pretty sad that I've been gone. In San Diego when I leave for work she always says, "But I dust wanted you to stay." And that's just when I'm gone during the day and come home at lunch. Now I've been with her non-stop for a week and I'll be gone cold turkey. At least Dama and Tapa will be with her yots while I'm away. A plus, tout le monde!
item.excerpt:encoded: So this morning I have the fortune of flying for who knows how many hours (14?... to Hong Kong for work.

item.title: Don't Mix Flux and a Heat Gun with a Microscope in a Crowd
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Better Learning Through Experimentation So I've been in China for a week today and this is the FIRST opportunity I've had to write anything about my experience. I've had (and have) lots to say, but I'll not start at the beginning (unfortunately). I must share what's on my mind today before it escapes me. I work as an Electrical (Hardware) Engineer dealing with mostly digital circuitry, including CardBus (PCMCIA), and USB signaling, mixed with a touch of Power Supplies, Processors, and associated circuitry. University is great for teaching you the mathematical details of how/why stuff works and ways to optimize and improve things, but its very shy on non-programming, non-logical problem-solving training. That is, its great for teaching you how to reason through a problem or theory and find a solution, but doesn't bless you with good soldering skills. Now, some people come to University from Technical Schools (Colleges) and have actually taken courses that teach you the hows and why's of mixing solder, flux, heat, and PCBs (Printed Circuit Boards). But people who've only done the math-heavy (heavy-math?) Bachelors/Masters/Doctorate programs don't stand a chance when it comes to a 60/30 Sn/Pb (Tin/Lead) mix and how to work with it effectively. Luckily, I'm the son of a farmer. I grew up experimentally teaching myself how to do what I'd seen only others do. Soldering would be no different. I learned to use an Oxy-Acetylene torch by watching my brother melt rocks (turning the surface glassy) in the best vise I've ever seen. Only a few exploded, and I was never harmed as much as the time the woodstove blew up (which only melted my eyebrows and eyelashes – but that's another story...). Arc Welding was a skill I developed out of necessity, with my brother-like nephew Chad and I pooling our knowledge to figure out the basics. I was rather afraid the first time I even turned on the welder, and that fear quickly turned into frustration as I struggled to stop sticking the welding rod to my injured Go-Kart and create an arc instead. We also struggled with the MIG welder from time to time. So when I first worked for my current employer (this is the third time), I was rather intrigued by how all those little parts were stuffed onto such an intricate board. Oh, how much deeper I've now gone down into this rabbit hole. On my second stint, I was given opportunity to debug some of these rather complicated collections of fiberglass, copper, gold, and ceramic elements fused into function with solder and flux. Soon I had a part that needed replacing - the biggest part on the board. I decided, in keeping I suppose with my previous history, to try to do that which others around me were doing. I removed the part without too much fuss, but before a new part could be placed (which I'd let someone else do), the solder tailings needed to be removed. I didn't understand the incredible value of each board or the huge risk that was inherent in what I was trying to do before I started, but I was game to try. At this time, unfortunately, we only had 13 of these early prototype boards, and only three worked even minimally. That number quickly dropped to 12 when, in my ignorance, I left the vital flux out of the equation, and tore one of the signal pads off the PCB. New to the job, and lacking prior experience, I was ashamed to have so badly failed in my job of fixing boards. The graduates of the "lesser" technical schools are the gods of product development. The engineers can reason and understand the nuances of what's needs to be done, but the techs are the ones that make it happen. Without them, we'd be stuck playing with our models, schematics, and ideas. But that which I find intriguing is that which I wish to understand and master, and so I vowed to learn by experimentation and study by observation the skills and techniques of my solder-savvy coworkers so that I would never so recklessly "bone" a board again. I've spent a couple of years since that time endlessly trying to improve my skills, not to compete or replace my tech mentors, but to not be so dependent on them that I can't fix failing circuitry when they're not around to school me save my butt. Today I find myself in that very situation, and my hard earned skills have been heavily taxed. Jared and Satnam, things would have progressed much faster today if you'd have been around. But I'm far away in China, and I don't trust one of the locals to do the work the way I need it done. The language barrier, at its best, is just too great. I'm working on fixing part of the design that is completely new to me. I understand the system-level operation of this section of our design, but I'm not trained in the component or inner workings, yet the situation demands my time, and so once more I learn by experimentation. Additionally, the specific components I'm trying to make work aren't simple surface mount parts, they're rather delicate Bump Chip Carrier Packages whose proper connection is sensitive and integral to the proper operation of our product. My investigation involves removing and reseating some of these parts to determine the root cause of some failure's we're seeing. I've been nominated to be the one to attempt to do the work of my tech mentors. Its fairly important, and I've done the job before, but the exact scenario is new. Not only do I need to make the board work, but I must try to do so without using fresh parts, and be as methodical and precise in the order and details of the problem-solving routine as possible. Its an intense blend of engineering analysis, logical-proof, and technical skill. And its all done from behind a microscope using tools that almost all too imprecise for this meticulous work. At least I brought my own tweezers. I spent five consecutive hours looking through eyepieces, alternately wielding a heat gun, a soldering iron, Q-Tips, tweasers, a toothbrush from the hotel, isopropyl alcohol, solder, and flux in an attempt to produce perfect results. My actions somehow drew a crowd, and for the first two hours I had an ever changing group of up to 5 or 6 Chinese workers peering over my shoulders, watching my every move and tool swap. They chatted to each other in a language I can't understand about my actions and intentions most probably, but also, at times, the foreign colour of my hair, and well, I don't know what else. Regardless, I'm a somewhat self-conscious person when I'm doing such demanding and sensitive work at the best of times, let alone when I'm being crowded from behind and inundated with noisy jibber jabber. A stressful situation with the additional stress of foreign observation and discussion was taxing on both mind and body. I cannot yet trust my results, so I'll try to repeat the process tomorrow on a second board before making any conclusions. Hopefully I can be ignored by those around me, as I work faster when I'm "on my own" and in a groove. I also hope my efforts bear fruit (figuratively of course), the big unknown behind this problem is frustrating and I'm running out of time. Its intimidating to be in such a challenging and important situation, but its both what I've been trained (and employed) to do and I suppose what I'm skilled at doing, and I quite relish the opportunity to make a positive impact with my precise efforts. The potential reward of succeeding is what motivates me to do my very best – despite the 16 hour days. Still, I'm glad I only travel (and work) like this about once a year. I'll be happy to be home, where I can hold Lauryn and Sophia in my arms, and feel Madge's embrace once more.
item.excerpt:encoded: So I've been in China for a week today and this is the FIRST opportunity I've had to write anything about my experience. I've had (and have) lots to say, but I'll not start at the beginning, but share what's on my mind today.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: From the title of your post I was wondering if you got arrested for carrying dangerous goods. good to hear you are doing well and not in some prison somewhere.

To me it sounds like prison wouldn't be that far off from what you've experienced. . . . Hard Labor, manditory escorts, minimal free time and no release on your own recognizance, not to mention nightmarish bathroom experiences, stomach rumblings and exclaimations of gastric revolt, language barriers, scrutiny, fatigue, and the feeling of being torn away from every familiar place and routine.
There's no place like home There's no place like home O Toto!

item.title: Fall Photos in La Jolla
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
While we were able to take our traditional fall photos while we were in Calgary (which I haven't posted yet), this last Saturday we took a rather impromptu to the fancy part of La Jolla.

click the movie to see the photos
or here for a larger movie
Lauryn was able to get her toes sandy and Sophia cooperated very nicely. It was a nice relaxing afternoon – almost like being on vacation except it was only a 10 minute drive away. We ate outside some little sandwich shop and took turns looking at all the shops. It wasn't overly busy as we were able to find a parking spot on the street in front of the beach. We even saw a Mom and two kids riding Segway HTs. Its definitely a sign that things are going better when its Madge's idea to get out of the house and go do something adventuresome. I've gotten so used to it not even being a possibility that weekend outings haven't even been on my mind. Sophia is quite enjoying drinking formula from a bottle. In fact, Madge thinks that I feed her too much! Its really great to see her so happy, though. Definitely a different baby than when I went away to China. She's always been cute, but now she's a bit plumper, and so happy now that she doesn't really cry – she just sings and calls, even when she's hungry and just woke up. Today she's been chomping her gums and drooling more again, so perhaps the little white enamel will start poking through. The cheeks aren't burning red and her bottom isn't rashy yet, so it still might be a ways off. At least Lauryn is excited for her to have teeth. (It just means that she'll be able to feed her.) Click to check out our La Jolla photos.
item.excerpt:encoded: While we were able to take our traditional fall photos while we were in Calgary (which I haven't posted yet), this last Saturday we took a rather impromptu to the fancy part of La Jolla. Lauryn was able to get her toes sandy and Sophia cooperated very nicely.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Wow, I think that is the same beach I used to go to as a kid. My grandfather on my dad's side lived in La Jolla (just across the road from the beach, if you believe it), so we went down every two years or so.
Glad to see everyone looking so happy! Sophia sure is getting big and Lauryn is just as pretty as ever.

item.title: Yittow Yittow Babies
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded: Mommy: Won't it be fun when she can talk? I wonder what her first word will be... Lauryn: Maybe "Hi" Or maybe "I had fun bein' a baby" Mommy: She'll start crawling in a little while. Lauryn: Yeah, and I know two crawling songs. Mommy: Can you sing one for me? Lauryn: Nooooo! They're not for big people. Just for yittow yittow babies!!!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Perfect translation of Lauryn! I can picture it in my head. Miss you guys, Love Camila
i miss u. angie had a little girl so lauryn can sing her crawling songs to her. see ya later jamie

item.title: Back Again
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Unfortunately my employer has required me to once again come to Southeast China. I've not yet posted my comments from my first visit two months ago, but I'll say a few things now while I have the chance.

I'm just a bit too big for airplane seats. If I sit with my legs stretched out straight, my shins are forced into the back-bottom edge of the seat in front of me, and the front of my seat cuts into the tops of my legs (right beneath my butt) enough to make my butt and legs go numb. On a short flight I can handle it, but when the flight takes 15 hours, its awful. I also like isle seats as its always easy to jump up and stretch your long and numb legs, or, as I did on the way over here, jump up and head to the bathroom in the middle of some good turbulence.

No, I wasn't sick. I wanted to head to the lavatory in the middle of the movie so I wouldn't be trapped in a lineup with everyone else on the plane the moment the show ended. The seatbelt sign was on, but the turbulence had been very mild. That was until I closed the folding door behind me. I had to put my hands in front of my head and try to keep it from hitting any one of the four surrounding walls. I came quite close, the less, of cracking my skull on the door. At least the lavatory was small enough that I didn't have to worry about falling off (though I almost experienced periods of weightlessness.

Traveling from the Hong Kong airport to Kowloon and then up into mainland China wasn't intimidating this time, and having been here once before, I'm not experiencing the culture-shock I did last time either. The traffic here in the city of Dong Guan is still very crazy, and there's always lots of people on the streets, but I've learned to appreciate the benefits of blending in.

Last time I had no trouble, but for some reason this time the beggars are attracted to me like vultures to a wildebeest carcass. Since living in France I've always considered myself fairly aware of my surroundings, especially what the people close at hand are doing. I think, however, that I've been very desensitized by the fact that everyone here stares at me and I ignore the feeling of their eyes on me. The fact that there's always so much that's completely foreign to me, that I examine more intently than the people around me doesn't help either. (Plus, like I said, there's just always tons of people on the street - yes, even on the street.)

Nothing really dramatic has happened, but I have been chased down the street by an old beggar trying to shove his bowl in front of me. I've been around panhandlers, street-drunks, and rude beggars before, but never around any so persistent. The few encounters have made me grateful of the constant companionship of our hosts. I would really love to just walk around on my own, but being tall (to them), with dirty-blonde hair, and fair skin, I'm just a "rich american" target. Ugh.

The food hasn't shocked me as much this time either. But surprisingly I've had very little appetite. Last time, the food was completely new to me and I was hungry and ate well. This time I often know what we're going to have, but I'm just not hungry.

I've tried a few more "crazy" dishes too. Last time we had shark, goat, deer, bird (not chicken) and some good fish, but this time I've tried jellyfish, eel, and, well, tonight's dinner.

I had a bad food experience in France several years ago. It deserves its own account, but lets just say that I'm not a fan of tripe. Well, tonight my traveling companion Denny and I felt like "light" food - like noodles and broth. So that's the kind of restaurant we went to. It was a small place the driver knew about – a very common-person restaurant where a bowl of soup and noodles cost around 5 RMB ($0.75 USD). The menu naturally had no pictures or english and lots of options. I picked a beef and mein noodle combo that had a "thumbs-up" beside it. I hoped the thumbs-up would mean that I would enjoy it, but my palate doesn't match a chinese palate yet, so I was unsure.

The bowl arrived and the first thing I noticed was the unmistakable surface of tripe. It didn't smell too bad, and if it is prepared ok it should be ok, right? Plus, I figured I'd just eat the noodles and leave the "flavour agents" behind. I dug in and it was pretty good – for the first few bites.

Soon I noticed some other odd organ meat. I think it may have been lung or maybe kidney. I couldn't remember from my days of high school biology what the cell structure was, but it was familiar. The hosts couldn't identify it either.

And then I noticed the smell.

At first it was just a bit faint – something I could ignore. The others noticed that I was having more trouble than they, but it must have been an expression on my face or the way I chewed the noodles endlessly, because I really thought I was doing well, eating large mouthfuls of noodles. But the the smell seemed to grow stronger and attacked at my memory.

My gut wrenched involuntarily, and I tried to not figure out my history with the smell. I still haven't associated any particular experience with it, but I would best describe it as being very similar to ammonia. Ammonia mixed with cow stomach/tripe, and a hint of something else.

Needless to say, as I leaned over my bowl to take a mouthful of noodles, I was forced to hold my breath to even take a bite. I tried to continue, but my body told me no, and I wasn't about to disagree. I've learned that sometimes you just have to listen to your gut instincts (hee hee).

The others asked if I wanted to order something different, but I was neither very hungry, nor ready to expose my stomach to something different but equally difficult to consume (or anything for that matter). I still feel some tummy rumbles, and I hope that's as bad as it gets.

Last night we went to a common-person Hot Pot restaurant that only serves goat meat. I don't mind goat, but again, I wasn't very hungry. I ate a reasonable amount and had an OK time, but Denny must have been too hasty in eating some of the meat cooked in the boiling pot, as he was up half the night, paying for his meal.

So it is a rather unique experience coming here. Hopefully I don't catch anything from the food, the beggars or just some dirty door knob. The situation easily puts me at risk, but that's part of the fun, isn't it?

I also like isle seats as its always easy to jump up and stretch your long and numb legs, or, as I did on the way over here, jump up and head to the bathroom in the middle of some good turbulence.

item.title: Brylie Jaye Wynes
item.dc:creator: site admin
item.content:encoded:
Being a world apart from my family right now, I consider myself lucky to remain relatively abreast of the current family events. However this means that my information may be a bit lacking in accuracy, as the time shift an odd hours of communication, make things a bit fuzzy.


Click the picture to see more

That said, I'd like to give our (Skip and Madge's) warm congratulations to my niece Angie and her husband Mike on the birth of a beautiful little girl. I think she was born Friday night and was 6 lbs, 3 oz.

Her aunts (no uncles at all???) and grandparents are thrilled and excited I'm sure. We wish you all the best and hope that Mom and Baby will be and stay healthy and happy (and that Dad will be able to get enough sleep).

If you send me more pics, I'll do my best to post them.

[UPDATE] Mike and Angie have decided on the name of Brylie Jaye Wynes. She was born December 3, 2004 at 9:26 pm and was 19.5 inches long.
item.excerpt:encoded: That said, I'd like to give our (Skip and Madge's) warm congratulations to my niece Angie and her husband Mike on the birth of a beautiful little girl.... We wish you all the best and hope that Mom and Baby will be and stay healthy and happy (and that Dad will be able to get enough sleep).

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: She's BEAUTIFUL!!! And Angie, you look so great! Congratulations to you both - Baby girls are the BEST! (But then, I may be biased.)
i just want to send my puertorican love from the Caribe. congrats angie and mike.

Congratulations. Angie your dad is very proud of you, even though he is now and grandfather, and is married to a grandmother, he went so far as to email his business associates pictures of your 1st born.
Doug congratulations and best wishes from everyone at TNS.
Congratulations Angie and Mike! Everyone looks great but the baby is especially adorable! I love the name Brylie. Good work Angie!

item.title: Apologies
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: I'd like to publicly apologize for some inappropriate content on this site.?? It was not content that I published or would even let exist on this site (had I known it was there).?? It was comment spam, and while I was in China the bots (usually compromised Windows machines) had fun filling up the comments to my posts with vulgarities and links intended to boost their google page rank. You may have noticed that the look and feel of the site has changed as well.?? The reason for the change was the comment spam, as the original weblog software I was using (MovableType 2.6) was created before comment spam was a real problem.?? Add-ons were developed to fight the spam, but MT 2.6 became outdated and I had no motivation to move to version 3.0.?? The more attractive solution to me was to migrate from MT to WordPress.?? I've done a couple other WP installs for others, and its generally a much slicker approach to blogging than MovableType.?? MovableType had a huge following, and many nice plugins, but with version 3.0 came a licensing change and hoards of people shied away to other solutions.?? WordPress looks to have some good momentum behind it, and hopefully the plugin creators keep making slick plugins, as I'd rather not have to switch platforms again. The layout and appearance is from the Kubrick project, but I intend to make modifications.?? If things appear wacky for a day its probably because I'm trying out something new.?? I've grabbed two comment spam plugins (as comment spam bots exist for WordPress too), that should work together to keep it easy for people to comment, but keep the nasty trash off this site. So feel free to safely peruse the archives without fear of you (or your children) running into something you'd wish didn't exist on the internet, and please let me know if you should ever find something.
item.excerpt:encoded: WordPress looks to have some good momentum behind it, and hopefully the plugin creators keep making slick plugins, as I'd rather not have to switch platforms again.The layout and appearance is from the Kubrick project, but I intend to make modifications....?? I've grabbed two comment spam plugins (as comment spam bots exist for WordPress too), that should work together to keep it easy for people to comment, but keep the nasty trash away.

item.title: ecto and WordPress
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
One of the tools which has allowed me to blog as often as I have has been ecto.?? Recently updated to version two, its only gotten better.?? I haven't tried out the MarsEdit competition, but I did buy a license to ecto, so unless MarsEdit blows ecto away, I probably won't be switching until economics enters the picture again. Evidently WordPress (the site software that makes this happen) didn't play nicely with ecto, but it was all WP's fault.?? Today I found this patch for Wordpress 1.2 and Ecto (or MarsEdit) that apparently enables the following:
  • Categories
  • File upload
  • Some date magic
  • Ecto will again be able to get the URL of a post
  • The Markdown plugin will be seen by ecto
  • Trackbacks will work
So if you'd like to try some nice Mac (or Windows) desktop blogging software, be sure to give ecto a try.
item.excerpt:encoded:
I haven't tried out the MarsEdit competition, but I did buy a license to ecto, so unless MarsEdit blows ecto away, I probably won't be switching until economics enters the picture again.Evidently WordPress (the site software that makes this happen) didn't play nicely with ecto, but it was all WP's fault.
Trackbacks will work So if you'd like to try some nice Mac (or Windows) desktop blogging software, be sure to give ecto a try.

item.title: Too Much Meat and Noise Pollution
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
[Note: I wrote this at the start and end of my first trip to China.?? I've recently completed my second trip, but didn't post this until I had a chance to go through all the photos I took.]

Click the photo to see more
After the first 24 hours of being in China, all I can say is too much meat.?? They're probably trying to show us hospitality, but I'm really not used to eating so much meat.?? I am actually a bit afraid of mealtime, because it just means that I'm going to be expected to eat a bunch more meat.?? I would have expected much more rice, but it seems like for most meals there isn't any rice. But anyway, here's a better play by play of what I've experienced thus-far. We rode the train north from Hong Kong to Dong Guan.?? The train didn't seem to get moving until we had left HK and gotten into China.?? Clusters of housing complexes (like apartment buildings but what remind me strongly of the socialized housing "projects" in France - the ZUP or Bats) floated past the train window, mingled with "farmland".?? Topless farmers could be seen tending their little spots of land, and it was clear that farming here (from what I've seen) is 100% physical labour. I didn't actually have the time to finish writing this back when I started.?? I'm now on the flight home and, well, its been quite an experience. Dong Guan is what I'd describe as a "rural city."?? Its big, has a large population, but its completely lacking in most modern amenities.?? No brand name anything exists.?? No "regular" shopping, or anything similar.?? The hotel was adequate, but had its own quirks as well.?? The only purchases I made in Dong Guan were DVDs from the "DVD Store."?? Like everything in China (it seems), they're knock-offs.?? As I was told one day, the people of Dong Guan aren't concerned with brand name, if its cheap and it works, then they're satisfied. Getting off the train was like being in any other train station, except that we needed to go through Chinese Immigration and Customs.?? My visa was in order and soon we were outside, looking for our ride.?? The factory provided a van and driver, to pick us up and take us wherever we needed to go.?? One of my coworkers had been here before, and he recognized the van/driver and we loaded up and headed off to the hotel.?? I soon realized the wisdom in being driven by what I'd consider a professional driver. Traffic in China is anything but what I expected.?? I always considered Communist countries to be heavily regimented and organized.?? But, given that I saw no visible evidence of Communism, I suppose it shouldn't surprise me that traffic is anything but organized.?? The larger roads have stop lights, complete with count-down timers, but the lights seem sometimes to be considered only a suggestion.?? There's an incredible system of communication between drivers, consisting of different lengths and patterns of honking.?? Its very noise and most mornings it was not my alarm that woke me, but the incessant and loud honking (despite being on the 18th floor).?? However, the most shocking element of traversing the city was the seeming lack of care for human life. It was more common to see motorcyclists riding with their helmets hanging from their handlebars than on their heads.?? It was also very common to see more than two people on a motorcycle.?? Three and four is quite common (sometimes with baggage as well).?? Families, complete with tiny children would ride, with children sandwiched between parents or sitting in front of the driver, holding the mirrors for stability.?? Cargo, from caged chickens, to barrels of ???, are also commonly transported by motorcycle, and they also seem to be the most common type of taxi.?? I just don't understand how ladies, in dresses, can balance while ride side-saddle on the back of a motorcycle, especially in that chaotic traffic. Chaotic doesn't begin to describe it.?? Vehicles of all types, mix with pedestrians, at any and all points along the road.?? I've been passed on the left, by a city bus who had crossed the yellow line into oncoming traffic, with another bus coming head-on.?? Pedestrians play frogger with their lives, inching across the road from lane-divider to lane-divider.?? They don't even flinch or hurry or anything.?? They walk, the drivers honk and dodge them, but they're also dodging bicycles, scooters, motorbikes, tricycles, and tractor/rototiller carts?? (take a rototiller and an add a small truck box and then gun it down the road). Somehow it all works out surprisingly well.?? Brake pad manufacturers must make a killing, but there's surprisingly few accidents.?? Even so, a good driver makes all the difference.?? It a crazy blend of quick reflexes, agressiveness, and sharp defensiveness that makes it work.?? Intersections are completely uncontrolled usually, and whoever gets in the way first is the one that gets through.?? Though they race toward the intersection, somehow the drivers mentally communicate or are defensive enough to understand who they will and won't let go through.?? Somehow the factory drivers can weave they're way through better than the others. The only enviable part about this traffic scenario, is how none of the drivers get stressed or angry or concerned about the situation.?? The honking is notification and negotiation, not a symbol of anger or protest (mild protesting sometimes, but rarely).?? I guess they're just used to it. I shot some video of the traffic, hopefully I got some good moments that demonstrate the adventure that occurred each time we climbed into the van.?? Oh, and no-one wears seat belts.?? The back seats of the van didn't actually have any.?? You're therefore completely at the mercy of the driver and the other vehicles.?? And yes, there were some close moments, but all you can do is trust the driver. The factory was good, for the most part.?? We sleuthed out some issues and I had to make a trip to Hong Kong and back with the top factory official.?? That experience will be a story all its own. Mostly I worked between 16 and about 18 hours a day.?? I was rarely at my computer with its horribly slow connection, and spent all my time trying to pick out the biggest problem and come up with a solution.?? I've already written about one of the days, the others were very similar. The thing about this factory trip that was new to me, was their intense security.?? Entering and leaving the factory often involves registering laptops, and not being allowed to have cameras, but we also had to have an escort at all times.?? We sometimes dodged this rule, but also were chastised for doing so.?? In fact, other than the short time we were at the hotel, we had a escort of one type or another at all times.?? Moving between floors, or going around the office required an escort.?? Worst of all, the usually trivial task of going to the restroom also required an escort.?? I seriously felt like I can now identify (mildly) with prison inmates who have to request permission.?? It made it really hard to take care of business some days. The people were hard working and contentious, so much so that often while I was experimenting or when I'd leave something where they obviously didn't think it belonged, it would get spontaneously cleaned up and disappear.?? It was nice to see but really quite a bother. The language barrier was also a big headache for me.?? There were about 5 individuals who spoke reasonable english.?? There were an additional two I think who spoke and understand a bit, and beyond that, they didn't speak or understand any.?? Consequently I became, or tried to become, good at pantomiming what I needed, but this type of communication just didn't work effectively sometimes, leaving us both confused, frustrated or both. And other than the first couple of days, I really enjoyed the food.?? There was still a large amount of meat consumed, and a shocking lack of rice, but the meals were varied and flavourful and unique.?? Fear-factor has nothing on me now.?? I ate most everything, though sometimes only a few bites.?? Spicy food was more enjoyable to me than the others, and I soon became known for liking spicy stuff.?? Somehow I could trust the spicy stuff to match my palate (beyond just the heat), and once they knew I liked it, at least one dish would be selected specifically for me. The hot peppers were good, but I went a bit overboard one night.?? It was pretty hot and since that evening my stomach, and the continuation of my digestive tract, have been a bit out of whack.?? I don't honestly know if it was the peppers, or the large amount of hot oil that I consumed that night, or even the quality of the food and the poor cleanliness at that particular restaurant.?? Either way, I've managed and haven't felt poorly, but I need to stay aware of the location of restrooms and make use of them fairly often. The plant manager, who I travelled to Hong Kong and back with, occasionally shared a meal with us.?? He spoke english very well, and loved to pick unique restaurants so he could expose us to as many different types of traditional food as possible.?? His choices were wonderful and it was particularly special to receive the explanation of the origin, history, and significance of each dish. China is incredible.?? From the more modern cities to the rural, dusy, dirty, noisy places like Dong Guan, there's an incredible amount of potential and talent.?? No one was overweight, and few men were even heavy.?? Many people were walking or biking, and though they live in rather third-world conditions, they seem happy and friendly ??? content and appreciative.?? There was no talk of politics, no evidence of the Chairman or Communism.?? There was a healthy (well, substantial) number of guards, peace officers, and police (if there's a difference), but no other symbols of regime or oppression.?? I consider myself lucky to have been able to visit a country so rich in culture so different from the American and European cultures that I know.?? Its so rich in history and tradition, and I'm glad I've been there before the Olympics arrives.?? I don't know for certain that China will change by itself, but I'm certain it will become a more popular destination and those consequences are unavoidable.
item.excerpt:encoded: As I was told one day, the people of Dong Guan aren't concerned with brand name, if its cheap and it works, then they're satisfied.Getting off the train was like being in any other train station, except that we needed to go through Chinese Immigration and Customs....?? Either way, I've managed and haven't felt poorly, but I need to stay aware of the location of restrooms and make use of them fairly often.The plant manager, who I travelled to Hong Kong and back with, occasionally shared a meal with us. He spoke english very well, and loved to pick unique restaurants so he could expose us to as many different types of traditional food as possible.

item.title: Changing a Life Forever
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
I met a woman in the Hong Kong airport on the way back from China.?? When I first saw her I had to caution myself not to stereotypically judge her or "look down" at her because of her appearance.?? She is a human being, a person equal to myself, though her physical size is something that I personally would not want to sit beside on a 11-15 hour flight over the Pacific.?? She was pushing a stroller and carrying a couple of the bags that are a necessity when traveling with children.?? Though perhaps a bit burdened by her situation, she otherwise didn't look very different from the other weary travelers congregated around the gate.?? Having flown several times with both one and two small children, I certainly didn't envy her position. When I stood to get in line to board the plane, she was immediately in front of me in line, and, evidently more weary than I initially judged, commented, "We have to show them our passports, again??? We couldn't get this far without showing them already." I looked down, saw a 2 year old Chinese toddler in this 35-year-old caucasian woman's stroller, and asked, "Have you travelled with her before??? Does she travel well at least?" She responded, her hands full of passports, tickets, and bags, by saying, "No, I just came over here to pick her up." Suddenly I was overwhelmed by the courage and charity of this poor woman.?? I've done many things for my two girls, but I would be cautious about flying half way around the world with them at this age, let alone traveling by myself to a foreign country to pick up an orphan child and immediately begin caring for them as my own.?? I was simply amazed by the love and devotion of this wonderful woman for the otherwise destitute child she rescued.?? It takes a lot to be a parent, and for a mother to give birth to a child.?? It also takes a lot, though differently perhaps, for a person or couple to adopt and love a child as their own, not to mention one who doesn't speak your language or come from your culture.?? Though the scenarios are rather incomparable in many ways, they still require the commitment of a lot of devotion, time, and love. I offered my assistance ??? what little I could ??? but she declined and I wished her the best.?? As I took my seat, I thought more about her probable situation back in Georgia.?? I cannot accurately draw my own conclusion about the family lifestyle this child will grow up in, but I hope for the best and assume that anything this woman can provide will definitely be better than the state-run orphanage in mainland "communist" China.?? So many possibilities are now open to this tiny little girl that didn't exist a day or two before.?? Its simply amazing when you step back and think of it. But I ask these questions of you, the reader, and I'm curious about if/when your answer will change from "Yes" to "No".?? Feel free to sound-off in the comments.
  1. Do you agree, with me, that it is wonderful of this woman to adopt a poor Chinese orphan, and give her love, hope, and a place for her to fulfill her potential?
  2. If this woman is married, though I doubt it, isn't it wonderful that this child will go from being parent-less to having two role models and caregivers, and the support structure to possibly allow one parent to raise her and the other to provide financial support?
  3. If the child's new mother is single and employed, isn't it better that this daughter spend days in day care but at least has a loving mother to go home with?
  4. If the mother is single, but has a relative who lives with or near her and can help love and raise this little girl, isn't that still better than the alternative life as just another orphan in the land of 1.3 billion people?
  5. What if the mother was single, but lived with another woman who she considered her partner for life, wouldn't that be better still than having no parents and no future?
  6. What if the union of these two women was legally recognized by the government, would the child still be better off, with these two individuals filling the role of parent, than the alternative of living without any family in a third world country?
[Note: My questions should show the kind of family organization I would prefer this child to be raised in, but hopefully they also provide a thought provoking perspective that I doubt many people have considered before.?? Traveling to foreign lands always makes me appreciate the things I have that others do not.?? It can put a new spin on old perspectives I think, but only if you look beyond your own situation. Tolerance does not equal advocacy.]

What if the union of these two women was legally recognized by the government, would the child still be better off, with these two individuals filling the role of parent, than the alternative of living without any family in a third world country?[Note: My questions should show the kind of family organization I would prefer this child to be raised in, but hopefully they also provide a thought provoking perspective that I doubt many people have considered before.

item.title: Wordpress Blues
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: I've done no less than 5 separate Wordpress installs, and each one has worked flawlessly... that is, except for this one. If you've visited anytime in say, the last month, you will probably have been shocked to see just 1995-style text.?? No colours, borders, nice fonts, nada.?? For the first couple of weeks of wackiness, I tried a few things to fix the problem.?? I could fix it momentarily, but soon the links to the css stylesheet, which nicely converts boring text to flashy layout, would become broken.?? Finally today I gave up, backed up my install, deleted the database, and then restored just the content (and none of the potentially messed up settings).?? I've also switched to a lemony theme.?? I'll definitely modify it, but its a start. Welcome back to the 21st century.

Lauryn: Mom, do you know what? Mom:    What, Honey? Lauryn: One, two, three! I'm three! Mom:    Yes, you are three! Lauryn: How many is Sophia? Mom:    Well, she's eight months old, so she's not even one yet. She's kind of like... a half. Lauryn: Half a baby!!? Mom:    No... she's a whole baby, she's just not one year old yet.

item.title: Sophia Motion
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Click the image to watch the movie or here for the big version (3.2 MB)
Sophia has been on the verge of crawling for a week or two now.?? Using combinations of sitting, flopping, and backwards-scooting, she's been able to get most anywhere for even longer.?? As of yesterday, she would move her arms out from her body and then "buck" forwards and backwards but stay in the same place.?? Finally this morning, when Sophia and Lauryn were playing in Lauryn's room, Soph could see a toy that she wanted and boom she just crawled over and got it. Later this afternoon we managed to entice her a with a crayon.?? Watch the video to see the results.

item.title: Tina
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
We have the sweetest neighbour here in San Diego.?? "Grandma Lee" recently turned 95 and lives all alone next door.?? Her son is estranged and she hasn't heard from him in years, and her daughter lives in Colorado.
Like many of the elderly people I've lived around, she's a rather independent soul even at such a frail age.?? We used to see her shuffle past our door and drive off in her car to get groceries or head to the bank,?? but recently her car hasn't moved from its parking spot.?? Just before her birthday, she asked Madge to take her to the DMV so that she could renew her driver's license.?? She managed to pass the test and could drive her car, but since receiving her new license, I think she's moved her car only one time ??? she says the battery is dead.
No one visits her.?? No one came for Christmas.?? Since her car wasn't working, Madge has intercepted her, with the help of Lauryn, as she tried to walk to either the bank or grocery store ??? neither of which is reasonably close for someone of her age.?? In fact, her bank is more than a mile away and on the other side of a deep valley.?? Since Madge caught her trying to walk to the grocery store, her daughter has been ordering (over the internet) groceries to be delivered, but she still needs to go to the bank once a month.
Madge was busy with two sick kids yesterday ??? Sophia was asleep in bed and Lauryn was in jammies ??? when Grandma Lee walked past yesterday.?? Several minutes went by before she realized that this sweet elderly woman was wearing a hat and handbag and, regardless of our previous offerings to help, was attempting to trek somewhere again.?? But despite feeling responsible to help her, Madge didn't dare leave Lauryn and Sophia alone while she ran down the street to look for and stop her.
I was at work, a few blocks away, packing up my cubicle as our office is moving.?? I understood Madge's position but still felt obligated, and compelled, to look out for, and find, this aged soul.?? We don't live close to our own parents and I often feel bad for not being in a position to assist them, but find it consoling to be able to keep an eye on our aged neighbour in their stead.
After deducing the direction she most likely walked, as she uses bus-stop benches as resting places, I ran off from work to a place on a nearby road where I hoped I'd be able to find her.?? It had been about 25 minutes since Madge had first seen her, and she didn't expect I'd be able to find her.?? But as I ran up to the corner where I was going to start looking, I was amazed to see Grandma Lee standing next to the stop-light pole, waiting to cross the street.
I ran up and told her, "Hi, I'm your neighbour, are you ok?"?? I was glad to see both surprise and relief enter her face, and I quickly told her that Brenda would come and we could drive her to her bank.?? I had a two-way radio with me and was able to talk to Madge at home to tell her that I'd indeed found Grandma Lee, and where she could find us.?? (By then Lauryn had gotten dressed and Sophia had woken up.)
I helped her shuffle back to a nearby bench where we waited for Madge.?? She told me of her plan and how she underestimated the distance.?? When she drives in her car, it seems so close, but she'd only been able to walk 1/6 of the way.?? She feels like if she gives up some of her independence that she'll quickly lose all her abilities.?? For her age she does amazingly well, but I feel its rather risky to live completely alone and independent, especially now that she's losing the capability of caring for herself.?? But, as with many elderly people, she doesn't want to live in a "home," so for now she'll keep on alone.?? Hopefully we'll be able to keep her from voyaging.

Sophia was in bed and Lauryn was in jammies ??? when Geneva walked past yesterday....?? I understood Brenda's position but still felt obligated, and compelled, to look out for, and find, this aged soul. We don't live close to our own parents, and I often bad for not being in a position to assist them, but find it consoling to be able to keep an eye on our aged neighbour in their place.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: When I saw the title of this post, I thought the words, "Tina! Come get some ham!" were going to appear somewhere. It's sure nice that you're keeping an eye out for your neighbour though. The world needs more good neighbours like you guys!

Mmm Ham.
I think that this is a good example of why i adore you guys. I got a package of yummy valentine cookies and treats yesterday. Thanks, I totally wasn't expecting anything, so it came as a wonderful surprise.
Sometime Tina will escape this binding mortal coil - but your kindness will live on and one.
Thanks for inspiring me and making things better just with the ray of goodness that surrounds you.
what a nice story to read, i just got back from helping a friend with a flat tire. Its good to know that regardless where you are there are still good samaritans out there.

item.title: Oh, no, she swallowed it again
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
More than two years ago I bought Lauryn a dolly.?? If you squeeze its hand or tummy it makes little cooing or crying sounds.?? At first she was scared of it.?? Then just disinterested.?? But in the past two weeks she's really gotten into "Mommying" her baby.?? Her name is "Charlie".
After playing with and talking about the baby doll today, this sequence spilled out.
Lauryn: She's sad because she has a sore tummy Mom:   Why does she have a sore tummy? Lauryn: Because she has a hard spot in her tummy Mom:   How did she get a hard spot in her tummy? Lauryn: Betause she swallowed a bee. Mom:   Did she mean to swallow a bee? Lauryn: Nope, it just buzzed right in Mom:   Oh. Lauryn: I need to det (get) her some medicine to make it better Lauryn: (Leaves and comes back.) I have the medicine Mom:   Did you get it from the Doctor? Lauryn: Nope, I just found it.?? I would give it to her (runs away with the doll). Audible: *slurp* Lauryn: (Runs back) She needed FOUR parts of medicine.?? Now I have to burp her. (Pat, pat, pat, pat...) Mom:   You take care of your dolly Lauryn: I knowed how Audible: *burp* Lauryn: The bee flew out. Mom:   It did? Lauryn: With her burp.?? Oh, no, she swallowed it again.
item.excerpt:encoded: After playing with and talking about the baby doll today, this sequence spilled out.Lauryn: She's sad because she has a sore tummyMom: Why does she have a sore tummy?Lauryn: Because she has a hard spot in her tummyMom: How did she get a hard spot in her tummy?Lauryn: Betause she swallowed a bee.Mom: Did she mean to swallow a bee?Lauryn: Nope, it just buzzed right inMom: Oh.Lauryn: I need to det her some medicine to make it betterMom: Lauryn: (Leaves and comes back.)...?? (Pat pat pat pat)Mom: You take care of your dollyLauryn: I knowed howAudible: *burp*Lauryn: The bee flew out.

item.title: Too much hustle, too much bustle
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: About the day that the improbability drive went down, I was intending to make a "What's New" post.???? Fortunately, the site is back up and nothing was lost in the drive failure.???? Unfortunately, the title speaks to my current situation.???? Alas, this brief update will merely list events so hopefully one day I can record them properly. Visitors First Clovis came and visited.???? We took a bunch of pics in Del Mar at the beach and then he and I made a dusk trip to TJ.???? It was a good Saturday together with our first official visitor (other than Brenda's parents).???? Naturally we don't intend for it to be as long until we hang out with the Under-water Chicken Rancher again, but we also don't make any promises Next, Rick and Ren???e took a vacation from the bleary cold of Ottawa to the rainy climes of SoCal.???? Rain and cloudy weather kept us from having a good beach day, and a trip to Old Town burned up the only sunny and warm day we had.???? Not that it mattered much to me, though, as an unforeseen problem at work kept me experimenting late each night for almost the entirety of their visit.???? I managed to escape on the weekend, and we spend two good days in LA.???? The highlight was definitely the J. Paul Getty Museum, but we saw a few other fun things and were glad to hang out with Rick again and to get to know Ren???e better. Ryan and Cam also graced us with a visit, one week after R & R, and again it was raining ?????? even worse.???? Cam got to play with the EVDO wireless modem I recently finished helping design at work as we drove back from the airport in LA, and we generally had a good time playing Canadian Trivial Pursuit, home-made Scattergories, and Phase 10, visiting the Wild Animal park in the rain, playing on the beach and boogie boarding in the rather cool water.???? Ryan's took lots of good pictures - check them out.???? One day I'll post my own (duplicate?) gallery. Kids Our two blondes sure have fun together.???? Lauryn is a great role-model and Sophia is anxious to do all that her sister does.???? She's rapidly moved from scooting to crawling, to furniture surfing, to stair scampering in the past two (three?) weeks.???? We've caught her free-standing for several (5+) seconds at a time, but I get chastised for encouraging her, as she is already constantly putting herself in precarious positions.???? Her latest trick is to climb the back of our folding kitchen chairs, grab the top of the backrest, put her feet on the bottom bar, and have the chair tip over backwards onto her.???? She flip-flops between being unable to have her body contain her happiness (and flopping around, and kicking, in glee) and moaning, wailing, and writhing about with teething pain. Lauryn's skills and capabilities make us happy, and its hard to not be too proud.???? She's slowed (a bit) on the number of "why" questions asked each day, but she remembers the answers and is very sincere in asking why.???? She loves to run and screech as her sister "chases" her, and she's probably glad that her hair is getting pulled less and less.???? Madge stays busy keeping Lauryn "tasked" with fun things to do, and everyone has to stay on their toes to make sure Sophia doesn't get too far up our dangerous stairs without supervision. Work Work has been satisfying but altogether too busy for my tastes. Usually this busyness comes in waves, but this wave is lasting a bit longer than normal.???? We're working on exciting stuff and moving forward very quickly, but with fast pace design, testing, prototyping, and evaluation comes potential oversight, time constraints, problems, and a general need to work long hours (to fix the problems).???? It doesn't help when previous projects urgently need attention, and trade shows demand timely results.???? We've been fairly lucky, but there's still lots to do. I'm really trying to devote my non-work hours to my family, as often in the past few weeks I've been forced to stay extra late at work.???? Every moment with my sweet girls is precious to me, so some of my personal side-projects have naturally taken a back seat.???? But I feel that's the way it should be.???? Not this busy, but that family should take precedence whenever possible. Back to the grindstone, Sk][p

Naturally we don't intend for it to be as long until we hang out with the Under-water Chicken Rancher again, but we also don't make any promisesNext, Rick and Ren???e took a vacation from the bleary cold of Ottawa to the rainy climes of SoCal.

item.title: Excel Formula to Calculate Standard 1% Resistor Values
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
I had a need recently to look up precision resistor standard values, and ran across this Electronic Design page: http://www.elecdesign.com/Articles/Index.cfm?AD=1&ArticleID=1480.?? The formula listed on the page was rather long and unwieldy, so I didn't even try it, but the smrt people who made comments had two good formulas that do the same thing.
=ROUND(10^(ROUND(96*(LOG10(A1)-INT(LOG10(A1))),0)/96),2)*10^(INT(LOG10(A1))) =IF(A1<(ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1))/96),2-INT(LOG(A1)))+ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1)+1)/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))))/2,ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1))/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))),ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1)+1)/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))))
I post these primarily for my own reference - perhaps I'll spin them as a Mac OS X Tiger Dashboard Widget.

The formula listed on the page was rather long and unwieldy, so I didn't even try it, but the smrt people who made comments had two good formulas that do the same thing.=ROUND(10^(ROUND(96*(LOG10(A1)-INT(LOG10(A1))),0)/96),2)*10^(INT(LOG10(A1)))=IF(A1<(ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1))/96),2-INT(LOG(A1)))+ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1)+1)/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))))/2,ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1))/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))),ROUND(10^(INT(96*LOG(A1)+1)/96),2-INT(LOG(A1))))I post these primarily for my own reference - perhaps I'll spin them as a Mac OS X Tiger Dashboard Widget.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: But can it give me a pair of standard resistors that form a spesific voltage divider with an equivilent resistance around a target (I want to divide 4.2v down to 1.91V with the sum being around 6Mohm)
I just look them up in the digikey part finder.

I derived the equations for this case.
Define a = Vout/Vin Define Rin = sum of resistors
Then Upper resistor = (1-a)*Rin Lower resistor = a*Rin
For you case, a = 0.454762 Rin = 6E6
Then, using standard 5% resistors,
Upper resistor = 3.3E6 Lower resistor = 2.7E6
Calculated a = 0.45 error = -1%

item.title: Round Rects
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: After reading Andy Hertzfeld's description of how Round Rects came to the Mac OS, I've been much more aware of their existance.?? I quite like Round Rects, as they just "feel" nicer (that is, if computer graphics indeed have feelings). Creating Round Rects with CSS has always been something I wanted to do for the reason that they're less pointy than square boxes.?? I've seen code before, but the code I ran into today at http://www.redmelon.net/tstme/4corners/ is a nice clean slick method that allows the round rects to be resized and still look good.

item.title: Remote Install of OS X Applications
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
In my role as a technical consultant for those family members and friends around me who have Macs (a number which has greatly increased over the past 7 years), the occasion has arisen when I have the need to remotely install an application (.mpkg or .pkg) on an OS X box from the command line. The machine might be inaccessible or I don't want to "talk" someone through the process, and usually the only access I have is by way of SSH. One of the typical reasons is to upgrade a remote machine to support Apple Remote Desktop 2.?? ARD (the admin program) has the ability to remotely copy and install applications, but usually it fails or says that it can't.?? Here's my solution (replace the parts in italics).
  1. ?? Find the InstallerPackage.pkg (or .mpkg) in the terminal and (as it's a bundle) tar it up.?? (For Apple Remote Desktop I referred to this MacOSXHints page.)
    • tar -zcvf InstallerPackage.pkg.tar.gz /path/to/InstallerPackage.pkg.tar.gz
  2. ?? SCP/SFTP the package to the remote machine.
    • scp InstallerPackage.pkg.tar.gz username@address:/path/to/destination
  3. ??untar the package in an SSH terminal
    • tar -zxvf /path/to/destination/InstallerPackage.pkg.tar.gz /path/to/untarred/location
  4. ?? Install the program in an SSH terminal(this is the critical command that I found on this other MacOSXHints page.)
    • sudo /usr/sbin/installer -verbose -pkg InstallerPackage.pkg -target /
I'm not certain what happens if you install a program that requires rebooting after install, but this has saved me several times and is worth sharing. Enjoy.

item.title: RE:Tag
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
So Tamara "tagged" me and then had the audacity (just kidding) to say that I blog infrequently and would be unlikely to respond to the tagging. Well, I wanted to respond immediately, but well, better late than never(?). But before I pay my tagging penance, I'd just like to throw down a lazy excuse that I've been busy. Between working on an under-staffed, unreasonable-schedule project, wrapping up loose ends on living in San Diego, moving my family North 2600 km (and driving it both ways), traveling back to San Diego for a week, unpacking, and trying to make progress on a few-too-many side projects, I've had no time to spill the thoughts trapped in my brain into this archivable format. So this will be two posts in the same day. Think I can keep it up? Number of books I own: Simple answer - not enough, thought I don't have/make the time to finish reading them. I need to amass more technical books. As a poor student I avoided purchasing textbooks due to their exorbitant costs. Now that my purchasing power has been increased, I find I really need to add these to my library. Real answer - probably only 50. Last Book I Bought:


"Technical Analysis of the Future's Markets" (John J. Murphy, Murphy)

A fantastic book if you're interested in the Stock/Options/Futures Markets. I read a good portion on a flight to China and bought this $120 book for $5 from a "new and used" Amazon affiliate. Last Book I Read:


"It's Not About the Bike: My Journey Back to Life" (Lance Armstrong)

I burned through this one in just over 24 hours by reading while walking to and from work, during lunch, and instead of sleeping. That's my trouble with non-technical books, once I pick it up I can't put it down until I'm done. This one gives a great insight into Lance's life-changing experience with testicular, lung, and brain cancer and his amazing recovery, incredible determination, and his return to the world of competitive cycling (and the first two of his now-six wins of the sport's crowning race). A very encouraging book with regard to overcoming life's obstacles. However, it was saddening to me to read about his relationship and marriage to Kit knowing that it has since "failed." Five Books That Mean a Lot to Me:


  1. "Where the Red Fern Grows" (Wilson Rawls)

    Madge and I are midway through this and its one of my all-time favorites.


  2. "The Hunt for Red October" (Tom Clancy)

    I've read this and a few other Tom Clancy page-turners more times than I can count (I think I've read either Hunt for Red October or Clear and Present Danger 7 times). The last one I read was while traveling to/from Korea I think.


  3. "Mountaineering: The Freedom of the Hills" (Mountaineers Books)

    This is the "Climber's Bible" and has come in handy several times. Need to refresh your knowledge of knots, crevasse rescue, ice/rock/snow climbing, glissading, etc? Anyone who does more than car-camping should have a copy and browse through it before any outing (or pack it). You never know what situation you'll need to overcome.


  4. "How to Stay Alive in the Woods: A Complete Guide to Food, Shelter and Self-Preservation Anywhere" (Bradford Angier)

    This is a recent acquisition that I haven't gotten through yet - but if you want to know what/how to find something to eat when you don't think there's anything, this is the book for you. Stew stinging nettle, eat insects, but just don't eat too many rabbits.


  5. "Cocoa Programming" (Scott Anguish, Erik Buck, Donald Yacktman)

    I've read a good amounts of this one and get excited every time I think about reading more. Its well written and clear, but sadly I haven't (yet) been able to capitalize on the knowledge contained therein. I have plans and intentions, and Objective-C and Cocoa are so nice to play with. If only I could immerse myself in it for a month or two...
Five More Bloggers I'm going to abstain, but feel like swapping it out for Five Books I'd Like to Acquire. Sadly, I don't have the time to build that list at the moment either...
