item.title: Fast Times on the John Laurie Pathway
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Prior to moving to San Diego just over a year ago, I enjoyed riding my rigid '93 Specialized StumpJumper the 8.78 km work every day. Some day's I'd ride over Nose Hill, but mostly, and especially during the winter, I'd ride the path parallel to John Laurie and then tuck through some quiet residential roads to Northmount and on to Deerfoot and 64th Avenue NE. During that time I began to suffer an incredible amount of pain in my right wrist. I consulted a Doctor and tried to eliminate all potential sources of Repetitive Stress Injury (RSI) that could be literally killing my wrist. I went on the Foosball injured list, I stopped using a mouse, I was careful about my typing positioning, I began wearing a wrist guard, and I was very careful about how and when I bent or put weight on my wrist. And then we moved, and apart from being cautious holding Sophia, my wrist injury became mostly forgotten. That is, until work switched offices and I began riding my my bike to work again. Within one week my wrist and arm were hurting more than ever, and the only thing that had changed in my routine was bombing down the valley to work. The mountain bike hand positioning (and lack of suspension) was continually jarring my wrist and I was suffering once more. I immediately stopped riding and ran and walked to work instead (ask me about the Western Diamondback Rattlesnakes sometime). And then we moved home, and I was in a dire situation. I don't want to own a second car, and its too far to walk. I'm not a fan of the bus and it doesn't really go where I need it to, so either I get a ride to and from work, or I figure out a way to bike. After thinking about the circumstances behind my recent wrist-injury aggravation, I decided that I most likely would be able to write a road bike (with drop-bars) and thereby keep my hand inline with my forearm and my wrist would not need to bend, flex or bear any strain. I quickly researched road bikes and went into my local Trek shop and was enamoured with the Trek Madones. Unfortunately, it snows here, and I want to ride year-round. Phil at Calgary Cycle recommended that I try out a Cyclocross bike instead of a pure road bike. Cross bikes are of a very similar geometry to Road Bikes, but are built with more fork-to-tire clearance to accommodate larger (ie. knobbier) tires, and allow snow/mud/fender clearance. High end carbon fiber road bikes are built for the road, and my route to work is definitely a mixed track and a Cross is decidedly the more suitable vehicle. The next day I rode off on my new Trek X0 1 and within a couple of days I knew that cycling would no longer be a major source of wrist injury. But my path to work, as I said, is mixed (pavement and grass/dirt/rocks), and the jarring movements that occur as I blaze across the landscape scare me. So I've modified my route and have dropped farther down the side of Nose Hill to ride on the paved surface of Cayuga Crescent. Fortunately, the days of heading down to Capri and Cayuga will soon be over. Several weeks ago I noticed surveyor markings at the one end of the offensive mixed section of park between 19th Street and 14th Street. Yesterday a crew was out digging up the grass and topsoil and a paved pathway appears to be under construction. I was ready to email my alderman and request such a pathway, as only this small section of parkland parallel to John Laurie doesn't have a paved path. Its absence has caused the creation of at least 4 different parallel paths, and really, only one path should be necessary. I believe that fundamentally people tend to that which is easiest or most convenient. If the given situation it isn't easy, convenient or absolutely necessary, people tend to create or do the next easiest thing regardless. Thus the creation of a paved path (as long as it goes in the most reasonable location and in a mostly straight line) will keep people from tramping down the grass and creating their own route through this rather narrow park. Dogs can wander either side (but I'll kick them if they come after me), and kids can roam in the grass, but the majority of the traffic will tend to follow the most convenient, soon-to-be-paved path. Give people the most obvious choice, and they'll follow it without thinking of alternatives. ps. This same idea applies, in my opinion, to the paving of SELECT paths in Nose Hill Park. If you give them the most desirable routes, the secondary routes will grow over. If you leave it "unguided" nothing will motivate people to stop charting their own course.
item.excerpt:encoded: Prior to moving to San Diego just over a year ago, I enjoyed riding my rigid '93 Specialized StumpJumper the 8.78 km to work every day. Some day's I'd ride over Nose Hill, but mostly, and especially during the winter, I'd ride the path parallel to John Laurie and then tuck through some quiet residential roads to Northmount and on to Deerfoot and 64th Avenue NE.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Congradulations on moving back to Calgary and on the new bike! Cyclocross is pretty cool.
ttyl, mch
Handlebars and wrist injury Utilitarian cyclists disagree on just about everything, and one of those things is handlebar style.

After a couple months of riding that same bike to work I started to have weird sensations in my left wrist/hand. After about 30 minutes of riding my wrist and hand would go numb like it was asleep. But once I got to work it would be fine after a couple minutes. It would only happen when I rode to work - riding uphill (home) must have shifted my weight/position just enough to not cause the problem. Thanks again for the use of the bike. With the nice weather I'm still riding it once in awhile.

item.title: Automated Podcasting
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
Using Wordpress, Audio Hijack Pro and Applescript

The local Campus/Community Radio Station ??? CJSW ??? has some pretty good shows but I never manage to listen to them except by accident. Podcasting has been growing as a movement and with the recent addition of Podcatching features (retrieving Podcasts) to iTunes, I figured this would be the beginning of the popularity surge of this subscription format of acquiring audio content. The most natural fit of this technology, on a rather private scale, would be the ability to time-shift (think Tivo) CJSW radio shows and publish these archives so a few close friends can enjoy them as well. I use WordPress to publish this site (and a few others) and with my recent upgrading to version 1.5 along came the podcast feature of WordPress to automatically detect links to .mp3 files and store the info necessary to generate the enclosure tag in the RSS2.0 feed. So a few tests later and I had content available for subscription through iTunes (by manually entering the URL of the RSS feed). Now came the tough part(s). To automate the process of capturing and publishing the shows, I was obligated to overcome the following obstacles:

Problems

  1. Capture the .mp3 stream from CJSW.com to a bookmarkable AAC (.m4a). Bookmarkable AACs are desirable because new-ish iPods and iTunes will keep track of the point in the track where you last stopped and will resume from that point the next time you play it.
  2. Gather the data for the RSS enclosure tag. The enclosure tag includes a link to the audio file, the size of the file in bytes, and the MIME type of the file (audio/mpeg). <enclosure      url="http://www.cbc.ca/quirks/media/2004-2005/mp3/qq-2004-12-18a.mp3"      length="10036870"      type="audio/mpeg"/>
  3. Create a new WordPress post linking to the audio file. (Luckily my sites are served from a Mac and I can capture the same machine, eliminating the need of ftping the completed capture to the webserver.)

Solutions

  1. The most natural choice for capturing the stream is Audio Hijack Pro. It will record from any source, can mute the source while capturing, is easily schedulable, and can run an applescript at the completion of the capture. It can also record directly to AAC Bookmarkable, Audio filters can be applied real-time to the capture to "improve" the quality, and, well, Rogue Amoeba has a cool logo.
  2. It was relatively simple to look up the file name and file size using Applescript. Basically I just look in the folder where AHP stores the .m4a for any files that haven't been tagged with a label. I look up the size in bytes and then tag the file with a label so it can get ignored next time.
  3. Early on I'd detected that while WordPress will automatically generate the info necessary for the enclosure tag for .mp3 files, it was completely ignorant of .m4a files. The web-form for creating and publishing new WordPress posts allow you to add custom data fields to any post (where the enclosure key and value are stored), but my preferred, and highly scriptable, desktop blogging software, ecto, doesn't appear to have this same capability. I needed to come up with an alternate method of automatically publishing new posts. I've known for a while that Safari is Applescript-able, but I've only ever used it for automatically loading and refreshing pages. While poking through some of the Safari Applescript documentation I discovered that recent versions of Safari respond to JavaScript called by AppleScript. This can allow you to look up and modify DOM elements of any web page (given that you can figure out how to reference the element). So here was my plan, script Safari to load the WordPress post page (assuming I'm already logged in), and then populate the Title, Post, and custom tag fields with the appropriate information and click the Publish button all by way of Applescript JavaScript calls. This would let me have .m4a enclosures and everything should be spiffy.
Aside: Truthfully this is precisely one of the strongest points of OS X. Applescript is usually painful to work with due to its atypical syntax and horrible error messages. Just because an Applescript dictionary appears to list functionality you can use, that doesn't mean you can figure out how to use it. However, the simple ability of being able to use one Applescript to drive GUI elements, modify web page content, make system (ie. terminal) calls, and link multiple applications together in a workflow is amazing. Yes, "unix" pipes can do wonderful things, but are there really any other ways of automating the process of filling in a web-form (other than with default personal details)?
After getting frustrated being unable to reference and successfully manipulate the web-form elements, I uncovered this Applescript code snippet posted by one of the smartest Mac developers around. The second code snippet is exactly what I needed in order to identify the number of the elements I wanted to modify. Once I was able to fill in the form, I still had a difficulty. The way that WordPress converts the custom enclosure tag value (a string) into the three elements of the RSS enclosure tag is by reading an end of line character after each item. That is, the audio file URL, the size of the file in bytes, and the MIME type of the file are deliminated by end of line ('\n') characters. Try as I might, there was NO way that I could include that end of line character in my Applescript/JavaScript and get that field populated with data. Either Safari didn't like the '\n' in the middle of the JavaScript or Applescript didn't like it in the middle of the JavaScript. (This is precisely why Applescript can be so maddening - you never get the kind of error reporting that would typically enable you to figure it out.) So I had automated the creation of a WordPress post, but I couldn't write the enclosure data in a format that WordPress would understand when it attempts to create the enclosure tag in the RSS feed. There was only one solution left - modify WordPress. While it was difficult to find the WordPress code that scans the post for links to .mp3 files (ie. I never found it), it was rather easy to find the code that splits the enclosure tag value at each newline ('\n') and generates the enclosure tag with a quick grep for enclosure. The rss_enclosure() function in wp-includes/feed-functions.php includes the following code: if( $key == 'enclosure' ) {      if (is_array($val)) {           foreach($val as $enc) {                $enclosure = split( "\n", $enc );                print "<enclosure url='".trim( htmlspecialchars($enclosure[ 0 ]) )."' length='".tr im( $enclosure[ 1 ] )."' type='".trim( $enclosure[ 2 ] )."'/>\n";           }      } } Which, when the enclosure key is found splits the enclosure value ($enc) into an array of strings as separated by newlines ('\n'). It then prints the actual enclosure tag using the values at each index of $enclosure. I quick read of the php manual made it clear that a more efficient method of doing this split into an array would be with the explode() function. So I decided that I'd use my own delimiter (a semicolon) and then change Wordpress to explode $enc based on '\n' if it is present (the default) or on a semicolon ';' (my situation). This is the resulting code: if( $key == 'enclosure' ) {      if (is_array($val)) {           foreach($val as $enc) {                if(strpos($enc, "\n"))                     $enclosure = explode( "\n", $enc );                else                     $enclosure = explode(";", $enc );                print "<enclosure url='".trim( htmlspecialchars($enclosure[ 0 ]) )."' length='".tr im( $enclosure[ 1 ] )."' type='".trim( $enclosure[ 2 ] )."'/>\n";           }      } } And it appears to work. Naturally the likelihood of violating someone's copyright by time-shifting and redistribution these streaming-audio (radio) captures is highly likely. But I defend that:
  1. The captured streams aren't beautiful quality. They're nice but nothing nearly as clear as owning the original CD, so no one is going to be losing CD sales.
  2. I may, at best, cause more interest in the artists featured, spurring CD and concert sales
  3. At worst, I'll be the only person to use what I've created.
  4. I encourage anyone who makes use of my CJSW podcasts to support the station by donating to their funding drive each fall (or anytime). Its your donations to them that you and me to be able to listen and learn of new artists.
So enjoy the podcasts (not hosted here) and support independent radio and the artists. And comment on any shows that I should podcast. The Applescript that glues it all together can be found here.
item.excerpt:encoded: using Wordpress, Audio Hijack Pro and Applescript The local Campus/Community Radio Station ??? CJSW ??? has some pretty good shows but I never manage to listen to them except by accident.

item.title: Automated Podcast WordPress Posting
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
(* Version 1.0??

Copyright David Anderson

July 8, 2005

*)


property timeout_value : 60

property crlf : ";" --(ASCII character 10) --& (ASCII character 13)

property the_type : "audio/mpeg"



property theWPPostURL : "http://www.domainname.com/wp-admin/post.php"

property podcastDirectoryURL : "http://www.domainname.com/podcasts/"



set theProperties to fileProperties()

set enclosureValue to item 1 of theProperties

set enclosureDate to item 2 of theProperties

set enclosureName to item 3 of theProperties

--display dialog enclosureValue & " " & enclosureDate & " " & enclosureName

if enclosureValue is not equal to "" then

?? ?? makeWPPost(enclosureValue, enclosureDate, enclosureName)

else

?? ?? display dialog "No file with lable < 4 was found."

end if


on makeWPPost(theValue, theDate, theName)

?? ?? set theUrl to "<a href="" & podcastDirectoryURL & theName & "">Podcast of " & item 1 of explode(theName, "_") & " recorded " & theDate & "</a>"

?? ?? --display dialog theUrl

?? ?? tell application "Safari"

?? ?? ?? ?? activate

?? ?? ?? ?? try

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? make new document at the beginning of documents

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set the URL of the front document to theWPPostURL

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? delay 2

???? ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? if my page_loaded(timeout_value) is false then error "The page did not load in the indicated timeout value."

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[3].value = \"" & item 1 of my explode(theName, "_") & " " & theDate & "\"" in document 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[11].value = \"" & theUrl & "\"" in document 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? (* Set the enclosure key and value *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[32].value = \"enclosure\"" in document 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[33].value = \"" & podcastDirectoryURL & theValue & "\"" in document 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? (* Toggle check boxes *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? --do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[7].click()" in document 1 (* ALLOW COMMENTS *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? --do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[8].click()" in document 1?? (* ALLOW PINGS *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[4].click()" in document 1 (* CATEGORY 1 *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[5].click()" in document 1 (* CATEGORY 2 *)

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? do JavaScript "document.forms[0].elements[16].click()" in document 1 (* PUBLISH *)

???? ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

?? ?? ?? ?? on error the error_message number the error_number

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? -- don't display error message if the user canceled a dialog within the [try] and [on error] lines above

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? if the error_number is not -128 then

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set the error_text to "Error: " & the error_number & ". " & the error_message

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? display dialog the error_text buttons {"Cancel"} default button 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? end if

?? ?? ?? ?? end try

?? ?? end tell

end makeWPPost


on page_loaded(timeout_value)

?? ?? repeat with i from 1 to the timeout_value

?? ?? ?? ?? tell application "Safari"

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? if (do JavaScript "document.readyState" in document 1) is "complete" then

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? return true

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? else if i is the timeout_value then

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? return false

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? else

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? delay 1

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? end if

?? ?? ?? ?? end tell

?? ?? end repeat

?? ?? return false

end page_loaded



on fileProperties()

?? ?? tell application "Finder"

?? ?? ?? ?? set the source_folder to the path to sites folder

?? ?? ?? ?? set podcastFolder to the folder "podcasts" of source_folder

?? ?? ?? ?? set the_files to the contents of podcastFolder

?? ?? ?? ?? set theName to ""

?? ?? ?? ?? set theSize to ""

?? ?? ?? ?? set theProperties to ""

?? ?? ?? ?? set theCreationDate to ""

?? ?? ?? ?? repeat with myFile in the_files

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? --display dialog (the label index of myFile) as string

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? if the label index of myFile < 4 then

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set the label index of myFile to 4

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set theName to the name of myFile

???? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set theSize to the size of myFile as integer

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set theProperties to theName & ";" & theSize & ";" & the_type

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? set theCreationDate to the creation date of myFile

???? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? end if

???? ?? ?? ?? ?? ??

?? ?? ?? ?? end repeat

?? ?? end tell

?? ?? try

?? ?? ?? ?? --display dialog theProperties

?? ?? ?? ?? return {theProperties, theCreationDate, theName}

?? ?? on error

?? ?? ?? ?? return {"", "", ""}

?? ?? end try

end fileProperties


on explode(haystack, needle)

?? ?? set oldDelims to text item delimiters

?? ?? set text item delimiters to needle

?? ?? set newText to text items of haystack

?? ?? set text item delimiters to oldDelims

?? ?? return newText

end explode

item.title: I only tried once

item.title: Nanking Cherry Jelly
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
I grew up eating most anything. I'm not talking about food served at the table, but generally anything that could possibly be considered edible, I've probably tried or would be willing to try. My brother almost fooled me into taking a finger-lick of grease after he opened a new tube for the grease-gun and he told me it was chocolate pudding. I also once ate a bee that had been squished by a french dictionary and two encyclopedias (for a bit less than $10). I've eaten every sort of grass or plant imaginable. And I've tried most berries (early on I was told to stay away from Buffalo Beans - AKA golden bean/buck bean/yellow pea/Golden Pea/False Lupine). Basically, after a long hot day at the farm, anything will taste good. I can only eat a small quantity of Alfalfa before the taste starts to bother me (its rather "rich" in flavour - like its full of minerals). Pulling most any grass/grain apart will reveal a tender section that's quite pleasant. Many flowers taste OK - Roses are on the bottom of my list (but rose hips are good - esp. from the Alberta Wild Rose), Carnations are at the top. (I once played a dinner-game where the goal of the game was to eat the carnation out of the centerpiece vase without anyone outside of the participants noticing. I didn't win, and I didn't even notice the winner making the move). I've licked sap, chewed on bark, eaten leaves, you name it. But berries are the best. I once went camping with some people who wanted to go for a hike over some rolling prairie hills. Climbing out of one valley I noticed some Saskatoon berry bushes, announced their presence, and started picking and eating. The camp leaders were astonished at my stupidity - eating something that was just growing out of the hillside. They couldn't possibly fathom that something so delicious could "just grow" out in the middle of nowhere. After a great amount of convincing (backed up by the quantity I was enjoying) everyone soon began to participate. (I also love Chokecherries, but it was too early in the year for them to be ripe.) Living in France it wasn't uncommon for me to hop off my bike and just start eating the blackberries that seemed to grow on every hedgerow. They were delicious in August (and otherwise wasted). Yesterday, we went for a walk through the park, enjoying this glorious warm weather. Heading up the hill toward Dama's house, Madge spotted some Nanking Cherry bushes covered in ripe berries. (She was initially shocked as well when I claimed I recognized these "berries" several years ago and began eating them.) We used Lauryn's hat and soon had it filled with the sweet round cherries. Madge had the plan of making jelly, and this evening we followed through. It is delicious. For reference I'm listing the recipe. I think we didn't need as much pectin as the recipe calls out. (We used Bernardin Pectin - a 57g box). Next time I think we'll cut it in half and see how that does.

Nanking Cherry Jelly

  • 6 cups Nanking cherries
  • 1 cup water
  • 1 pkg powered pectin
  • 4.5 cups sugar
    Stem and wash cherries. Place in a saucepan with the water. Bring water to a boil; simmer 15-20 minutes until fruit is soft. Mash fruit to press out juice; strain. Return juice to saucepan and stir in pectin crystals. Stir over high heat until boiling. Stir in sugar and bring to a vigorous boil for 1 minute stirring constantly. Pour into sterilized jars and seal with parafin (we used boiled/sterilized snap lids).

item.title: Saturday Morning Breakfast
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Every Saturday morning we usually enjoy a good breakfast. Typically its Madge's wholesome pancakes, and Lauryn gets a novelty pancake in the shape of any animal she wishes (usually a puppy, but even lions, kangaroos, and ???). [insert pic of fancy pancake] Today we enjoyed Belgian Waffles. Yum. I figured I'd share our favorite (yet basic) recipe, and what I think is key to making good waffes.

Quick Waffles

  • 1/2 C. butter or margarine
  • 1 T. sugar
  • 4 egg yolks
  • 2 C. milk
  • 2 C. flour
  • 4 egg whites, stiffly beaten
  • 4 t. baking powder

Directions:

Melt butter; stir in the sugar and egg yolks. Beat well. Beat in milk and sifted flour; fold in egg whites and baking powder. Bake in a greased waffle iron. Store leftover waffles, wrapped in plastic wrap or foil, in refrigerator; reheat in toaster or in frying pan.

Skip's Counsel

If there is anything I learned when I briefly attended a cooking class in France, its how important good egg whites are in recipes. Even a tiny amout of yolk will keep the whites from being their stiffest. There was also something about adding salt, or cream of tartar. Evidently I don't remember all the details, except that stiff egg whites are important, that you shouldn't over-beat them, and how important it is to delicately fold them into whatever you're making. That is, I think, the secret to good waffles - good egg whites, folded in carefully. Any waffle recipe that does not include beaten egg whites isn't worth the effort (though it may be simpler). Good waffles need good whites, otherwise you might as well buy Eggo :)
On realizing that I've forgotten many of the details learned in the 5-franc-an-episode cooking class, I decided to look up the secrets to making perfect egg whites. I found a fantastic page, but despite its wonderful content, it looks awful. I plan on cleaning it up and reposting it here. Watch for it and then make perfect waffles.

item.title: Scripting Languages and Mac OS X
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: Apple has a great introduction document for the scripting languages built into Mac OS X. If you've wondered what the "Terminal" is all about or how you can easily automate processes, write simple programs, or develop dynamic websites this is probably a good place to start. It contains links to all the relevant sources of beginner information and even talks about building new versions of the tools (including grabbing source code from CVS). So if you've wondered about bash, csh, tcsh, ksh, zsh, tclsh, sed, awk, Perl, Python, php, Ruby, Fink, DarwinPorts, SourceForge, FreshMeat, autoconf, automake or CVS, give it a peek.
item.excerpt:encoded: Apple has a great introduction document for the scripting languages built into Mac OS X. If you've wondered what the "Termial" is all about or how you can easily automate processes, write simple programs, or develop dynamic websites this is probably a good place to start.

item.title: Restore Grub to Dual Boot (Windows/Ubuntu) Laptop
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Shortly after receiving a new laptop at work I went about figuring out how to resize the NTFS partition so that I could install Linux on the other half of the disk. I was going to document the process, but... Recently, however, my Windows partition was having issues so IT reinstalled XP on the first partition. This process caused my Master Boot Record (MBR) to get overwritten. My laptop no-longer knew that it could boot into either Windows or Linux (Ubuntu). I needed to restore the MBR. A bit of googling and I found this thread: http://ubuntuforums.org/archive/index.php/t-24113.html The steps that worked for me were near the bottom of the page (I've adapted them for my scenario).
  1. Boot with any live CD (I used Knoppix STD 0.1 as it has some fun tools)
  2. Get a root shell and fdisk -l /dev/hda
  3. make note of which partition is your main 'Linux' partition (mine is /dev/hda3)
  4. make a folder (mkdir ubuntu)
  5. mount the root (/) partition of ubuntu (e.g. mount /dev/hda3 ubuntu - the 'Linux' disk from fdisk)
  6. chroot the mounted partition (chroot ubuntu)
  7. grub-install /dev/hda (If you are multi-booting with Windows, make sure you do NOT install the MBR on the active partition (/dev/hda3) but on the drive (/dev/hda).)
  8. Exit the shell
  9. Reboot
item.excerpt:encoded: Shortly after receiving a new laptop at work I went about figuring out how to resize the NTFS partition so that I could install Linux on the other half of the disk. I was going to document the process, but...Recently, however, my Windows partition was having issues so IT reinstalled XP on the first partition.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: After I installed Windows XP over a previous Windows installation, I lost my bootloader so I couldn't boot into Ubuntu. Thanks to this tip, it works perfect again!

item.title: emlx vicious cycle
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: Mac OS X 10.4 Tiger is nice. I can't print to Windows printers anymore. And the Junk Mail filter for Mail causes Mail to crash. While trying to figure out what was making Mail crash incessantly, I started fresh with Mail, setting all new preferences and accounts, but I was careful to keep an old copy of my ~/Library/Mail folder so I could recover all my old sent items and whatnot. Luckily for me, the Tiger version of Mail (v2.0) won't import its own .emlx files. Talk about frustration. I moved the .emlx files around in the ~/Library/Mail folder and looked at plists but nothing would let me import or drag and drop the .emlx files into Mail itself. However, I could double-click any of the .emlx files and Mail would display them. Talk about a Jekyll and Hyde syndrome. Fortunately someone else already encountered and solved this problem. The emlx to mbox Converter will take .emlx files and save them all as a standard .mbox file the Mail can import. Ironically, Apple lists this same software on its website of Mac OS X-compatible software.
item.excerpt:encoded: I can't print to Windows printers anymore. And the Junk Mail filter for Mail causes Mail to crash.While trying to figure out what was making Mail crash, I started fresh with Mail, setting all new preferences and accounts, but I was careful to keep an old copy of my ~/Library/Mail folder so I could recover all my old sent items and whatnot.

item.title: Interesting...
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
I didn't come up with this myself. I'm just mirroring it for reference lest the original source disappear. Luckily I think I have a donor machine that's suitable, and I already have the Ubuntu Live CD (go Ubuntu!)
First of all, you can???t install OS X on a new partition, it needs it???s own drive. For this guide Im installing it on my Sony Vaio TR2A. Since I only have one harddrive, it means I???m wiping windows and all my files in the process. You can easily follow the same steps but instead install it on a second harddrive in your PC. Here is how I have succesfully install OS X x86 NATIVELY on my laptop! First of all, I think your CPU needs at LEAST sse2. For rosetta and to get itunes and other ppc apps working, you need sse3. My vaio has a Pentuim M, so no rosetta for me. Everything else works. Im posting this from the OS X x86 port of Firefox Wink 1. Download ???VMWare files for patched Mac OS X Tiger Intel??? from your favorite torrent site. (Hint: Use the search function). 2. Copy tiger-x86-flat.img from the archive to an external USB drive (it???s 6gb) 3. Download Ubuntu Live CD (link) ?? be sure you get the ???Live CD???!! 4. Burn the ubuntu iso, stick it in your pc, and boot it! (make sure you have your bios set to boot to CD) 5. Once ubuntu boots and the gui finally comes up, hook up the USB drive you copied the 6gb image to. A window should pop up showing the contents of the drive. Take note of where its mounted. It should be /Devices/Yourdrivesvolumename 6. Open a terminal window and cd to that directory (/Devices/Yourdrivesvolumename). Do an ???ls??? to make sure you are in the right place (you should see the 6gb img file. 7. In the terminal window type: dd bs=1048576 if=./tiger-x86-flat.img of=/dev/hda Replace hda with the correct drive! If you only have one drive, its probably hda. Thats what mine was. You are about to erase this entire drive so make sure youve got it right and make sure you want to do this! Hit enter. It takes a while?? took my vaio about 9 minutes. 8. When it???s done, remove the ubuntu disc and shut down the pc. Disconnect your usb drive. Thats it! When you power it back on, OS X should boot! For whatever reason, mine hangs when its loading. If this happens to you, boot with the -x option (hit a button at the darwin screen when you boot your pc. enter ???-x??? and hit enter). Should work without any problems, and I dont see any restrictions being in safe mode. You???ll notice there is a login screen, and you dont know the password! This image was created by ???deadmoo??? and we can easily change his password. Reboot the machine again. Again, hit a button at the darwin screen. This time type ???-v??? and hit enter. At the command prompt screen type: sh /bin/sh?passwd curtis?(change the password to what you like)?passwd deadmoo?(change the passwrod to what you like) Done! Now reboot once more, and again use the ???-x??? option. Everything should boot, and at the login screen enter your new password. WELCOME TO THE OS X x86 CLUB! Look ma, no vmware! Note: If you are installing this in a PC and have multiple drives, you dont need to use an external drive or linux distro. Simply dd the image in the same manner to any physical drive in your pc, and when its done boot to that drive and it should work. For windows users, there is a port of dd for windows you can use here. I messed around with this in vmware before installing natively, and I can tell you running it native is a million times faster! Its full speed. USB works, ethernet works, all the x86 software works. Enjoy!
item.excerpt:encoded: Luckily I think I have a donor machine that's suitable, and I already have the Ubuntu Live CD (go Ubuntu!)First of all, you can???t install OS X on a new partition, it needs it???s own drive.... Simply dd the image in the same manner to any physical drive in your pc, and when its done boot to that drive and it should work.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Posting this reply from a machine that succumbed easily to these directions. This machine seems very well suited to this operation as at least the wired ethernet is working properly. But a couple of hints: 1) the external USB drive (either FAT or FAT32) didn't work as there's a 2GB file size limit. I had to untar it to an ext3 drive and then copy it to an HFS+ external drive. I could have expanded it to the HFS+ drive directly... Ubuntu includes HFS+ read/write support so that worked well. 2) my drive was NOT hda so I needed to 'fdisk -l' to discover that I needed to dd to /dev/sda 3) I didn't have to do any of the Darwin boot options to change the password. It automatically logged in on boot and then using the password 'bovinity' I created myself as an admin user, logged out of deadmoo and logged back in as myself and deleted deadmoo 4) OS X is far to speedy on this Celeron M 1.3 MHz. I don't have it burdened down with all sorts of apps running simultaneously, but it makes my 1.25 GHz G4 feel 'old'

item.title: CameraPhone and iPhoto Posting
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: So Madge and I recently moved up to the world of the cell phone. I rather hate cell phones but love the principle behind SMS (txt). I think my hatred stems from how they seem to always take precedence over face-to-face conversations or situations. I dislike most any "interrupt-based" system (except in software). I much prefer the time-shifting capabilities of SMS. Messages are sent with the knowledge that I might not see it immediately and they're usually terse enough to not burn up my minutes with idle chit-chat. I'm trying to be frugal, and SMS's are the best communication value for the doller that I've found thusfar. So don't expect me to answer if you give me a voice call. (And I won't check my voicemail from the phone either - as that burns up $$$ too - if I think its urgent, I might, otherwise I'll wait 'till I can use a free landline to listen to the voicemail.) But I'm digressing. The phones themselves weren't cheap, but I told myself long ago that I wouldn't get one unless it did what I wanted. I can put any ringtone on it that I want without having to buy them from the carrier as the phones have bluetooth and integrate super-nice with our two bluetooth Macs. And a side perk is they *can* take pictures. Note to self, however, the "4x zoom" just means "ineffective crop". This is one of the non-zoomed images that Madge took of me and the girls last night at the playground. On The Unofficial Apple Weblog I saw mentioned an open-source iPhoto plugin that lets you upload pictures from iPhoto directly to your weblog. So the base of this post was made using the Photon iPhoto plugin. It does what its advertised to do but well, this post was originally just a picture and the post was titled with the name of the picture. Unfortunately, I can do the same (and more) by using ecto, as it can read the iPhoto library and post whatever pictures I want. I'm sure someone can hack the code (now that its GPL'd) so that you can post a complete gallery with a custom Title and other text. I personally would like to use this as a base for other iPhoto plugins. The action-code of a plugin wouldn't be tough for me to write, but figuring out how to get iPhoto to recognize the plugin (writing the "plugin" part) seems a little tough for me. One day I'll code in Cocoa again. One day...

The video card (sometimes referred to as the GPU) is one more vital component in any gaming rig, as it handles nearly all of the graphics for your video game titles. A person of the issues with video cards - in certain the center and minimal end ones - is that they tend to come to be obsolete faster than the other components of a gaming pc. item.title: .htaccess on OS X Server 10.4 Tiger
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: You need to create a .htaccess file in your root WordPress directory. Text edit and bbedit won't let you create files that begin with a period. What I did was search on my system for .htaccess files (you need to search for invisible files). Then make a copy of an htaccess file to your root wp directory. Open up terminal cd /library/web server/documents/path-to-your-wp-directory/ touch .htaccess chmod 666 .htaccess Open up the now writeable htaccess file with bbedit, and delete anything thats already in it. Add/change these lines to your httpd.conf file. First you'll have to change the permissions on this too to write to it. (I also changed the AllowOverride for the "/" directory to All, not sure if this is needed) <directory "/"> Options FollowSymLinks AllowOverride All </directory> Then in the sites/ directory modify the site-specific .conf <directory "/path/to/your/wp-directory/"> Options FollowSymLinks AllowOverride All Order allow,deny Allow from all </directory> Save it (first you have to change the permissions so you have access). Restart apache from terminal with sudo apachectl graceful Go into Wordpress and set up your permalinks and copy the settings to the .htaccess file. [Courtesy of WordPress Support]

item.title: Five Months
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: So ends the longest drought since I first started blogging 3.5 years ago. I moved my server, then swapped servers and ended up having a few months of DNS problems. My regular DNS hosts have now been updated and i'm toying with swapping over to the Free DNS hosting provided by xname.org so I can make any necessary changes, additions, or adjustments myself. In the meantime I've had many things I've wanted to say and I've even drafted a few that I should now be willing to post. I've also upgraded to WordPress 2.0 and have Akismet working to protect me from comment-spam. All I need now is more PC-100 (or PC-133) memory for my webserver, time to tweak my theme to add some nifty features, and time to go about getting my CJSW recording/podcasting running again.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Another DNS host you might want to look at is zoneedit.com, which is the one Tamara and I use. Welcome back!

item.title: Suggested Software - Fugu
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: For a long time I've been wanting to document software that I regularly use all the time and honestly couldn't live without. These choices can extend beyond my preferred platform, so I've created a new category, Choice Compiled Code, which I'll post each favorite under. Its possible that I'll post potential favorites here as well - software that I either want to check out or software that I've started using but that I'm not fully committed to yet. But initially I'll list one that I've used for several years. It may not have been updated recently, but I've found no show-stopping bugs either. So my first pick goes to Fugu. I enjoy doing file transfers from the command line, but this free, open-source, graphical SSH, SCP, SFTP program allows me to create bookmarks and can store passwords in the OS X Keychain.

item.title: Wordpress Install on OS X 10.4 Tiger Server
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
I found this information very useful a couple of months ago and wanted to repost it lest the original source disappear.
I've just sorted this one out myself. It seems PHP and MySQL don't communicate properly out of the box using Mac OS X 10.4 Tiger Server. Here's what to do: 1. Fire up MySQL Manager (Applications/Server/MySQL Manager) and ensure MySQL is installed. Also double check the PHP4 module is enabled in your Apache settings. If it isn't, enable it and restart the service. 2. Start up MySQL. We need to ensure that a particular SQL directory is created so we can tweak it later on. 3. Open Terminal and type sudo cp /etc/php.ini.default /etc/php.ini 4. Open /etc.php.ini in your a text editor and add /var/mysql as the default MySQL socket. It should read: mysql.default_socket = /var/mysql/mysql.sock 5. PHP should now know where to look. Make sure the directory can be read: sudo chmod 755 /var/mysql and close your text editor. 6. Type mysql -h localhost -u root -p and enter the root password. 7. Replacing the coloured text with your own choices, at the MySQL prompt, type: CREATE DATABASE wordpress; GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON wordpress.* TO word@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'password'; SET PASSWORD FOR word@localhost = OLD_PASSWORD('password'); FLUSH PRIVILEGES; 8. Point your browser to http://localhost/wordpress/wp-admin/install.php (or wherever install.php resides in WebServer/Documents). Finally, hit return and pray.
[Courtesy of macosxhints.com with the help of the Apple info database
item.excerpt:encoded: Open /etc.php.ini in your a text editor and add /var/mysql as the default MySQL socket.... Replacing the coloured text with your own choices, at the MySQL prompt, type:CREATE DATABASE wordpress;GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON wordpress.* TO word@localhost IDENTIFIED BY 'password';SET PASSWORD FOR word@localhost = OLD_PASSWORD('password');FLUSH PRIVILEGES;8.

item.title: Nigella's Brownies
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Beyond just posting about interesting software that I'm interested in or can't live without, I also like food. Actually, if I could typically go without eating, I would. But, when I'm interested in food, I quite enjoy it and especially enjoy food of quality, not necessarily quantity. So here's a recipe that I found on the Internet (via slashfood), that Madge first made, and that I've now made once (with pointers from Madge). These are, according to my tastes, very good brownies. I'd say that they're "the best ever" but that's a tough judgement call until I've tried every brownie recipe in existance. These are definitely a contender. And I expect Nigella is Nigella Lawson.

Nigella's Brownies

1 2/3 cup soft unsalted butter ???? 13 ounces (368.5 grams) of very fine chocolate (I used Lindt 70% Cocoa Chocolate - each bar is 100g, and some Chipits chocolate chips)???? 6 large eggs???? 1 tablespoon vanilla???? 1 2/3 cup sugar???? 1 1/2 cup all purpose flour???? 1 teaspoon salt???? 1 1/3 cup chopped walnuts pecans (I'd say optional) ????????Preheat the oven to 350????F. Line your brownie pan (13x9") with parchment paper. This is a little extra step but makes the brownie a breeze to get out of the pan....????????Melt the butter and chocolate together over medium-low heat. Let this cool a bit after melting. Mix together the eggs, sugar and vanilla in a large bowl. Measure the flour into another bowl along with the salt. (I used a 2 cup measuring cup and then added the salt directly to the measuring cup and stirred.) Mix together the cooled chocolate/butter mixture and the eggs/sugar mixture. Add in the nuts (I didn't - I left them out). Mix in the flour and beat to combine smoothly and scrape into lined pan.????????Bake for 25 (35-40?) minutes and be vigilant. Brownies can go from delish to dry in about 2 minutes.... They will continue to cook a bit as they cool.... 25 minutes just wasn't long enough. I ended up baking them for closer to 35-40 - until a knife could be inserted in the center and the batter would just barely cling.

item.title: Warm Chocolate Molten Cake
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
During our time in San Diego a couple (and their daughter) quickly befriended us, and gave us the opportunity to go surfing a couple of times. We always had lots of fun together and had a lot in common. After one dinner party (or other outing) the topic of desserts came up and they said they knew one of the best, richest, most delicate, dark chocolate desserts. Naturally we had to schedule a follow-up dinner party during which we made these. Thanks to Cameron and Lisa for introducing us to this one (and their hospitality). Now I just need to document the rules to their addictive dice game.

Warm Chocolate Molten Cake

Serves 4 5 oz bittersweet or semisweet chocolate chopped (145 g) 1/4 cup (1/2 stick) unsalted butter 1 tablespoon brandy (or 1 tsp rum flavoring) 2 large eggs 2 large egg yolks 5 tablespoons sugar 1 teaspoon vanilla extract Large pinche of salt (+1/8 tsp cinnamon) 1 tablespoon all purpose flour 1/2 cup chilled whipping cream 1/2 package frozen raspberries Method for the Cake: Generously butter four 3/4-cup souffl??? dishes or custard cups (ramekins to the cool kids). No flour or sugar. Arrange on baking sheet. Stir chocolate and butter in heavy small saucepan over low heat until smooth. Remove from heat; stir in brandy (rum). Cool 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. Using electric mixer, beat eggs, yolks, 4 tablespoons sugar, vanilla, cinnamon, and salt in medium bowl (about 6 minutes) Sift flour over batter; fold in flour. Fold batter in chocolate mixture Divide batter among dishes, filling completely. Can refrigerate up to 24 hours. Preheat over to 400????F. Bake cakes until tops are puffed (about 15 minutes). Cool cakes 5 minutes before turning (inverting) onto plates and serving with the following: Raspberry Coulis: De-frost raspberries and puree with 1 tablespoon of sugar. Pass through a sieve or cheesecloth to remove any seeds. Ladle sauce onto a plate and center a cake in the pool of sauce. Garnish with Confectioners sugar (icing sugar, powdered sugar) (optional) and serve with whipped cream.

item.title: Email Archiving
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: I need a way to archive email but still have it completely accessible for the future. I'd like to be able to pull all my old work email off our exchange server (and its corresponding .pst local archive) and export it (through Apple's Mail.app) to some format that I can read regardless of platform. I haven't figured out a way yet, but this might help. Mail Steward. It can export all the data (what about attachments?) to an SQL file or tab-deliminated text (among other formats). I'll have to give it a shot.
item.excerpt:encoded: I need a way to archive email but still have it completely accessible for the future.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
It sounds like you would like to archive your emails for your own future use, and not for of compliance related issues.
Most email archiving solutions would require access to your exchange environment in order to capture each email with the log file as proof of authenticity.
If your requirement is solely for own use, and not compliance there are less expensive ways of achieving this, such as forwarding all incoming and outgoing mails to a 3rd party mail system (such as gmail) for archiving and search purposes
Regards

item.title: man oh man
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: man pages are the unix word's manuals for how to do anything. If you happen to know the name of a command, but don't know how to use it, typing man command in the terminal will bring up the manual for that command. There are a bunch of shortcut keys that you can then use to move forward and backward and to search the man page, but these aren't obvious and I personally only know the basics. If you're not forced to do all your work in the terminal, a very handy app Bwana will allow you to browse man pages inside Safari. All you have to do is download Bwana and then you don't even have to launch the app. I'm not certain how its been done but all you do now is type man:command in Safari's addressbar and Bwana will do the rest. Bwana will automatically convert the man pages to HTML and show it in your Safari* window. Click on a link to another man page and the new page will show up. Bwana doesn't even show up in the dock. And its FREE! Makes me wonder what other tools could be activated in safari's addressbar. An AJAX version of ssh/scp/sftp? Now the only thing left is learning the terminal command that matches the action you want/need to take in the first place. *Also works in Firefox, Internet Explorer or Camino.
item.excerpt:encoded: man pages are the unix word's manuals for how to do anything.

item.title: expand Archive.pax.gz files
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded:
gzip -dc "/Volumes/iMac Software/System/Installation/Packages/BSD.pkg/Contents/Archive.pax.gz" | pax -r
then peek inside to see what files exist
pax -v -f Archive.pax
extract them all into the current directory
pax -r -f Archive.pax

item.title: I hate Linux, Long live Linux
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Most of all I dislike Windows. I really hope that Vista is a good upgrade because I find it deplorable that 90% of the computing world is stuck using something that I find so frustrating. I dislike the mouse acceleration. I dislike the settings windows that layer upon each other in a modal fashion, but aren't accessible via the Taskbar and are easily lost under all the other windows. I'm confused as to why, when I select "Shutdown" and I have Outlook open, I get a modal window telling me that I have to quit all Microsoft Office applications before I can shut down. Sometimes (I forget the use-case) the "kill" dialog appears saying that the application will be terminated in X number of seconds. And then there are two buttons you can click to "Quit" or "Cancel", and neither option intuitively conveys the result. Its too bad that the world has been stuck with such a poor platform. The hard-drive Explorer is the Internet explorer. Yes, you can explore both items with the same program, so I see why they did it, but honestly it was a poor decision. We are left with legions of people who have no concept of their hard-drive hierarchy (and hence fine "the computer" baffling) because the html/url content of the internet has been so confusingly mixed with file-locations. And then there's the whole hard-drive hierarchy as visually represented in Explorer. Honestly, Microsoft doesn't want to help people understand how their machine works (where their files are REALLY stored) they want to obfuscate the real location so that people don't have to know. Fine, if you really think that's simpler. But what does that do to people's perceptions when, though Desktop is shown at the top of the hierarchy, you can navigate to the same location on the hard drive via C:/Documents and Settings/username/Desktop ? Programs can install themselves and hijack the Start menus, Quick Launch area, and Open With menu, but users have to have these areas hidden from them, inaccessible unless they know more about "the computer" than the user interface teaches them? People stuck with Monitors flickering at 60 Hz, hurting their eyes without them knowing why? Why? Because the control for changing the refresh rate is buried under an "Advanced..." button's modal window full of tabs with obscure names. Do people really need to change that setting as often as they check their video driver version/parameters/IO range? That's what this setting is associated with by its location in the UI. Its so wrong. Its not enabling. That's why I dislike windows. I don't think its the best way to represent the operational abilities of a computer. I think its designed in a manner to obfuscate the paradigms upon which it is constructed. I think that, yes, people don't need to understand all the underlying intricacies, but people should be able to understand the basic concepts if they are represented in an intuitively logical manner. That's why the GUI has persisted for more than 20 years as the interface of choice (well, a little less than that in the Windows world). Power users use the command line, but who uses DOS these days? People use the graphical user interface in most instances because it makes the most sense. No other paradigm makes sense to the average person. Those who understand the underlying concepts can be at home on the CLI (Command Line Interface), but people who think that Desktop is the "root" (base) of their computer would be (and are) horribly confused when they open the Windows command line, cmd, and try to do anything (other than run ipconfig). I work with technical people. They understand how radio frequency (RF) communication works. They understand the technical details that are far beyond my understanding. But they don't understand how to use their computer (no offense intended). There's a set of operations that they use every day that work for them, but when things go awry, they're completely lost. And I don't blame the users, I blame the designers of the interface they're forced to use. This horrible interface is, unfortunately, the best that is available to them, and for this reason I hope Vista is an improvement, and not just further obfuscations and eye-candy. So with this introduction, I'll continue onward with my intended topic. Linux. I love linux. It lets me do things in a way that Windows doesn't allow (or is inconvenient in Windows). I recently acquired a new laptop at work. Its an LG LM70 Express. A slick, thin, powerful, well designed laptop who's only deficiencies are a really poor LCD and no built-in option for bluetooth. The LCD is not the now-normal "widescreen" aspect ratio, and the color clarity and "evenness" of the pixels is despicable. Any solid color on the screen is not a homogenous "blue" or "white" but a heterogeneous amalgam of shades of blue or grey. Every pixel is a different shade of the intended color. And I'm not used to the keyboard layout, but that's inconsequential. I use Windows when I have to. I go out of my way to use OS X or Linux if at all possible, so as not to have my frustrations with Windows affect my daily outlook and attitude. It really bothers me that much, probably because I know there's a better way. I have no problem with other people enjoying Windows, until I'm forced to help people who wouldn't need help if the system they're stuck using wasn't so disabling. So with the transition to a new laptop comes the necessity of three things. 1) Resize the NTFS (Windows) partition on the hard drive so I can install Linux on half of the hard drive and use either Windows or Linux. 2) Install Linux - Ubuntu is my Linux distribution of choice. 3) Install all the Linux apps I need and get everything configured as needed to be productive. Ubuntu is great at getting most things setup right from the start, but there are always things I need to tweak. I decided to try out the preview version of the next version of Ubuntu (Breezy Badger is the name of the next version - due out in a couple of weeks). It is supposed to have the capability of resizing a Windows partition during the installation process so that it can automatically convert a Windows-only machine into a Windows/Linux machine without the need of reinstalling Windows or losing any data. But, being a preview, this function didn't work on my specific laptop. I can't completely fault Ubuntu, as this LM70 with a fairly new chipset, no cardbus slot (just ExpressCard) and a SATA hard drive. Other Linux LiveCD's wouldn't boot my machine, so I must be near the bleeding edge. It's actually been some time since I started writing this and honestly can't remember what all I had to do to get Ubuntu running on the LM70. Either way, I much prefer Linux to Windows (Linux warts and all). But I dislike Windows, and really hope for all those (poor?) Windows users that Vista is better. Unfortunatly, I think some of the fundamental User Interface design principles are what disturb me, and that they will still be an disagreeable part of Vista.
item.excerpt:encoded: Most of all I dislike Windows. I really hope that Vista is a good upgrade because I find it deplorable that 90% of the computing world is stuck using something that I find so frustrating.

item.title: Finding Nemo
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: Ok, none of the various computers I use at work or at home are named Nemo. I've tried to name my computers, but I guess I'm not apt to anthropomorphize. Or, perhaps I just fill my life with too many dumb computers to truly enjoy any of them to the point of naming them. Recently I think I had 9 laptops in my cubicle and two desktops. Really I only use three machines. I take my 1.25 GHz Mac Powerbook with me most everywhere I go. Its my preferred computing tool and preferred OS. I also have a 2 year old Dell D800 and a 4 month old LG LM70. Both machines I've made dual-boot Windows and Ubuntu Linux. My trouble is that I want to VPN into the office network from home or when travelling and have difficulty discovering these machines. So these are just some notes as to how I can potentially discover a machine. avahi-publish-service "Desktop SSH" _ssh._tcp 22 http://avahi.org/wiki/Avah4users http://www.google.com/search?q=avahi+publish+ssh+service&hl=en&lr=&client=safari&rls=en&start=10&sa=N http://www.livejournal.com/community/evan_tech/153727.html http://www.tildesoft.com/Programs.html Or just try http://ettercap.sourceforge.net/index.php until I find a MAC address that I know, or is there some way to search a network for a MAC address and find out its IP Or try building http://angst.sourceforge.net/ using http://libpcap.darwinports.com/ and http://libnet.darwinports.com/ Built it but not sure if its working... Try http://freequaos.host.sk/arpwatch/ instead looks like arpwatch (the original version) is in darwinports http://arpwatch.darwinports.com/ or could try http://www.sc.isc.tohoku.ac.jp/~hgot/sources/trackpeer.html
item.excerpt:encoded: Ok, none of the various computers I use at work or at home are named Nemo.

item.title: The Tardiness Never Ends
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Apart from having coworkers attempt to refer to me as AL (always late) I've also been horrible about expressing myself by way of this site. Its a sad, typical statement, but I've been busy. Riding home (aka. to the hotel) on the train in Korea seems to be the first chance I've had to indulge in some one-sided communication. As a general reminder, I should, in the following days, write about
  • The circumstances of the trip (everything that came together and everything I'm missing)
  • World Cup in Korea
  • Visiting the DMZ
  • "All my children"
  • Sushi!!! (o-sho)
  • and more that I can't recall at the moment...
The trip has been great thusfar. A bit less work perhaps than other instances. The company has been great and I've been able to work on a nifty little python program for pouring through datasets and making information more presentable (easier to interpret with less work). Now I just need to figure out how to wrap a gui on it and distribute it for OS X and Windows. I'll be the only one here from the company starting tomorrow - so hopefully everything works out well with the plan for the rest of the week. I'm also hoping to publish some things I've started writing (but never completed) months ago. Hopefully the flurry of activity will set a new trend. I also should take the time to post some galleries of pictures. sk][p

item.title: Circumstance and Consequence
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: So I've known for a long time that my company would be introducing a new product into production some time this summer season, but not specifically when. Of my group, I made the last trip to Korea - to help introduce a product of which I wasn't involved in the design. So when this product, of which I was deeply involved, was coming up for a pre-production run in Korea at the end of June, I didn't much want to go and feared that I would be the one to get asked. That was, until I learned more of the circumstances of the world around me. You see, the last time I came to Korea, I swore that the next time I would make use of the opportunity and travel to neighbouring Bejing and visit my brother-in-law (whom I've know longer than Madge). Well, Mennipus was going to be travelling back to Canada around the same time as the possible trip to Korea, but he would be returning to Bejing sooner than his wife and there was a slight possibility that he'd be back in Bejing before I needed to leave Korea. Some quick emails and calendar examination later showed that if I managed to both delay and extend a trip to Korea, I could fly into Bejing the same day as Mennipus. So I volunteered for the job. Everyone at work was surprised that I signed up and I openly stated my reasoning, intentions, and that I figured that due to the nature of the product and my involvement, that I likely would have been asked (to which I was told that my Manager didn't have anyone specifically in mind). And then it struck me. My brother Jon had been talking of travelling (to Cuba) but has also had an interested in cultural "specialties" of China and North Korea. So I invited him to come along. So 11 days after leaving for Seoul, we're now leaving for a week in Bejing. This will have been a pretty long trip away from home - almost three weeks. I most certainly owe Madge for the opportunity - especially given that I'll be hanging out with her brother, whom she misses and would love to spend more time with. The trip hasn't been without sacrifices (for her or me). About two months ago I started training to run in a 10K road race on July 1 in my home town. I've been mixing biking to work with twice-weekly lunchtime soccer games, and once a week runs home from work (approx. 8K). I'd hoped to do 10K in under 45 minutes and was well on my way to doing so. I would also be missing World Cup and the first 10 days of the Tour de France ??? two sporting events both Madge and I look forward to enjoying together. I would also miss my 1st of July hometown celebration - specifically sharing the quaint parade with my two little girls and visiting with my family. But now Isopraxis and I have seen many of the sights of Seoul. I was obligated to work for all except two days - but we made the most of those. Look for future posts to describe our exploration of Seoul and its surroundings. So now for another cultural shift and off to the "madness" of Bejing. I've been to China twice before, but this will be my first visit to someplace other than Hong Kong/Dongguan/Shenzen. But the rather fortunate part is how well this whole trip has come together - despite the sacrifices involved. Its had been fortuitous that I both delayed my arrival (vs. the others from work who came as well), and that I stayed longer. I was able to ensure proper testing completion and shipment of all produced units. Along the way I've written a tool to parse through testing-results files and was able to use this to give my counterparts of the manufacturing facility a breakdown of all the testing-failures encountered. I was also able to meet up once again (for the third time out of three trips) with my University friend Eric (who is from Korea and now lives in Seoul). We went out for a great Korean BBQ and then made a trip on the tram up Namsang peak to Seoul Tower. The only time he gets out to see interesting stuff in Seoul is when I come into town! :) (Next time I want to go with him to Panjegumon (sp?) where the Korean War Armistice was negotiated and signed. And I have to send him both the pictures from this and my last trip (and somehow find my old pictures from my first trip).

item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Bejing?
Dirty.
Dirty and dirty, more, and more dirty.
The air is dirty the sky is dirty the buildings and people and cars are dirty. Everything is dirty.
Dirty dirt, dust, soot and dirt Fumes, pollutants, irritants and dirt Dust and sand and grit...
Sweat and grit, mixing and burning.
Eyes burning. Lungs burning. Burning, burning.
Short of breath - can't escape it. Cannot breathe. Suffocating.
Aching Nausea Dirty Burning
Ancient places - dirty, grimey. Picturesque view - grey and bleak Hot, sweaty, humid, moist Musty, dirty, rotting, dirty
Throngs and throngs, Hassles and throngs. Broken-english, persistent, intrusive. Ever-present annoyance
More and more and more to see. All the same - grey and dirty. Grimey and dirty and smelly and awful. Unique, special, amazing - but awful.
Funny how it changes your mood, Makes you ill Makes you move.
Back to the cleanliness Air and room Takes an hour, or more and more Better than swelter, ozone, monoxide Recovery - repeat?

item.title: The Great Shopping Wall of China
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Went to The Wall today. It was a blessedly wonderful day. The winds must have changed as the air was much clearer, even in the heart of the city. Our english speaking driver took us the scenic route to the part of The Wall he said was the best. Naturally the drive was, well, Chinese. No other driving I've seen yet matches the uniqueness of being driven in China. We almost hit a cyclist - an older woman who decided to ride across the road without looking. Luckily our driver swerved into the oncoming lane of traffic to miss her. I'm not sure why he didn't swerve to the right... And on we drove towards clearer air, and mountains that came into view. We arrived at a section of the wall only 640 years old. It is flanked by older sections and we walked almost all of the younger portion. It was amazing. Unique and like nothing I've seen before or will see in the future. Off in the distance you can see it wind across the tops of the mountain range. On the most incredible precipices it continues to wander with outposts every 100 meters or so. Regardless of the steepness of the hillside it climbs. Steep, steep steps. We climbed and walked and climbed and descended. The sun beat down and we enjoyed it. The air was fresh and clear and clean(er?). The breeze through the parapets was refreshing. It was nice - I'd go again. And then we descended on an alpine slide. In my youth I'd seen the Sesame Street closing with an adult and child gliding down an alpine slide. I've always wanted to ride one and now I have. It was great fun - I love things like that. My brother slid faster and caught me. But I was enjoying it and not poking along. I enjoyed the curves and their acceleration. At each major corner an "attendant" of sorts, stood or sat with a megaphone and shouted out "slow down". Given that this is China, I'm sure people have been hurt. You likely don't have much recourse, and there's no specific protective mechanism, so I appreciate that they at least have guards on watch for the spills. Back down the hill and line of market-huts stood, showing their wares and hoping you'll heed their calls. Even if you pause for but a moment, to look for something new amongst the same trinkets, they attack and impede and obligate a response. If you ask the price you receive one greatly inflated. All the better for those unaware of the real price. They want you to bargain and the game's in their favour. A cheap item they've sourced for 5 they ask 150. You start "low" and they descend. But they want you to go up for every amount that they descend - hence the astronomical prices. But I held fast to my realistic price - and gave up 5 once. She descended from 150 to 90. Then to 80. She wanted me to come up but I gave her my honest price and said "No thanks." It turning to go she continued to impede me, and dropped down to 45. I stuck to 35 and she asked me to give up 5 more. My wallet was truly empty, and I really only wanted to get a price benchmark. So I said no once more and turned to go. Her neighbour - their being few other tourists around and with all the racket the first was making - came with her own, only bigger and nicer. And offered me my asking price. But amid the confusion I turned and escaped, but up the hill I met a bigger battle. Mon fr?re had happened upon a Mao-printed bag. I figured it fancied him and didn't want him fleeced. She started at 180 and he said 80, but I felt it was too much and hadn't arrived in time. She agreed and I knew she was getting a good markup and I think I interjected. He said no and we managed to escape - despite her claims that a deal had been made. And down the hill we went to find our driver. As we turned toward the tea-house, she shouted 40. She evidently wanted to make the sale. I'd already soured her by getting involved in the attempted-fleecing, but I wasn't going to let her pushy demeanour win. So I switched to French (her English was too good), and told my brother to "Say 30". It was obvious to me that if she would jump down to 40, that she had margin left and we had room to bargain again. Her face turned sour as she knew I was helping. Helping her lose in a language she couldn't follow. But he wouldn't speak (or was just saying no), so I said it instead. She knew she was had. She claimed it was too low, but I knew that it wasn't. I told her that if she'd jumped down to 40 then that wasn't too low. And she got really bitter and told me that I was crazy and that I wasn't welcome in China and that I shouldn't ever come again. But along the way she agreed to 30 and amid the confusion and her worked-up state, she dropped her pen and I found a wonderful opportunity to get back at her. I quickly stooped and picked up her pen, and held it out to her with two joined hands and a bowed head. Her ugly, disgusted, enraged face disappeared, and she momentarily smiled and embarrassed smile. She could see I wasn't the bad-nasty she was accusing me to be - and I knew that I hadn't been evil in sticking my ground and asking for 30. But once the transaction was gone, she attacked me again with the same line of words. " You're not welcome in China! Don't back come again." And she turned and left. I wanted to tell her "I love you too", but didn't. She was gone. She'd shouted to save face, perhaps. But the best was still to come. As we turned to leave, a shop-keeper above us was smiling and clapping - we'd drawn a crowd and they were pleased with the performance.

item.title: Long time, long time...
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Been weeks and weeks since I've written anything. Since I was in China.
Much has been going on and finally I'm starting to take care of some of the smaller, day-to-day tasks which have been building up.
Hopefully I'll be able to write on a more frequent basis. I have a build-up of posts that I'll likely post in one swoop. Some might be incomplete thoughts, but i need to get them out.
The biggest project I've about finished (just waiting on final approval) is a video project that I shot, edited, wrote the music to, and made all the motion graphics for. It was recently shown at a relevant conference in Scotland where it was well received. Unfortunately, though its within my capacity to do such work, its a heavy workload to deal with "on the side."
I have other "on the side" projects which are better suited to working on at random times and places and on this notebook (as opposed to a dedicated desktop editing station).
Wish I could post the video - but I can't.
... more to come ...

item.title: Programamming
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: When I first went to university, I very soon had two favorite classes. The one involved coming up with an idea - a solution to a problem - and documenting it (why, how, the solution would work, etc). The second, was a class in TurboPascal. I ate it up. The language was ok, but mildly frustrating as I remember it. I didn't have a completely clear understanding of why and how, but I found it very magical to create. I could create - create anything I wanted or anything I could use the language to create (as languages, of all types, can easily become barriers unless you learn to properly employ them). I'd been timid as a child. Intimidated by my peers, by my siblings, and by my surroundings. In my own element, where I found myself somewhat in control or completely knowledgeable about the subject at hand, I could find myself at ease, but apart from at the farm, or outside the classroom, I was out of my element. My peers, and siblings (and their offspring) found my excellence in the classroom as perhaps intimidating, or perhaps insulting or unworthy of recognition. But if that's one of two places where you find yourself at ease, its nigh impossible to stop performing well. Its not a question of impressing the right people, but, in my situation, any positive reinforcement feels wonderful. I the business world, at least in my business world, I've found that excellence is rewarded, complemented, and appreciated. As a youth it lead to hostility, insult, jealousy, contempt and disrespect. Certainly, in the business world, these negative results can still be experienced, but I'd vouch to say that they emanate from adult bodies with insecure youths trapped inside. But university is a place to be tried, rewarded, insulted, and generally instilled (tuned) with knowledge, ability, and understanding. And so I found comfort in creation. At first it was the simple ability to run a program - a simple program that put words on a screen. Any words I commanded the machine to put on the screen would be displayed (if I held to the rules - the syntax - of the language). Yet my confidence and focus in university were battered and I let myself down. I didn't have the faith in myself that I could understand if I put in enough effort. So I didn't apply the necessary time on one lab that came back to haunt me in the final. My marks suffered and I left "First Year" with the desire to do something different. Two years in France gave me a chance to learn - to learn about myself, about other people, about the world, and about where I found work most enjoyable. Again it was in front of a computer. This time the language was different - it was data organization and representation. Yet the task was the same - improvement. Using the computer to improve a process, simplify, reduce labour. I am a machine. I live to improve. Improvement comes through creation. I am creation. So I returned to university. I had worked, in the best and worst conditions all at the same time, in France and found confidence and ability and understanding in myself. I found my strengths. My patience and determination were improved. I found faith in myself and tolerance in my surroundings and peers. Their words would no longer stick to me. Though they may hurt - sting for a moment - I gained resilience and confidence. I retook classes that challenged me before and prevailed. And I took a new programming class. C++ Those three syllables had been ominous to the old me - something beyond my abilities or opportunities. Like Calculus to Arithmatic, C++ to Pascal was seen, by the old me, as a higher level - a challenge that would surely be demeaning and frustrating, not something I would enjoy. And yet, given the opportunity to receive instruction, I latched on and have not yet been filled. Soon I found myself using language constructs the instructor did not understand or appreciate and I found myself yet again conversing with the instructor (or teacher in the more youthful days) over how I was indeed correct. Another year of school and the language became more clear and my abilities grew. Year over year I learned and grew and created. Soon it was another language, and another. Then it was how ALL languages work. And on reaching that point, the language specifically ceased to be important, as fitting the appropriate language to the problem at hand became more fun. Using the language that made the act of creation easier, or more enjoyable, is what happens now. But the task is always the same. Solving the problem. Creating the solution. Improving the process. Yet software development is a hobby - a side-project. My skills improve in many areas, and as long as I learn and improve, I am happy. But I do not shake this software addiction - nor do I want to. (Originally written on a train to Seoul Nov 9 2005)
item.excerpt:encoded: When I first went to university, I very soon had two favorite classes. The one involved coming up with an idea - a solution to a problem - and documenting it (why, how, the solution would work, etc).
