item.title: Vesperous Gigabit Ramblings
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: I've been slowly transitioning how this site is hosted over the course of the past couple of weeks. This meant that I was offline for a while, but I'm back. A couple of years ago, back when I was in San Diego, my old reliable tower (that'd I'd slightly overclocked years before) stopped functioning properly. I ended up ordering a BTO G5 tower - a single processor one, and it was nothing but problems for the first year - until a firmware fix came out to solve the random crashes that would occur. In fact, dispute over the whether the machine was faulty or not has caused me to have negative memories about visiting the local Apple Store for support. The Genius I got stuck with played a power-trip instead of listening to reason - but 9 months later Apple proved my assertions correct... Too bad that 'Genius' likely never connected my dispute to the later firmware release. But seriously, who ever heard of a computer spontaneously freezing because a 19" VGA CRT was used, not an Apple DVI LCD? But this isn't what I was intending to write about. So the old tower that I'd written off for dead, forcing me to acquire the lemon G5, has recently been brought back to life and it seems to run great. Its only got 128 MB of RAM and a 10GB disk, but its serving a couple of sites and running smoothly. Another couple of drives and more memory will give me a decent backup-repository and continue serving a few pages. But I've had an Intel Pro/1000 MT Desktop Gigabit Ethernet adapter sitting in an unused Linux firewall box for more than a year. So I threw it in this old tower and naturally OS X didn't include a matching driver. But from this Intel Pro/1000 support page I discovered a 3rd party source for OS X drivers for Intel. Small Tree Communications appears to sell custom versions of the Intel Gigabit Ethernet Cards for OS X boxes. I'm not sure what's special about the Small Tree ones versus the off-the-shelf-at-the-local-OEM-supply-store cards, but Small Tree does have their own Gigabit Ethernet Driver for OS X. Naturally the set of cards supported isn't listed - they likely only support the cards they sell, and my specific card wasn't even listed on the Intel Support site (my card's Device IDs wasn't listed). But I gave it a shot. I installed the driver and, nope, the card didn't work. I looked around some more and found that the cards the Small Tree driver supported used the same Intel 82541PI Gigabit Controller as found on my card. So I figured that the only thing keeping the driver from working on my card was a driver matching failure. I tweaked a couple of the .kext's Info.plist files within the driver bundle to include my card's PCI Device and Vendor IDs and rebooted. (Note, OS X's system profiler identified my card as having a Vendor ID of 0x8086 and a Device ID of 0x1076 and the Info.plists need these in a combined format of 0x10768086 in order to match.) Voila! I now had gigabit ethernet working in a G4 450 tower that had been sitting abandoned for almost two years. Two NICs will get me a proper firewall with VPN access to my home network. Color this geek satisfied.

item.title: Email is a Hammer
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Give an active kid a hammer and what will they do? Use it on everything in sight. With no boundaries or rules in place, everything is subjected to the hammer's usefulness, because it is such a wonderful and marvelous tool toy. Email is a hammer. I was on the internet for the first time back in 1995 and I had just started my university career. It was the heady days of Pine (for email), Finger (for finding if people were online), Gopher (for searching), and the Usenet (mmm... alt.caving). Browsing the web was done only in text. And getting "online" meant using telnet from within the school network or a dial-up connection. One of the first friends I met in class was a fellow with a penchant for forwarding emails. Email was this brand new toy and we were all excited to use it, though we only had each other to talk to. (We all checked email in the same room at the same time.) I very soon was known in class by my username, probably because we saw each others' addresses so often. Forwarded emails became a staple of our diet. My friend had his network of friends who would send him everything they received, and he on to us. It was pretty cool and a lot of fun... for about three weeks. After a relatively short period of time, the novelty began to wear off and these endless forwards became quite tarnished. It became very obvious that many of the "feel good" stories were nothing more than well-crafted lies, and the threads of jokes went from poor to worse (especially the ASCII animated ones where you hold down the spacebar to achieve animation). Years later the cycle continues, and for some it never ends. Honestly, I don't know how people have the time (or interest) to read (and then forward) all the garbage that passes through their mailboxes. Perhaps this is why spam is successful. Lonely, unbusy people, enjoying the novelty of this new hammer, expecting everyone to have the time (or interest) to read whatever "feel good" scam comes their way. Bang, Bang, Bang... Forward, forward, forward... Please, before you waste my (or others') time, do be considerate and research the background on the latest "hot" story to hit your inbox. Search for it in Snopes, and more often than not you'll find its a hoax. And yes, there are legitimate articles that may be of benefit to me or to others. Forgive me if I never read them or never respond to them. If it doesn't interest me at that moment, chances are I'll never look at it again. I'd much rather prefer a personalized communication than something you received and think I'll be interested in. Or at least preface it with a personalized note and high-level synopsis. I don't want to read 2/3 only to discover that its a complete waste of my time. If you can sum it up in one sentence, and that sentence is appealing, I'm probably 10 times more likely to read-on. Last but not least. Email generally is not the best mechanism for distributing cool videos to your friends. Find it on youtube.com or video.google.com (or post it there) and send me a description and link. My mailbox has a finite size, and I process (and store) a lot of email. Please don't flood me and make legitimate messages bounce. (...directed at no one in particular. Just an observation and personal declaration.)

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
You're totally right. Email is free and easy, and therefore abused. Back in the day of snail mail, you wouldn\'t photocopy your favorite story or an interesting ad you found in the mail and send it to all your friends. To do so would cost time and money for stamps - a nice deterrant. Although, rarely, there WERE people that sent those abhorrent "chain letters" that you had to add your name at the bottom, copy and mail to 10 friends. They went along with all the warnings of "bad luck" coming to those who broke the chain. Well I, for one, broke the chain every time - and I've had pretty good luck my whole life.
Unfortunately, email gives these (crazy?/bored?) people an easy way to play their little game - and wastes a lot of time and inbox space for the rest of us. There ARE good uses for a hammer - every house needs one, but one ought to be discriminating with its use. One man's "feel good" is another (wiser?) man's trash.

item.title: No news is... news?
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: For all those who voted on when our baby would arrive, most of you surely didn't win. He's hanging on inside longer than any of us expected, though we all doubt he'll hold out until Monday. At least his birthday won't fall on our anniversary or Sophie's birthday. Our midwives joke that, "It takes longer to make the handle".

item.title: On the move
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: No, I'm not moving, but I finally after about a year of downtime got my podcast server running again. That is, I'm timeshifting CJSW so that I can listen to my favorite shows in a time-delayed fashion - subscribing to my own podcast. Use this URL in iTunes to subscribe: feed://skip.skipandmadge.com/?feed=rss2&cat=10 I'll be experimenting for the next few weeks on exactly what shows I'm going to grab as some old favorites have been replaced. It also turns out that some of the last shows I recorded last year never got posted correctly. I've fixed most of them and they're now available anything October 2006 or later is new.

item.title: Parallels Desktop 5580 on Leopard
item.dc:creator: skip
item.category: Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
Mac OS X Tips, Tricks and Taunts
item.content:encoded: So I tried to install the latest RC of Parallels Desktop (5580). Naturally the installer failed. I'm not much of a person to accept failure, so I launched Console.app and took a look at install.log. Quite soon it was evident that the preflight script was hanging while trying to unload/delete files that might be present from a previous install. This was a fully clean install so the preflight had issues unloading a driver that didn't exist! (doh!) preflight[432]: grep: /Applications/Parallels/Parallels.app/Contents/Info.plist: No such file or directory preflight[432]: preflight[432]: /Volumes/Parallels Desktop/Install Parallels Desktop.pkg/Contents/Resources/preflight: line 82: /Library/StartupItems/Parallels/Parallels: No such file or directory preflight[432]: preflight[432]: kextunload: /Library/StartupItems/Parallels/Pvsvnic.kext: no such bundle file exists So I copied the installer from the disk image to my desktop, open the package and tweaked the preflight: kextunload /Library/StartupItems/Parallels/Pvsvnic.kext sleep 1 turned to #kextunload /Library/StartupItems/Parallels/Pvsvnic.kext #sleep 1 Success!!!

item.title: Running - August 19, 2008
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
I'm running either a 22K or 10K in about 6 weeks so I need to train up for it. I'm not in horrible shape but I haven't been as intense over the summer as summers past. Now its time to change.
Here are some notes from a 10K I did at lunch.
10K run Aug 19, 2008
Started from Novatel office, first 1 KM was tight and slow at 5:30 After coming down the hill felt good and set pace 5:00 @ 170 bpm Listening to Portishead album Third. Good accompanyment
Decided at 3 km to do full 10 k (Split rock flat route) as felt good At 5 km left knee started to hurt and be sore as climbed hill from Nose Creek valley through split rock At 7 km legs started to tighten up. At 8 km left knee started feeling better and legs felt better, but slowed off pace to 5:25 At 9 km pushed back up to 5:00 for 1/2 a km. Felt good but at slow pack.
Plan Soccer tomorrow, long slow run the next day Or hills and sprints
Long run on Saturday morning from 6:00 to 8:00

item.title: DTM ideas
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: DTM with webkit integrated - get use Webkit (canvas tag) for the UI? Canvas could be used for the graphing I think. Should prototype a way to do this...

item.title: Running - Aug 21, 2008
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Set out to do a "recovery" run. Figured out that for a maximum 192 bpm heart rate:
  • VO2 Max (Maximum Effort) 192 - 173 bpm
  • Anaerobic (Hardcore Training) 173 - 154 bpm
  • Aerobic (Cardio Training / Endurance) 154 - 134 bpm
  • Weight Control (Fitness / Fat Burn) 134 - 115 bpm
  • Moderate Activity (Maintenance /Warm Up) 115 - 96 bpm
These were calculated using 10% ranges of my maximum bpm. There are other calculation mechanisms, though the feeling within the top three ranges is about right. So I ran trying to stay in the Aerobic range the entire time. I ended up walking up some hills to keep my heart rate down. Running back to the office with the brisk wind of a storm at my back felt great. I think I was able to run at a better pace but still at the same heart rate. I'll need to track my run-at-specific-heart-rate 10K time to see if it shifts over the next few weeks. At about 8.5 k my butt was feeling sore. For all the biking/soccer/running of the past few days my legs felt pretty good. My left knee was still a bit sore but icing it and keeping the intensity of my runs down should help things start feeling better. Weight at start of run: 172 lbs Weight at end of run: 170 lbs

item.title: Soccer - August 20, 2008
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded:
Played 4 on 4 soccer. Left knee had fluid under the bottom of the kneecap from running yesterday. Knee was a bit tender until I warmed up. Even then I was careful about it. My watch said I ran just over 3 km during the 45 minute match.
Tried to take it easy. Could still sprint and felt ok but generally my legs felt empty from the hard run yesterday.
Iced my knee at night. Swelling/fluid went down and felt good the next morning.

item.title: Why?
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: So I've done this blog thing, off more than on, since July 2002. July 2002 was the summer I got a job working for a software startup on the U of C campus after being laid off from gig as an internship student. Originally I used it to voice opinions, list neat things I discovered or figures out, as a memo pad for my own future reference, and as a public diary of family events and happenings. Turns out I'm not willing to dedicate the time each day/week/month to actually make updates. Mostly the site gets used as a repository of time-shifted radio podcasts as my way of discovering new music on my own schedule. So what do I want this to become? I guess I'll have to decide or forever this will languish. Mostly it seems to be for introspection. A spot to vent and explain myself no to one in particular. Presumably this will help me understand myself better? I'd say more about day-to-day happenings, but some stuff I want to keep private, and other things I can't really talk about because they are work-related. It was nice to get a "why blog" reminder from papahashi.blogspot.com. I started this for a reason, and that reason really hasn't ever gone away. (And being able to blog from my phone eliminates most other excuses about "inconvenient" etc. I should do this instead of Sol Free solitare. )

item.title: Sick kids
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: For the past several weeks the kids have been taking turns being sick. Mostly Erik has had a runny nose and cough, but Rhys and Soph have had their turns being fevered, throwing up, and trying to recouperate. It will be nice when everyone us feeling better and the weather is nice. Just need it to rain instead of the impending snow.

item.title: Too dry
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: It's been beautiful weather the past few days. Today it was better than 20 C. But we need rain. Rhys, Erik and I went to the playground. Rhys makes friends wherever he goes. A mom was being a "monster" to her daughter and soon Rhys was chasing the "mean monster" and hugging her legs. When they left, he went to the gap in the fence and waved. Erik, however, is afraid of the grass.

item.title: Planes, trains but no automobules
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: As Brenda, the kids and I left for the Calgary airport it was a badly-needed, heavy spring rain. Shortly after boarding the plane the rain turned to thick, heavy snow. Because of the snow, we had to wait for our turn to get de-iced. It took so long to get de-iced and the snow was so heavy that we needed a second de-icing. 45-55 minutes had already passed. We waited another 30 minutes to get de-iced the second time Finally the process was over and we started to move. 2 hours and 15 minutes later than scheduled we finally taxied to the runway and departed. I had booked a train ticket to Karlsruhe from the Frankfurt airport. The train was scheduled to leave at 13:54. The flight was originally scheduled to arrive at 11:20, but with a 2:10 delay I didn't expect to arrive until 13:30, leaving 25 minutes to deplane and collect my single piece of baggage. Leaving the plane at 13:35 I hurried through immigration and was the first person to the luggage turnstile. The priority bags started arriving just as I did, but by then it was 13:50. 15 minutes later my bag was the first non-priority bag to arrive (a 10 minute break between priority and non). I grabbed my bag and hurried to the train station, a 2 minute walk. I knew I had missed my train before confirming it by looking at the departure board. A few minutes later (14:11) I had paid 28 and was scheduled to take a 14:51 train to Mannheim where I had 12 minutes to switch platforms and take a second train to Karlsruhe. After waiting on the platform for 45 minutes the departure board on the platform was updated. The train to Mannheim was delayed by 45 minutes and would make me miss my connection. Up the escalator I confirmed that I could take a direct train to Karlsruhe at 15:54, and that my updated ticket was an open ticket that required no further changes. So a 2 hour delay in Calgary has propagated into a second 2 hour delay in Frankfurt. We'll see how things go once I get to Karlsruhe. "Fun!"

item.title: Inter City Express
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Now I'm on the train. It seems to have been oversold to people like me without a reservation. All the seats appear to be reserved and full (a red LCD shows between which cities the seat is reserved). I get to stand in the entryway for the 1 hour ride to Karlsruhe with about 10-15 other people. On a straightaway the train gets up to 200km/h. A large LCD just inside the door (on which I lean) alternates between showing the cities the train will stop at (and train and wagon number), and the current speed and time. The countryside is whipping past but it really doesn't feel that fast, probably because of how smooth the ride is. Without the display I would not have guessed the rate of travel. Unlike our drive north to Minden (near Hannover), the land boardering the train line appears to be flat, fertile farmland. North of Frankfurt by car was quite hilly and forested with the exception of the small flat valleys surrounding the small towns. After the exchange of passengers at Mannheim the train as full or more full than before. It's great to see how many people use public transportation like this. A train between Calgary and Edmonton like this would be great, but only if the supporting public infrastructure within the city is sufficient to get people to their final destination. The expanded CTrain in Calgary is good, but still may not be sufficient. For example, the Ctrain does not go to the airport. Boo. Just passed a pair of cooling towers for a nuclear power plant about halfway between Mannheim and Karlsruhe. The land is still pretty flat. Where there are no trees you can see quite far.

item.title: Ice Cream
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Karlsruhe is very calm and pleasant this Sunday afternoon. Going for a walk back to the market square to find some dinner. It is warm and a bit humid. Very green and I'm pleasantly amazed at how many bicycles there are. More bikes than cars it seems. Sunday must be ice cream day. That is about all people are eating, and there are lineups to get it. I didn't buy any. Monday morning walk. More cars, but still lots of bikes. Lady riding bike with cocker(?) in the basket behind the seat. Have not seen a single person with a helmet. Even the postmen ride bikes. Unlike France, no dogs on the street. I didn't sleep horribly well. Too warm and my body didn't think it was the middle of the night. Finally a rain shower came by and the tapping of the drips distracted me from the guy snoring in the room next door. Woke up at 8:00 and felt pretty good despite the wakeful night. By 11:30 AM I'm feeling pretty bleary. I finally found free WiFi so I'm making use of it. Too bad it's a 20 minute walk from the hotel.

item.title: Run [through the] Forest, Run
item.dc:creator: skip
item.content:encoded: Tonight we're having a joint dinner with the other half of the two-part team I'm on at our hotel. Once we finished our meetings for today I had two hours of spare time, and because I was too tired to run this morning, I decided to run in the heat (26 C). So I headed off on the route I took two mornings ago and then 2km along the way I decided to explore the trails through the forest I'd previously spotted. Always amazed at how many people ride bikes, I was equally surprised at the number of walkers, runners, and cyclists in the forest. A network of relatively straight paths cross cross a large forest area behind the university, castle, and cemetery. I felt great and my pace was quick but soon I started to succumb to the heat. My heart rate rose an though I didn't feel the need to slow my pace I knew I must if I were to make it "home". My ad-hoc forest loop ended up being just longer than 7.2 km and I set a new seasonal heart rate max (194 bpm). The best part? The envealoping forest. Absolutely wonderful conditions I wish I lived closer to.
